PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, yesterday in the Senate, Senator Walsh, during Question Time, referred to my-I quote him:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . having been an active partner of the firm Northmore, Hale, Davy and Leake in 1973 at the time that that firm set up the first tax evasion scheme for Christo Moll.
A little later he said:
The question of whether Senator Chaney was personally involved in devising the scheme is a matter for conjecture-

Reports of those comments have been published in a number of newspapers and I have seen the reports in the Daily Telegraph, the Age and the Australian. Some of the reports and the headlines go further than what was said in the Senate by Senator Walsh. I was advised last night that Senator Walsh's office was actively promoting the reporting of his remarks in the Senate. In response to inquiries which were made to my office about my connection with the law firm, my Press Secretary issued the following Press statement last night:
Allegations in the Senate by Senator Walsh about Senator Chaney's association with the Perth law firm of Northmore, Hale, Davy and Leake:
Senator Chaney was an active member of Northmore, Hale until his election to the Senate in May 1974.
I added that I was a member of that firm from 1964 to 1974 and I was an active member in the sense that I earned my living by practising law as a member of that firm. The statement continues:

Thereafter he had no professional involvement but remained a partner until his appointment to the Fraser ministry in August 1978. His recollection is that by 1975 his financial interest in the firm had been reduced to $10.
Senator Chaney is aware that Mr C. T. Moll was at some stage a client of the firm but he was never involved in personal dealings with him.
I extrapolate that I was never involved in doing any professional work of any sort for him. The statement continues:
He--
that is me, Senator Chaney-

has had only occasional social contacts with members of the firm since election to Parliament but in no sense seeks to distance himself from the firm for which he retains a high regard and respect for their professional competence.

Again, I add that a number of the present members of the firm remain good personal friends. I would like to make it quite clear, in light of the reports and in light of Senator Walsh's comments, that at no time have I had any involvement in the devising of any form of tax evasion schemes. I have not advised on such matters. I have not had any involvement in such matters. I also wish to make it quite clear that the firm of which I was a member from 1964 to 1974 is a firm of solicitors carrying on a broad general practice which ranges from involvement in legal aid through to large commercial work. At no time have I individually or through that firm had anything to do with tax evasion schemes. I also wish to add that I have never had any reason to doubt the integrity of my ex-partners.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I am sorry, I did not hear the beginning of what Senator Chaney said, but I did hear him make a reference to my office actively promoting the story. A member of my staff, with my approval, did phone some journalists; I am not sure how many. The reason for that was that the statement issued by Mr Kessell implied that the comment I had made referred to 1975. A member of my staff rang journalists-I am not sure how many-to draw their attention to the fact that the comment I made referred to 1973.

—by leave-I would like to make it quite clear that, as was indicated in the Senate yesterday, the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, referred to events which had first occurred in his view in 1973. So that the position will be quite clear, I indicate that the statement from my office pointed out that I was an active member. I have explained that that means that I made my living full time with that firm until my election to the Senate in May 1974. I reject any suggestion that in what was put forward there was any intention other than to put down the clear factual position.

—The relevance of 1975 is that from the day of my election to this place I did not do any professional work. I put my full time into my political life. Over a period, I disengaged myself financially from the firm and that process concluded, I think, at the end of 1975 when, for personal and sentimental reasons as much as anything else, I maintained a $10 interest with the firm with which I was very pleased to be associated.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Sex Discrimination Legislation
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 could be used to support the provision by the Commonwealth Government of funding, counselling, etc. for deliberately procured abortions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled:
should amend the Sex Discrimination Bill so as to prevent it from being used in support of deliberately procured abortions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 30 citizens), Boswell (from 71 citizens), Childs ( from 15 citizens), Chipp (from 40 citizens), Dame Margaret Guilfoyle (from 59 citizens), Lewis (from 83 citizens), Missen (from 52 citizens), Primmer (from 50 citizens), Robertson (from 55 citizens) and Zakharov (from 52 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President, and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that 'The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State'. And
Whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1)
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are concerned about foreign owned military bases on Australian territory and the entry into Australian waters and territory of foreign warships and aircraft carrying nuclear weaponry. And that the Australian Government should take an active and constructive role in the promotion of a nuclear-free world. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. Promote the expression of Australian sovereignty by legislating to bring foreign military bases on Australian territory under the control of the Australian Government.

2. Make it compulsory that the disclosure of weaponry carried by foreign warships and aircraft be given in confidence to the Australian Government prior to a request for entry. And that foreign warships and aircraft that carry nuclear weaponry be banned from Australian waters and territory.
3. Legislate for the cessation of all uranium mining in Australia and its subsequent export.

4. Urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to pose to the Governments of the United States and the Soviet Union that both countries agree to immediately halt the testing, production and further deployment of all nuclear weapons, missiles and delivery systems in a way that can be checked and verified by both sides.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justices and equality which could be used to
undermine civil liberties and religious freedoms.
entrench abortion funding and render liable to action hospitals, doctors and nurses who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations.
deny to parents their rights to insist that the school ''community'' provide an environment conducive to the development, including the moral development of their children.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled:

should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of the principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1982-83

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The annual report of the Department of Housing and Construction which is before us is an interesting report. It covers the creation of the new department following the election of the Labor Government on 5 March. It also gives us details of the previous Government's programs and operations in the period immediately preceding the election. That period, of course, was the bulk of the year. I should like to run through some of the highlights of the report which are set out at page 3. I note, for instance, that there has been a very significant increase in the total expenditure on public housing in the last financial year. In fact an extra 27 per cent will be provided to the States which will total more than $332m. Significantly, the larger part of that occurred because $100m was made available by the former Fraser Government as a result of the wage pause program which, of course, was initiated in December of last year. Significantly, there have been very big rises in total expenditure in housing over the last financial year. It behoves us all to recognise that whilst the present Government is making a great deal of play out of the housing recovery which it claims is under way, a great part of this was initiated under the former Government prior to the election in 1983.

It is also wise to recognise the economic statement made on 19 May by the present Government, which was heralded with a great deal of trumpeting, to increase the amount of money going to housing. According to that document, in the 1983-84 financial year there would be an increase of some $77m in the total payments for housing. That same statement indicates a net reduction in the next financial year, 1984-85, of $255m, and looking further out, to the year 1985-86, a further net reduction in housing funds of $265m.

That runs at odds with the Government's claimed intention of putting more money into housing. Whilst the economic statement cannot be taken, I suppose, on the face of it, as being the most significant statement of economic policy, because clearly the Government is apt to change its mind as it turns every corner, as it has done over the last seven months, it indicates that although the Government has been anxious to spend more money on housing in this last financial year, its intention for the next two years is not at all clear, and that there will be a contraction in housing expenditure over the next two years. We on this side of the chamber are concerned about that because we have had no explanation from the Government as to its intentions, except that it intends to boost, so it says, the emphasis on housing expenditure from the private sector to the public sector . We hope to have more information about that in the near future. We would expect further explanations as to how that might be financed and what are the Government's intentions in dealing with the States in the next 12 months in clarifying its intentions in that regard.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 205th report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The 205th report contains the Department of Finance minute on the Committee's earlier report, No. 197, on coal export duty. The Department of Finance minute is the formal mechanism used by the Government for responding to the Committee's recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: The inquiry into coal export duty arose from comments made by the Auditor- General in his report of 1979-80. The Committee's report on this inquiry was tabled in Parliament on 29 April 1982. The inquiry indicated a need for the development of a consistent and stable policy on coal export duty. It also highlighted the fact that considerable uncertainty has been generated within the industry by the almost annual changes in policy. The Committee suggested in the report that a co-ordinated approach involving discussions with all interested parties, including State governments, should be developed to ensure the fair and equitable taxation of the coal export industry.

As a rule, the Committee does not concern itself with the substance of Government policies but rather with their administration or implementation. The distinction, however, is not always easy to draw. During this inquiry the Committee felt that it could not separate the difficulties involved in the administration of coal export duty from policy considerations. Consequently, the 197th report does concern itself to some extent with policy issues. As a result, the response, which was submitted to the Committee on 18 April 1983, is presented predominantly in terms of the previous Government's policies in this area.

Following the change of government, events have now progressed towards a resolution of these matters. The need for substantial discussions and consultations with the coal industry, with State governments and with other interested organisations has been recognised by the Government. A major initiative of the Government on coming to office was the convening of a national coal conference in March 1983 to discuss a wide range of issues and problems affecting the industry. That conference was attended by Commonwealth Ministers, relevant Ministers from New South Wales and Queensland and representatives of the coal producers, coal mining unions and the Joint Coal Board. The conference agreed on a number of immediate measures including:
The establishment of the Australian Coal Consultative Council;
A review of the Joint Coal Board;
A Commonwealth review and firming up of export control procedures;
The sponsoring of missions to overseas markets and newly emerging markets;
The promotion of education in coal use technology and logistics in less developed countries;
The carrying out of intensive research on identified market opportunity; and
The strengthening of bilateral relationships with consumer governments.

Coal industry representatives have drawn attention to financial pressures brought about by the levels of government charges on the coal industry. In this regard, the March coal conference noted that it would be a matter for the industry to pursue these matters directly with the State governments concerned. The Commonwealth, for its part, has since raised with State governments, through the Australian Minerals and Energy Council-AMEC-an intention to rationalise taxes and charges on the industry through the introduction of a properly designed resource rent tax. Consultations have already commenced.

The Committee will continue to take an interest in this matter. The Committee believes that the Government's policy should be directed at ensuring the efficient exploitation of Australia's coal resources, with particular regard for domestic requirements and the balanced development of our coal exports. I commend the report to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the Appropriation Bills, I take the opportunity to raise a substantially important issue in the Budget which has been ignored. It affects many thousands of people throughout our community.

—Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. Could I clarify whether Senator Missen is speaking to the first reading or the second reading of these Bills? The first reading, is it? I am sorry; we did not have notification of it.

—I refer to the announced decision by the Government in a statement made in May this year, in the Budget Statement and in the forthcoming legislation to remove the current rights of friendly societies throughout Australia. I refer to their right to be exempt from taxation on their incomes, a right they have enjoyed for over 100 years. I propose to deal with this matter. I know that many of my colleagues have dealt with general matters raised in the Budget and I support basically their criticisms in that area. But I prefer on this occasion to raise this issue so that members of the Senate and the public generally can realise the problems which will need to be faced as a result of a little publicised decision of the Government which it appears determined to carry on with.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to a long standing right of organisations in this community known as friendly societies, which operate in practically every State in the Commonwealth . Many have operated over many years, starting from the early part of last century. One of the benefits they have had, and to which reference can be found in the first Income Tax Act of this Parliament, passed back in 1915, is the right not to have to pay taxation on their income. In this way the organisations have represented small people in the community, people of relatively low incomes who have come together in a spirit of mutuality to provide benefits for each other. Those benefits have varied over the years because the State has accepted certain responsibilities and the societies have, in turn, removed themselves from those areas and provided other desirable benefits for their members. So thousands of members of these societies are affected by this threatened removal of their rights.

In the announcement made by Mr Keating on 19 May 1983 at page 810 of the House of Representatives Hansard, the Treasurer makes clear what is to be done by the Government. He expressed the Government's intention in these words:

Friendly societies do not currently bear tax on investment income from their life insurance and disability and accident insurance business. This has placed friendly societies at a distinct advantage over life insurance companies and has been a growing cause for concern. With the assistance of tax exemption their business has grown rapidly in recent years, and has involved policies of a kind which are of concern from a tax avoidance viewpoint. The Government has decided that the exemption for friendly societies on life, disability and accident insurance business will be terminated in respect of 1983-84 and later income years. Measures will be introduced to impose tax at a level comparable to that on the non-superannuation business of life insurance companies. Further details will be announced at a later date. This measure will not affect revenue in 1983- 84, but will add to it in 1984-85 and later years, and preserve revenue which would otherwise be foregone.

In the course of this speech I will challenge many of the statements made in that segment of the Treasurer's economic statement of 19 May. But I say at this time that the Government appears quite determined to proceed with it. Of course that decision came like a bolt from the blue; there was no indication of intention before then.
This statement was followed up in the Budget and in Budget Paper No. 1 the following statement is made, under the heading 'Friendly Societies':

The tax exemption for friendly societies on investment income from life, disability and accident insurance business is to be terminated from the 1983-84 income year. Tax is to be imposed at a level comparable to that on the non- superannuation business of life insurance companies.

It is also clear from letters which the Treasurer has written to a number of people who have made complaints about this measure that it will be persisted with. In a letter of 22 September this year, the Treasurer said to a Mr D. F. Adams:
The fact that friendly societies have not until now borne tax on investment income derived from their insurance business has placed them at a distinct competitive advantage over insurance companies.
That, I might say, is hotly denied by friendly societies and others who have investigated this matter. He went on to say:
The precise method of taxation to be applied to the insurance business of friendly societies to achieve this result is still under consideration.

I want to say by way of preliminary remarks that this matter was one about which we were not previously advised or warned in the election campaign. Last year when there was some feeling that some of the selling activities of the friendly societies could lead to some tax avoidance-I will say more about that later-the friendly societies agreed with the Government's position that there should be legislation which would deal with that problem. This legislation has not yet been brought into the Parliament. The societies took action to ensure that there would be no advertising of a sort which might encourage tax avoidance. When the discussions on this matter came to a conclusion on 22 October 1982 the then Treasurer, Mr John Howard, wrote to Mr Bill Cousins, the Secretary of the Friendly Societies of Australia Federal Council. I seek leave to incorporate the letter in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Mr Bill Cousins
Secretary
Friendly Societies of
Australia Federal Council
9 Dequetteville Terrace
Kent Town SA 5067
Dear Mr Cousins

Thank you for your letter of 13 August, 1982 and the submission on taxation and other issues relevant to the status of friendly societies, which you had said in an earlier letter you would furnish to me.

You will recall that, in responding to your earlier letter, I said that the Government did not have before it at that time any proposal for a change in the income tax status of the societies, and I confirm that that continues to be the position. Since I wrote to you, I have, of course, announced the Government's decision to amend the income tax law so as to put a stop to abuse of the present treatment of reversionary bonuses on life or endowment assurance policies, but this, as your submission implicitly recognises, must be seen as a measure of general application rather than as one aimed at particular issuers of such policies.

Given that the Government continues to have no proposals before it for amending the income tax law as it bears on friendly societies, you may agree that any meeting to discuss your submission would be premature. Should any such proposal come before the Government, you may be assured that the submission would be taken into account, and in that event you could expect your Council to be given the opportunity to discuss the proposal.
Yours sincerely
John Howard

TALK.START.PARA: —In that letter Mr Howard makes clear that the previous Government had no proposals before it to amend the income tax law as bearing on friendly societies. The previous Government agreed that before anything would happen the societies' submissions would be taken into account and they would have an opportunity to discuss the proposals. That procedure was known to the taxation authorities and to this Government. One can regrettably say only that that undertaking has been dishonoured and that the societies have found it necessary now to campaign against this proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: Friendly societies today are under a lot of difficulty. I will speak later on other matters in regard to which, due to present Government policies, they will suffer particular problems. As I have said, over the last 100 years or so the societies have enjoyed this freedom from tax which has enabled them, dealing as they do mostly with small policies and small concerns, to compete in some way with the life insurance policies. The life insurance companies have been objecting to this freedom from tax and have worked to have this concession taken away from the friendly societies. Though friendly societies have a low income, they have managed to accumulate some reserves. They have been able to buy and build homes for the aged, nursing homes and buildings of that nature. They have provided facilities which their members very much want. It was said in the statement in May that friendly societies were likely, by some of their policies, to engage in tax avoidance or things of that sort. But is must be borne in mind that the average superannuation policy of the friendly societies in Victoria is $7,500. The societies are of a small nature. They are not engaged in large businesses, and in the various States they have been subject to very severe restrictions of various kinds. I refer in particular to limitations on the size of the policy which they can sell to any person. The limit has been increased only recently.

Before this matter came forward in May I arranged for the Parliamentary Library to prepare a paper, which has now been issued and is available to all members of parliament. I hope it will be widely read. It is Current Issues Brief No. 10 of 1983 headed 'Taxation Status of Friendly Societies'. This matter has been discussed with not only the friendly societies but also the life insurance companies to ensure accuracy. I intend to refer only to some aspects of that paper. Before the legislation comes into this Parliament I urge members of parliament to read and study the detailed material which is set out in that paper. The paper comes to the general conclusion that the life insurance companies have no real disadvantage. They, of course, are allegedly paying 46 per cent tax on their business, but because they have a number of rights and are allowed deductions that figure is very greatly reduced. The fact is that when all the matters in this paper are taken into consideration the friendly societies receive very little advantage. If a tax of 46 per cent is imposed on them many will go to the wall. Clearly, they will not be able to compete in any way with the life assurance offices. I will refer briefly to a number of paragraphs in this paper which make significant points in this regard. Paragraph 15 of the paper states:
The total amount of insurance business done by friendly societies in Australia is not large.
That was a quotation from the report of the Australian Law Reform Commission on Insurance Agents and Brokers. The paper continues:

However, since the tabling in September 1980, of the Law Reform Commission report No. 16 on agents and brokers, the maximum assurance benefits provided by Victorian friendly societies has been raised to $50,000
So there has been a rise in the total amount, but it does not mean that the companies are selling a great number of policies. The paper continues:

This change, together with active marketing, has greatly assisted the expansion of friendly society insurance business in that state. The Victorian Government Statist in its 1982 report mentions that, for the financial year ended 1981 ( latest available figures), friendly societies in that State had $59.1m of ' assurance funds', and income from all sources of approximately $164m.

Paragraph 39 of the paper considers another aspect of this matter, that is, the extent to which government regulation-of course friendly societies are controlled quite strictly under State legislation-very much restricts the societies. The paragraph states:

State legislation governing the registration and activities of friendly societies imposes restrictions and costs on friendly societies which do not have to be borne by life offices. In particular, the level of assurance that societies can offer is limited by respective state legislation rather than left to individual policy documents.
The next paragraphs state:
The levels of friendly society assurance benefits are controlled by the rules of the society, not by individual contact, and are subject to variation by the annual meetings of members.

The type of assurance offered by friendly societies is limited vis-a-vis life offices. Friendly societies are not permitted to conduct superannuation business . This no doubt places friendly societies at a distinct marketing disadvantage compared with life offices.
Regarding the restrictions which are imposed, paragraph 25 of the paper states:

Once registered, their operation is regulated by the submission of annual returns to the government Statist Actuary. The funds held by the societies are to be actuarially valued every five years (or less) and subject to normal audit requirements. Societies must also comply with all legislation applying to specific activities, e.g. the National Health Act 1953 in respect of health insurance activities.
They are restricted by the extent to which they can invest; whereas life assurance companies are under no such type of restriction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to appropriate amounts required for expenditure in 1983-84 from the Consolidated Revenue Fund for the ordinary annual services of the Government. The expenditure program of the Government was outlined in the Treasurer's Budget Speech. The amounts sought in this Bill for each department are detailed in Schedule 2 and total $13,791,053,000; of this total, the Bill seeks authority for the issue of $8,049,737,000, the balance of $5,741,316,000 having already been authorised by the Supply Act (No. 1) 1983-84. An amount of $ 150,000,000 is also included in the Bill for the Advance to the Minister for Finance, the same as was provided in the Supply Act (No. 1) 1983-84 which this Bill, when enacted, will subsume.

A new provision is made under Division 312 for an amount to be appropriated to the Minister for Finance to cover the salary and related administrative costs of additional staff for extensions to on-going programs and for new initiatives announced in the 1983-84 Budget, the precise allocation of which was not known at Budget time. The allocation of this amount between departments will be considered by the Government in the post-Budget period and the expenditure will be classified to the appropriate function. Clause 5 of the Bill provides for appropriation of the Consolidated Revenue Fund to enable the Minister for Finance to issue amounts for payment of increases in salaries and payments in the nature of salary arising out of awards, orders or determinations made under or in accordance with a law. Allowance has been included in the overall Budget figuring for such prospective increases, $110m in respect of persons employed under the defence function and $130m in respect of other Public Service employers; that allowance is not, however, appropriated in advance of any increases being awarded. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
[COGNATE BILL:
APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 2) 1983-84]

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I suggest that it may suit the convenience of the Senate to have a cognate debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2).
—Is it the wish of the Senate to have a cognate debate covering those measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I am sorry; I should have been speaking to the second reading, not the first reading. I wish to make certain other remarks about the position of friendly societies and the disadvantages which they will suffer. Life assurance companies have assets of something like $18,500m. They have 4.3 million policy holders. They are engaged in a very large way with life policies. Of course, they have all the advantages which that increase gives them. Moreover, it is a fact that there has been a great growth in the superannuation engagements of life companies in recent years . Whereas in the year ended 30 September 1982 the ordinary business of life companies rose only 2.2 per cent, the superannuation business of those companies rose by 23.4 per cent. In fact, superannuation premiums accounted for 62 per cent of all premiums that they were receiving. Consequently, this is big business for the life companies. The idea that they are suffering disadvantage does not appear to be supported. In fact, the friendly societies, in a submission in August 1982 to the Commonwealth Government, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Overall, the submission concludes that there is no validity in the claim that Friendly Societies enjoy an unfair advantage over competitive institutions and hence there is no justification for changing the legislative provisions applying specifically to friendly societies.

Indeed, one could put it more strongly and say that to change them would change the balance. I have been given figures which suggest that when one takes into account the effective rate of tax of life companies there is probably something like a 10 per cent advantage for the friendly societies and, in tax terms, a 1.5 per cent advantage. To reverse the situation means a disaster for the friendly societies. I urge members of the Parliament to study the paper carefully. The paper, at paragraph 73, draws attention to the very criticism made about the friendly societies that perhaps some of their policies might have encouraged tax avoidance last year. It states:
Not wishing to act against the public interest, the Council--
that is, the Council of Friendly Societies-

took steps at a special council meeting in June 1982, to regulate the promotion of such policies by friendly societies. It was agreed that each State Council be asked to adopt a code of conduct to control the advertising of flexibile insurance policies.
They were the ones who were under criticism. The paper continues:
The code prohibits, among other things:
the use of the words 'tax-free' or any similar reference or the mention of 'tax- free' equivalent;
the use of 'interest';
the mention of guarantees; and
the restriction of terminology to that normally used in the life assurance industry.

So the friendly societies took action to put their house in order when there was some suggestion of a possibility of some misuse of their facilities. It ill- becomes the Government, I think now to go ahead and hit them in this way when there is no real indication from the facts that are available to me that they enjoy any advantage or are misusing their tax rights at the present time. If, in fact, the normal rate is to be imposed, as indicated in the speech by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), paragraphs 53 and 54 state:

With regard to the proposed rate of tax on friendly societies, a rate of 46 per cent is intended to be charged on investment income of friendly societies arising from life, disability and accident insurance business. This rate is comparable to that charged on the non-superannuation business of life insurance companies.

However, it has been argued that life insurance companies are allowed a series of deductions, including all expenses directly incurred in gaining investment and other assessable income, some management expenses and realised losses on the disposal of investments. These reductions effectively reduce the tax rate of non -superannuation business of the life offices to a much lower rate than the 46 per cent tax rate. Life offices effectively pay only 25 to 30 per cent tax in the dollar on their non-superannuation business.

One can see the way in which this would entirely reverse and put at great risk the activities of the friendly societies. There are a number of other ways in which the friendly societies will be losing. I know this is still the subject of discussion but I think it is proposed under the new pension test which will come in next year that income from friendly society investments will be taken into account. It will therefore be a lesser advantage to people who have this form of investment and who may have had it for years. The bonuses are now to be taxed. That is understood. Changes are to be made in respect of surrendered policies from 1 November this year. Also the friendly societies will suffer a considerable loss from the Medicare agencies which they had but which they are not now to have any real involvement with. So it is a fact that all these matters, some of which are accepted by the friendly societies, are cumulative. To add to them the removal of this right in respect of taxation will be a disaster. The friendly societies have made representations to and had discussions with the Government. They have pointed out that due to many of the Government's proposed changes-the idea of putting some of their moneys from aged persons and so forth into buildings will have to be discontinued. Some societies will go to the wall.

I feel very strongly about this subject due to the representations I have had. I will certainly take every endeavour to persuade the Government that it ought not go down the road it is going down so far as friendly societies are concerned , particularly in the economic circumstances that we are in today. I urge the Parliament to oppose any attempt to take away this long standing right of the friendly societies. When the legislation comes in I hope that there will be a concerted attempt to ensure that the societies do not suffer in this way. I think it is very necessary to put this point of view forward at this stage and to urge people to read the basic paper which has been prepared so we are prepared to argue this matter fully when the legislation comes before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -First I will address myself to some of the general questions of the Budget before coming to one or two particular matters of portfolio interest. I draw the attention of the Senate to some of the factors underlying the Government's Budget which the Government clearly prefers not to have exposed and which are clearly those kinds of things which it has been tending to smooth over in its discussion on financial matters in this country since the Budget was brought down in August. I think we need to recognise that this Budget does represent a very substantial increase in taxation on the Australian community. In some ways one could regard the Government as having been very clever in the way in which it has dealt with this problem by camouflaging certain increases in such a way that they are not going to have an immediate impact on people's pockets but rather will be stretched out over the next 12 months or so.

SPEECH.PARA: I instance the case first of all of the withdrawal of the income tax rebate in respect of the payments for medical insurance and hospital insurance to health insurers. That clearly will impact heavily on individual families in this financial year as it will represent a reduction chiefly in the refunds which pay as you earn taxpayers will suffer when they receive their refunds in July or August of the next financial year. As I say, that is not being felt so much in a weekly sense in terms of increases in taxation during this current year, but it certainly will have its impact a year from now and will show up at that time in lower consumer spending and consequently less activity in the economy. Other issues of that kind have been introduced as a result of the Government's removal of taxation benefits of that kind. There is, of course, the withdrawal of the housing interest tax rebate, which was available to a substantial number of taxpayers and which has been replaced by a more direct housing assistance package which we spoke of a little earlier today in regard to the annual report of the Department of Housing and Construction. That again will affect the average taxpayer to a certain extent. It may not show up so much in terms of his weekly taxation bill but it will be felt in a year or so from now when tax refunds start to flow from the Australian Taxation Office after the submission of returns for the current financial year. A number of other tax rises are camouflaged as well in this way as a result of the provisions of the Budget. For instance, the level at which a taxpayer becomes eligible for a rebate on concessional expenditure has been increased from $1,590 to $2,000. That will, therefore, wipe out effectively for a great bulk of taxpayers a substantial benefit which they have received in the form of taxation rebate each financial year. The effect again will not be felt until July or August of next year.

The Government wins points very well for making soothing sounds and for taking what appears to be very limited action in the taxation area; but, indeed, it has been very savage in the way in which it has attacked the problem. While the effects will not be felt immediately in the pockets of taxpayers, they certainly will be in the year to come. As a result, the economic effects of these actions will be delayed. The assessment is that the total tax payable by each Australian family to the Commonwealth Government will increase by $12 a week. That increase , of course, must be read in conjunction with increased charges by Labor State governments for their services. The effect of those increases is really starting to bite at present.

Other measures that the Government has adopted come to mind. I mention the proposal to increase the tax on lump sum superannuation payments, which was announced in the May economic statement and other matters relating to pensions, such as the assets test which is being proposed for next year. Perhaps worst of all is the indexation of excise charges. That change was introduced in this Budget and it will have a very significant ratchet effect on the cost of day to day goods such as petrol, alcohol and tobacco in the years to come as excise charges are adjusted twice a year in line with the rate of inflation. The Government has found a novel way to avoid the scrutiny by Parliament of taxation increases by simply providing that twice a year all of these excise charges will be increased automatically.

This is akin, of course, to the failure of the present Government to index the income tax scale steps. Of course, during the election campaign this was said to be one of its objectives. It is one that it has failed to achieve. All in all, the promises of income tax cuts which, before the election, were assured to us and which we were so certain would not be denied, have disappeared in a cloud of smoke since 5 May and are not likely to be seen again before the next election campaign starts. It is a wonder, though, that we have not seen some attempt on the part of the Federal Government to make some promises in this area in relation to the election campaign now going on in Queensland. But perhaps the point is being made up there clearly enough by the National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party that if the Australian Labor Party came to power in that State, the result would be higher charges in a State which has the lowest level of taxation of all States.

It is clear that the present Commonwealth Government requires very heavy levels of taxation to meet its expenditure programs and those which it contemplates. We , of course, will be watching very carefully the way in which taxes impact on the economy. But, suffice it to say, even though taxation will rise very significantly this financial year and the following financial year, there still remains a most substantial deficit as revealed by a perusal of the Government's financial papers. That deficit is to be of the order of $8.3 billion, almost double the deficit of the last financial year. That deficit, of course, is the highest proportion of gross domestic product in this country since Federation. That deficit will reach about 4.7 per cent of total gross domestic product this financial year and, of course, it represents a colossal job for the Treasury which must seek to raise money in the year ahead in order to meet that deficit.

Last financial year, money raising programs raised a little over $4 billion for the financing of the deficit in that year. The problem that the Government faces now is much more substantial and will clearly have a very big effect upon the Government's ability to control interest rates in the domestic economy. The Government faces other problems in this regard as well. They arise chiefly from the situation overseas. It is well known that a great deal of short term money, coming in from overseas, is available in the Australian economy at the present time. Indeed the state of our foreign reserves clearly demonstrates that. I think they are running at approximately $10.75 billion at the present time. I suppose that the Government has a clearer view about the extent of short term money which is represented in that reserves figure, but it will be something to watch in the year ahead as we observe very closely whether that money will turn out again in the current year as it perceives changes in the economy and in the international economy as well.

We have to note that the exchange rate for the Australian dollar has risen substantially in recent weeks. In fact, compared with the rate against the United States dollar, it has risen some five points since the presentation of the Budget. That obviously not only will have its effects directly upon exporters and, indeed, upon importers, but also clearly will have implications for the longer term potential of the Australian economy. Any major changes in the exchange rate produce structural adjustments within the economy and will cause movements to some extent not only in industry but also, as a flow on, in the job market. So, there could well be impacts upon the employment situation in this year ahead as a direct result of the firming of the Australian dollar against the American dollar. That development will need to be watched very carefully and we hope that the Government has that situation well in mind.

Some of the factors which will also influence interest rates in this year ahead relate, of course, to the rate of inflation. The Government has budgeted, I suppose-if we can call it that-for a rate of inflation of the order of about 8 per cent in this current year. While that may be somewhat unrealistic in the light of unfolding events at present, it has been calculated in that way as a result of taking into account the Medicare levy, that is, discounting the rate of inflation for the Medicare levy which is said to reduce the potential inflation rate by some 3 per cent which leaves us, of course, with an underlying rate of inflation of the order of 11 1/2 per cent which is approximately the rate which applied in the last financial year.

It has to be remembered that, even though there may be perceptions that the consumer price index is running at about 8 per cent as a result of this sleight of hand, the underlying cost of building materials, industry inputs and various consumer goods of kinds other than those measured in the CPI may well be running at an inflation rate far higher than that which is said to be the CPI. I think that has very serious implications for some industries, certainly for the building industry. When we have a buildup of demand in the building industry, such as is now occurring in Australia, it can have only a very positive effect in terms of increasing prices in the building trade. If that is so and if the inflation rate as perceived by the Government's calculations is to be about 8 per cent, the real level of interest rates might still remain very high.

I think one of the most disturbing features about this Budget is that, irrespective of what might be the perception in respect of the CPI, interest rates may not fall this year to the extent that was hoped earlier, for two reasons. The main reason is that the rate of inflation which I have just described may be different from that perceived. Another reason, which I have also mentioned, is the size of the Budget deficit and the need for the Government to finance that deficit by raising funds in the money markets-both domestically and overseas-and by competing against the private sector in the money market. That potential for increase is recognised in the Budget Papers and does represent a very real risk to the Budget strategy.

In terms of the domestic wage policy which is closely linked, of course, to the whole question of interest rates and inflation, one must have very real concerns about the trend in the labour market at the present time. The Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission recently announced a national wage increase of 4.3 per cent. That had been agreed to by the Government apparently as part of the wages accord with the trade union movement which resulted from the National Economic Summit Conference in April of this year. While it may be called other things these days, the fact is that that decision which, as I said, had substantial support from the Government, clearly is a trend back towards the system of wage indexation which went out of existence in 1981. That means that again we are building into the wages system, and consequently into the rate of inflation in this country, a very high rate of wage increase which unfortunately cannot be easily got rid of by virtue of any attempts on the part of the Government to control wage increases outside that 4.3 per cent.

The point is quite clear that, irrespective of the pressures put on employers by unions and employees generally, any wage increase above that 4.3 per cent will reduce only marginally the impact on inflation of wage cost increases in this year ahead. Substantially we will have built into the system of wage costs the very direct impacts arising from the indexation decision in September. It will have the effect of building into our cost structure future inflation which has very serious implications in terms of the economic recovery which we all hope is now beginning. The decision will make it more difficult for us to sell our goods on overseas markets. It will also, of course, make it easier for importers of overseas manufactured goods to sell on Australian markets. It will mean that as a result of the rising dollar, which is the current trend in our balance of payments policies, increased levels of consumer goods and other manufactured goods will enter this country by way of direct imports. All these factors have significant risks for us in terms of the development of job opportunities in this country. Consequently, they put question marks over the whole economic strategy which this Budget represents.

The question of unemployment remains the most intractable problem in this country. The Budget acknowledges this clearly in its supporting papers. The Government has admitted that it will not be able to reduce unemployment levels in the current financial year. It has admitted that there will be some increase in unemployment levels. The great pleasure which the Government has taken in recent days because of the unemployment figures which have been released recently for the month of September bears no scrutiny when one looks carefully at the facts and trends in the labour market. Whilst casting no aspersions on the Australian Bureau of Statistics, it is clear from the way in which the figures have been presented and the way in which the levels have been moving in recent months that there is some serious concern as to whether the statistics truly measure the level of unemployment and employment growth in this country. I noted with interest recent statements and reports that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, will be undertaking a review of the means by which statistics are collected to measure unemployment. It seems to me to be a most important aspect of the problem facing us at the present time. I hope that the Minister has in mind examining the methods by which this information is collated so that we can build up a little more confidence in the month to month trends which are evidenced by the monthly bulletins.

The concerns of the Australian community about the Budget have been well expressed in this place and in the House of Representatives in recent weeks. Clearly, the Budget strategy is one of high risk. That is acknowledged in the Budget Papers. Indeed the Budget strategy, if one carefully reads the Budget Papers, is demonstrated quite clearly in some of the references to interest rates, monetary policy, exchange rate policy and the level of inflation, both as it is perceived and as it may develop in the year ahead. We on this side of the Senate believe that the Government reluctantly is coming to the view that it cannot fight both inflation and unemployment at the same time. In fact, it is clear from all the Government's statements that it has recognised the sequential nature of the effect of inflation on unemployment, otherwise it would not be attacking with such vigour the question of the wages accord and then talking down the union demands for increased wage payments.

The Government has recognised the interconnection between inflation and unemployment. Consequently, the Government has recognised the basic statements of the previous Government in that regard. Hopefully, the Government will be able to exercise some degree of control over the trade union movement as a result of the accord agreed to at the National Economic Summit Conference. We on the Opposition benches believe that the Government will have considerable problems in doing so, as has already been evidenced by some of the breakouts in the wage increases in recent weeks. We have seen demands being made by various unions-not all of them the most militant-and consequently we have very serious doubts about the Government's ability to control this area. But it is a major breakthrough that the Government has recognised the interrelationship of these problems and consequently is addressing its mind to them in whatever misguided fashion it may deem necessary.

The Budget is basically a high risk Budget. It introduces to Australians the highest level of deficit that this country has ever seen. It will provide significant difficulties for the Government in seeking to finance that without producting both new inflation and higher interest rates, We wish the Government well. We hope that it recognises the true risk it is facing and that it does not seek to mislead the public by issuing bromides of the kind that it has been issuing in recent months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —These Appropriation Bills are a key element in the Government's Budget strategy and the implementation of its political philosophy and the promises that it made in the last election campaign. It is worth remembering that the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in March of this year:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe the Australian people have had enough of election promises made to be broken.
I offer no fistful of dollars to be snatched back after the election.

That is what he said before he became Prime Minister. It is worth examining what has happened since then and how these promises have been reflected in or omitted from the current Appropriation Bills. I should like to look at just a few of them. There are so many that it would take all day to deal with them, so let us look at a few. In the Australian Labor Party policy speech on 16 February 1983, Mr Hawke said:
Our government's total income tax package is being released concurrently with this speech.
Referring to this package, he said:
. . . a new six step tax scale to restore the progressive nature of the tax system.
It has not been introduced. There is no sign of it in either the mini-Budget or the Budget. Mr Hawke, in the ALP policy speech of February 1983, speaking of the income tax package, said:
Its key elements include immediate reductions in income tax for almost 6 million Australian taxpayers.
The same man said on 17 June:
We are not going to be cutting income taxes in the immediate future.
Mr Hawke, in the ALP policy speech of February 1983, said Labor would introduce:
. . . a lift in the tax threshold to $5000 which will free tens of thousands of low income earners from all tax.
What has happened in the Budget that we are considering? Nothing. Let us look at a different area, perhaps that of pensions. In the ALP policy speech of 16 February 1983, Mr Hawke said:
There can be no lift in profits or a lift in growth unless there is a lift in demand. And that cannot be done by taking money out of the weekly pay packet or the pensioner's cheque.
But in May 1983, in the mini-Budget, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said:

The third major measure we have decided to take in relation to retirement incomes is to introduce an income test on the component of age and services pensions for persons aged 70 years and over which is presently paid free of any income test.

So much for the remark: 'This cannot be done by taking money out of the pensioner's cheque'. In the ALP policy speech of February 1983, Mr Hawke promised to index pensions one month after CPI figures were released. The same man on 8 August said:
We will increase indexed pensions and benefits in November-
which is four months after the CPI figures are produced. In the ALP policy speech of February 1983, Mr Hawke said that Labor would introduce:
. . . a lift in the tax threshold for pensioners of $4650 to $5893.
What happened in the Budget? Nothing. In the ALP policy speech of February 1983, Mr Hawke said:
We are committed to raising over a three-year period the basic pension rate from 22 per cent of average male earnings . . . to 25 per cent.

This Budget did not alter it. As I have said, one could go on almost indefinitely on this subject, but let us look at one other area, that of the Government Information Unit. The Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, constantly carped on the existence of the Government Information Unit and the use made of it by the previous Government. He said just before the election:
A Labor Government will wind down the Government Information Unit.

I suppose that it did. What it did was to wind down the Government Information Unit and wind up the National Media Liaison Service, with the result that expenditure in this area has doubled, from $500,000 a year to $1m a year, and the number of staff has risen from 17 to 33. So much for winding down government services. I could deal with a dozen more items, but I take only one more. At a Press conference on 15 April 1983 the Prime Minister said:
There has been no basis for the speculation that the tax rate on lump sum superannuation payments would be increased.
We all know what has happened since then.

These are the disposable promises, what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) calls 'Hawkespeak'. At present the Government appears to be persuading the people that in some way they are not being broken. But they are, and the people are coming to realise that they are. The excuse used by the Government is that it was misled as to the size of the deficit. It seems very confused as to which year it is talking about. Many on the Government benches seem to be thinking and arguing about the deficit for 1982-83. In fact, at the time that all these promises were made by the Labor Party there had been no announcement of any description about the size of the deficit for 1983-84--

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, there had; Howard said it was going to be $6 billion.

—Yes, I am coming to that matter. These promises were made by the Labor Party, presumably after rational consideration-although one doubts that- before there had been any discussion on the size of the deficit. Only three days before the election, after all those promises had been made, did the question of the deficit, not for the current year but for the next year, come up. That was a projection based on extremely pessimistic forecasts of the nature of revenue and on extremely optimistic or large forecasts of expenditure, which is very normal in the early stages of Budget preparation. The Labor promises were all made without any misleading as to the size of the deficit for future years. I am not arguing that these promises should have been kept. The situation is that we already have far too high a deficit. The point is that the promises should never have been made. They were totally irresponsible and constituted a gross misleading of the Australian people as to the intentions and practicability of Labor policies.

SPEECH.PARA: We are now looking at the consequences of these sorts of actions-promising one thing and doing another. Perhaps the most dramatic of these has been the way in which both the election campaign and the National Economic Summit Conference were conducted on the basis of unemployment. The Premier of New South Wales said : 'The issue is jobs, jobs, jobs'. The trouble is that nothing has been done about it. The unemployment figures for September have just been released. They show an increase in unemployment from 10.2 per cent to 10.4 per cent. What is the Government saying? It is saying: 'This is a sign of economic recovery'. I would hate to see signs of economic deterioration in the Government's eyes. What we appear to be condemned to by the Government, despite all the rhetoric in the election campaign and at the Summit, is three-quarters of a million people out of work for years to come. The Government argument is that the worse job market signifies recovery. But how can one possibly accept the logic of that argument? If one does accept it, the blame for unemployment must lie with the unemployed themselves-or else, as Senator Messner pointed out, it is possible that the figures are wrong.

The reality is that the blame for unemployment rests with those in jobs and a government which encourages them to be selfish. If we wish to reduce the level of unemployment there must be some sacrifice by the 90 per cent of people in jobs. Far from sacrificing anything, they are becoming more greedy. The Australian Council of Trade Unions is fighting for a shorter working week. At first sight it might seem that that will increase jobs. But we all know the motive is not to increase jobs. It is merely a concealed pay rise. The consequence of this demand, if accepted, and it may be, inevitably will be more unemployment. This Government has institutionalised unemployment. It has given it a type of legitimacy and tried to get people to take it for granted. For instance, why did not the Government comment seriously on the unemployment figures which show that in September 27.5 per cent of teenagers who want work are unemployed compared with less than 20 per cent last year? Australia is the only industrialised country which officially expects unemployment to rise as recovery gains momentum. Professor David Kemp put it well when he said:

Governments and the major groups in the community get together to protect their interests. The thrust of the Summit approach is very much in the traditional Australian direction of 'protection all round' by the exercise of central authority rather than the more radical approach of replacing authority with market exchanges.

The Summit debates clearly reveal a continuing aspiration on the part of government, union and some business leaders as well as some of the new interests (defined as conservation, consumer, welfare and church groups) towards a further extention of the use of centralised authority in the regulation of economic and social life.

This Government has applied protection all round. It has given government and unions what they wanted-namely, wage indexation. Business got nothing more than predictable wage rises and the consequences of these can be devastating. I think the most irresponsible submission to an arbitration commission I have ever seen was the one made by the Government in the national wage case. That submission argued that incapacity to pay particular industries should be ignored. The submission by the counsel for the Government was that the Government was aware that some companies would have difficulties in paying wage rises. The lawyer presenting the government case went on to say:
In any economic circumstances marginal firms or industries will experience economic difficulties. This is part of the normal process of growth and readjustments of the economy.

First, the Government cripples a company by official action and then blames market forces-the cheek of it-for its crash. This was the most absurd economic argument ever put by a supposedly responsible government which is destroying industries by official action and then saying that market forces were to blame. There was no such thing.

This sort of nonsensical argument put by governments is enormously damaging. It is very difficult to get a sensible wage and economic structure in this country while Labor governments talk such nonsense. In the Summit, and in the Budget since, the unemployed have been bought off with an irresponsibly high Budget deficit which can only delay the return to lower unemployment. Wage indexation is based on a very high inflation rate and most of the increase in government spending, which we are considering at the moment, will go into wages and imports , not into profits and jobs. We have said over and over again that the profitability of companies in this country is far too low. Out of profits come investment and out of investment comes jobs. The first task of a sensible government interested in reducing unemployment would be to restore reasonable profitability to Australian industries. Instead of that the Government has damaged them still further. The implicit assumption in all this argument is that a public service job is a perfect substitute and equal in all ways to a job in private enterprise. But the private sector is capable of generating three times as many jobs as the public sector and this should always be borne in mind.

What have the unemployed received out of the National Economic Summit Conference and the Budget? They have received nothing. The only relief to the unemployed came from the wage pause put into place by the previous Government and destroyed by the present Government. If this Government had extended the wage pause there might have been some hope in the near future for the unemployed . But why should the Government care about the unemployed? After all, only 10 per cent of the people are out of work and 90 per cent are in work. The Government is too busy running a popularity campaign with the 90 per cent majority of its fellow Australians who are in jobs to care about the 10 per cent who are unemployed. Unions, of course, are also interested only in their own members, and most of them are in jobs. The Government did not offer wage cuts at the Summit or before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, as has been done in other countries in comparable circumstances, to try to save jobs in those industries crippled by the recession. What happened instead was the Government argued for an increase in wages and said that if businesses could not pay those increases they should go to the wall because they were subject to the ordinary operation of market forces. This is the way in which the Government considers jobs. It does not have any significant policy in this area. Did not the unions suggest deals in certain industries, such as the car industries, for no pay rises in return for job guarantees? What they got was an across the board pay increase. Apparently it did not matter if a flat increase destroyed the competitiveness of the industry. It was too bad for the company and too bad for its employees if the business went to the wall.

We may have a recovery, one has to admit, through circumstances quite beyond the Government's control-although I suppose the Prime Minister believes he personally broke the drought-but this recovery will be skewed by a heavy dose of government spending and a few one-off factors such as bumper rural crops and stock building by businesses. However, wage indexation will prevent many industries from recovering at all and there is no recovery in sight for the unemployed. There has been a great deal of euphoria in the last few weeks about Australia's dramatic successes in the America's Cup. I must say, as a former sailor, that watching match racing between two yachts is about as exciting as watching grass grow. Nevertheless, the result was dramatically exciting although the actual racing was not a good spectacle. Our win in the America's Cup was dramatic because it brought out our good qualities as a nation. It showed that we use superior technology to the Americans, that we use good workmanship and design and that we had a trained and disciplined crew which used highly skilled tactics.

TALK.START.PARA: —That sounds like this Government.

—I will come to that in a moment, Senator Grimes. These are all qualities which Australians can show but by no means always do show. These qualities were necessary to win the most highly competitive sporting contest in the world, and we succeeded. But competing as part of the world ecomomy these days is at least as competitive as the America's Cup. Unfortunately, in competing on the world economy we handicap ourselves dramatically. Are we, in our industrial life, technologically innovative? Do we try new things as a matter of course or do we copy too much? Would we have won the America's Cup if we had carried two extra crew unnecessarily because some earlier design of yacht had had a larger crew?

SPEECH.PARA: Would we have won if the crew members had worked to rule as a protest because someone had said something rude about their sail handling? Would we have won if they had gone on strike because someone found a cockroach in some obscure corner of the boat? Would we have won if they had demanded treble time for racing on a public holiday? Of course we would not have won.

We can be highly competitive and we can win. We must bring the sorts of spirit, attitudes and organisation that won the America's Cup to our industrial and social life. When we can do that, if we are not given the sort of negative leadership provided by the present Government, and when we get a proper sense of direction and proper leadership, we, as a country, can shine internationally in all fields as we have shone in the America's Cup.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's Budget is regarded by all of us in this chamber and by the public of Australia as the best indication of the Goverment's intention. It represents the Government in action. If we consider the Budget priorities for spending the Australian taxpayers' money, we will understand the priorities of the Labor Government. We will be able to look at its decisions in action and compare them with the promises that the Australian Labor Party made prior to the last election. We will be able to make a judgment whether the Goverment is living up to its rhetoric and the expectations it created at the time when it sought before Australian voters to be the government of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In this Budget-and, indeed, reinforced by other decisions and announcements throughout 1983-we have seen the Labor Government attack, in particular, three groups of poeple in Australia. First, there is the unemployed. The Government has done nothing for that group. Senator Hamer has outlined that case very well. Senator Grimes, the Minister for Social Security, is in the chamber. The second group that has been directly attacked are the two million age pensioners in Australia. Beyond that group, the Goverment has attacked superannuitants, those who have expectations soon to retire and who are concerned and anxious about their retirement. The third group that the Labor Government has directly attacked is that one million Australian families connected with independent schools.

That formula of the Labor Government to attack the unemployed, the aged and those associated with independent schools is as good a formula as any, as any political commentator in Australia could see, for the demise of this Government at the next election. If the ALP wanted deliberately to lose the support of Australia, it need only attack the three-quarters of a million Australians who are unemployed, the two million Australians who are aged and the one million Australian families who have opted, by direct choice, to be involved with independent schools. The case against the Government's attack on the aged has been well presented by Senator Messner, the Opposition spokesman on social security.

There is no need for me to repeat the decisions made in May by the Hawke Labor Government to tax excessively superannuation payments and to bring back an income test for eligibility for the age pension for the over 70s. The aged people, in their last years, thought themselves secure and they had been given all kinds of reassurances by the Labor Government. The Labor Government had built up a balloon, soon to be deflated, that it was the party of compassion; that it would not hurt these old over-70 Australians. But it did so by decisions announced in that May statement. It told the aged that they were not going to get those pensions any more, that they were to be fully means tested. So many over-70s have become angry and anxious and pessimistic about the years ahead. In the Budget we have seen the reintroduction of the assets test with all the anomalies and inconsistencies that we have drawn out in this place over the last couple of months. The assets test will allow jewellery, paintings and antiques to be exempt. It will allow a person to have a car, a caravan and a boat. All that is exempt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it?

—That is the announcement that the Minister has given us in many statements as we have tried to pinpoint the anomalies. But I see that he is coming back and rethinking this matter. I know that rumours are about that the Labor Government, knowing that it has attacked these two million Australians, is having second thoughts about the exercise. If this debate can be of any further assistance, Senator Grimes, to convince the Labor Government to abandon completely the reintroduction of an assets test, this Opposition will be all the happier, as will the Australian people. The Minister's misgivings now, his recanting, his beginning to find some ground to get out of the mess that he has created is evidenced by his endeavours to interject. I hope that he goes on and abandons this ill-conceived introduction of the assets test. In the next few months we will see whether the assets test is to be abandoned by the Labor Government. As a Liberal senator from South Australia, I certainly wish it to be abandoned. On behalf of all those who have made representations to me, I urge Senator Grimes, the Minister for Social Security, and the Labor Government more truly to live up to the expectations created before the election and to get off the backs of the Australian aged and, with that, to get off the backs of the unemployed by doing something of practical help for them.

SPEECH.PARA: During the Labor Party's term in office, it has even outdistanced our record in the level of unemployment in Australia. Seven hundred and fifty thousand Australians are unemployed and all the Government has done is give them some little compensation by an increase in the unemployment benefit. That is very inadequate action, given the enormous expectations that the Labor Party created prior to the election. We have been arguing-I have argued it since my maiden speech six years ago in this chamber-the need for young Australians to be given a fair go. Why is it that the ratio of young adults unemployed to adults unemployed is 3:1 or 4:1? Why is it that young people-teenagers, boys and girls, young men and young women aged 15 to 19-suffer the most in this period of unemployment? Why can we not give them a fair go? Why do we not allow them to offer their services to employers at a discounted level of wages or salary?

TALK.START.PARA: —Always the same answer, isn't it?

—I think it is, and I have consistently argued that. I am aware of the dangers of exploitation with an open-ended wage structure, whereby unscrupulous employers could take advantage of young Australians who offered themselves for say two-thirds to three-quarters of the adult wage. But let the proposition be defined. Let there be proper discussions by the unions who are concerned only for the 90 per cent of people who are employed and not for the 10 per cent who miss out. Let there be proper discussions involving young people so that they can say to an employer: 'It is true that I do not have the experience of a 30-year-old or a 35-year-old. I have not developed the skills in employment . Perhaps, too, I have come straight from school and have not yet understood the work place. I cannot bring the same level of skill and experience to this work as my 35-year-old competitor, but I am prepared to work for two-thirds of the adult wage. Give me a chance; I want the job and after I have been in this job for two years I will have developed those skills and then I will want to apply for the adult wage'. Why cannot we have a transition-lower wages for the young so that they can say they are worth what they are being paid by their employers?

SPEECH.PARA: At the same time, the wages policy of this Government is playing directly into the hands of the 90 per cent who have jobs. That 90 per cent wants increased wages beyond the ability of Australia to pay. The Labor Government says: 'Let's be popular, let's give these increased wages to the 90 per cent and forget about the 10 per cent. As long as we can get 50 per cent plus one of the vote and as long as we can keep our unions on side, we will keep our political base'. I believe that that view is short sighted; it smells. It is of no direct benefit. An odour is in the nostrils of the unemployed of Australia who have been doubly let down by the new Government.
