They thought that the Hawke Government would create jobs by having a sensible wages policy and would allow new jobs to be created; so that instead of giving wage rises employers would be able to create new jobs. Instead, we have seen during the months of the Hawke Government a further increase in unemployment. The unemployed can only say that this Government has given them a small increase in the unemployment benefit.

To summarise briefly, this Government's record, as it is expressly and most clearly evidenced in the Budget, is an attack upon three important groups of Australians. It is an attack upon the unemployed, 750,000 voters, it is an attack upon the aged, two million voters; and-I will concentrate on this group in my remaining remarks-it is an attack on independent schools and the one million Australian families which have been directly undermined and badly treated by this Government. We know that the education spending of the Commonwealth Government, as indicated in the Budget, will be $3.3 billion. That is just a small increase on last year's expenditure under the Fraser Government. The Hawke Government came to office saying that it would do all these marvellous new things in education. What have we seen? Only empty rhetoric. We have seen only a slight increase in the total commitment to education in Australia, whether it be tertiary or secondary education. Against this backdrop of business as usual, of a failure to live up to any radical change to the stable, consolidated position that the Liberal and National parties had given to education in Australia we have seen a direct attack upon independent schools.

Yesterday in the debate in this chamber on a matter of public importance Senator Baume, our spokesman on education, Senator Lewis and I were joined by Senator Macklin of the Australian Democrats in raising a matter which we regarded as most urgent. I refer to the uproar in Australia about the undermining of the foundation principles of government support-taxpayer support- for the independent schools of Australia. What was the promise made during the election campaign? The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, said that he would, through an ALP government, seek to provide unity in the field of education, to overcome the sectarian divisiveness of the state aid debate, and he would bring as much consensus to education as he would to every other field. This promise has been broken. In particular, the reassurances given to non-government schools have been neglected. It was a sorry story when the Labor Party, with Mr Dawkins as its spokesman, put into place the policies of those in the Labor Party who were opposed not just to the flourishing of the non-government schools but to the non -government schools full stop. There are in the Labor Party persons who are totally committed to abolishing independent schools.

TALK.START.PARA: —Knock it off!

—Let me quote for the honourable senator a Mr Jerry Tickell, a former President of the Australian Teachers Federation. He has been appointed by the Cain Government in Victoria to the education board in that State. He is on public record, as an appointee of a Labor government in Victoria, along with his colleagues in the Australian Teachers Federation-who are, in all of the cities and towns of New South Wales, Victoria and the other parts of Australia, key members of Labor Party branches-as saying they want to abolish any kind of taxpayer support for non-government, independent schools.
—That is not Labor Party policy.

—It may be a minority; Senator Grimes was nodding his head. I am saying that there are within the Labor Party persons who are totally committed to abolishing any kind of government support for independent schools. What sorts of persons make up this group within the Labor Party which had such a major part in formulating the policies which, under spokesman Dawkins, became the policies of the Labor Party? The policies of the Labor Party became so extreme during the Dawkins period that the Labor Party took the political step of taking Dawkins away from education and putting in a more stable, milder, more compassionate and conciliatory person in Chris Hurford. He became the Labor Party's spokesman in the run-in to the election in March. Mr Hurford had to try to repair all the danger signals and all the broken relationships that had emerged in response to the declared ALP policies. As honourable senators would know, in those weeks leading up to the March election Mr Hurford was going from one group of non- government schools to another, working out formulas, trying to reinforce assurances and changing the wording on certain statements so that at least the non-government schools would become a little quieter during that election campaign. Now even those assurances, even those formulas, have been set aside.

SPEECH.PARA: Who are these opponents in the Labor Party of state aid? There are those who are, by personal conviction, secularists. They believe that we should have a secular Australia. That is a legitimate view for anyone to have. They want there to be no involvement in Australian schools of any religion; nor do they want even any independent foundation for a school or any independent set of goals for a school. They say we should gain cohesion in Australia by uniformity. They do not want difference; they want everyone to be the same. Some people might have that view; I disagree with it. Then the members of a second group, because of whatever propaganda or ideology they have picked up along the way or whatever unfortunate experience they may have had as children or as adults, have come to be just anti-religionists.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very few of the Labor Premiers have ever seen the inside of a government school.
—Senator Baume is right. I declare my interest: I profess to be a Christian. I am not a very good Christian but I strive to follow carefully what the scriptures have to say.
—That is your prerogative.

—That is my prerogative, I agree. I have declared my interest. I want my family to be able to express the values and have the commitment of a Christian. I want to see in them the advantages of having been at a Christian school, which is complementary to the Christian family. I believe that it is the wish of very many Australians to see the school system directly reinforcing, elaborating and enriching the values and commitments of the family at home in the same way as other philosophies, beliefs and religions are expressed in the schools of Australia. I strongly hold that independent schools have a right to exist in Australia so that parents are able to choose the kind of education they want for their children. Unfortunately the Council for the Defence of Government Schools was formed-after fund raising and public meetings to gain support for its campaign-which is equally committed to opposing any kind of religious school in Australia. This group somehow has the view that the beliefs which are being taught are superstitious, nonsense or are doing harm. It is out to stop those schools.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that those illiberal, secularist and anti-religious people have been joined by another group-a small embittered minority who have an us/them view of state and independent schools. This attitude has been directly reflected in debates in this chamber and it is certainly reflected in statements to be found all over the country in teachers journals of the last six or seven years. The view has been put forward that 'we' in the state schools are being disadvantaged by 'them' in the independent schools because every dollar 'they' get from the taxpayer is being denied to 'us'. A false picture, a false dichotomy, is drawn between 'us' and 'them'.

The argument put by the Australian Teachers Federation in its propaganda during the last election campaign was: 'The Fraser Government has given dollars to the independent schools which ought to be given to us. We are in direct competition with them'. Whatever the background, beliefs or rhetoric of those opponents of the independent schools, I put to the Senate that a group within the Australian Labor Party has had a victory, having convinced the present Government to take away the foundation principles of government funding for independent schools so that money taken away from them can be given to the state schools. Those fears which I am seriously expressing are the fears of one million Australian families . I put it to the Government that by alienating those families it will alienate the votes which it will require to win the next election. Therefore I urge that the foundations principles with regard to taxpayer support for independent schools, which have been established for many years, be not undermined by the ALP, as they presently are, but be re-established.

I will very briefly explain five of these principles. There is the establishment of choice principle. A family or a group of families in a local area ought to be able to establish a new independent school which reflects the philosophies and the educational strategies that they choose.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Marxist schools? If it were a Marxist school, would you go along with that?

—The honourable senator should let the people vote with their feet. Let there be real freedom. Ministers should not be able to censor the sorts of schools which can be established. We heard Senator Ryan, when she was the Opposition Labor spokesman for education, condemn freedom of choice. She said there were community schools and small schools which ought not to exist.
—Rubbish.

—I can quote from Hansard. I believe that there ought to be freedom in Australia. I am a liberal and I believe that parents and children can vote with their feet as long as the education principles of every school meet the requirements of registration according to State law. The establishment of choice principle has been abandoned because the anti-state-aid members of the ALP have said: 'First of all, our strategy must be to stop any new school being developed. We will establish a new criterion'. This was announced by Senator Ryan in late July. She said that if new schools were competing with existing schools for potential enrolments, establishment funding would not be approved. Moreover this new set of censoring barriers and criteria was backdated to the day of the election, the disaster day for independent schools, when the ALP came into office. We saw in the debate on the report on Radford College an attempt by some supporters of the ALP to integrate existing independent schools within the state school system.
—Didn't we reject that report?

—It was rejected by the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan), but nevertheless her appointed commissioners looked into the Radford College proposal and came up with the suggestion of integration. It gained support amongst those gung ho members of the ALP who wanted to see integration eventuate. Can Ministers of the Labor Government deny that there are those within the ALP who are totally committed to achieving that integration goal which was set out in the report on Radford College? I believe that the debate in the Senate and more especially the public meetings which were attended by 700 to 900 citizens of Canberra turned the Government about. I am seeking, in this debate and in all debates, to get the Government to abandon this denial of the foundation principles on which state aid has been given to independent schools.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the abandonment of the honesty principle. It has been talked about by others as the nexus. It is the principle which keeps an education policy honest by ensuring that a direct proportion of the cost of a state school place goes to an independent school. This honesty principle has been directly abandoned by Senator Ryan and the Labor Government. She boasted about it, for example, in her Hurstville speech, at the end of September.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have abandoned indexation.

—The Government has abandoned the indexation which would have kept its policy honest. It has lived up to the strategy of the members of the ALP who say: 'We want to stop not only new schools developing but also indexed grants and the guarantee that the recurrent grant in real terms will continue, but to smudge the abandonment of the principle in this first year we will actually give a 3 per cent real increase to level 3 schools'. But that has not fooled the bishops. It has not fooled the representatives of the other independent schools. Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to incorporate a Press release of the bishops of Australia, which is dated 1 September.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The Central Commission of the Catholic Bishops of Australia in Canberra today vigorously re-affirmed the School Funding Policy of the Bishops as presented by their Catholic Education Commission in November 1982.
The Central Commission expressed its very deep concern over two aspects of the funding guidelines recently given by the Government to the Commonwealth Schools Commission.

The Government has decided to abolish the nexus between the cost of educating a child in a government school and the level of recurrent grants to non-government schools. This is against the Bishop's stated policy and is potentially destructive of non-government schooling. The removal of this automatic linking also minimises the capacity of non-government schools to plan.

The Bishops expressed misgivings over the decision to reduce the basic recurrent grant to some students. The right of all students to share in educational funding would be endangered if this reduction were a move towards excluding any student from a basic grant.

The Bishops re-affirmed the role of Government in relation to those in need. However, once again, they affirmed the right of every child to educational justice and the duty of Government to protect the right of parents to choose the kind of education that will be given to their children.
Archbishop F. Rush
Archbishop G. Young
Archbishop J. Gleeson
Archbishop T. F. Little
Archbishop E. Clancy
Archbishop F. Carroll
Bishop D. Warren
Bishop P. Dougherty
For further information: Archbishop F. Carroll (062) 48 6411
1st September 1983

TALK.START.PARA: —That statement refers directly to the abandonment of the principle-that is, the abolition of the nexus, the abolition of the honesty principle. It also refers directly to the grave misgivings, fears and anxieties which those people have about the abolition of the basic grant, which is the next principle, what I call the taxpayers principle. The notion that all taxpayers ought to be able to expect that some contribution-I emphasise, only some contribution-be given towards the cost of their children's education has been abandoned by Senator Ryan and the ALP Government. In Senator Ryan's speech at Hurstville she said that the expectation that there is such a taxpayers principle is specious. She rejected the notion that there be a basic grant. That is of direct concern to the independent schools.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also the representation principle. The strategy of the opponents of independent schools have stated that they will have to purge the Schools Commission, get their people into it and get the greatest supporters of independent schools out. That is what has happened. There has been the sacking of Mr Greg Dunne and of Father John Williams, the appointment of Mr Van Davy and the reappointment of Mrs Joan Brown. They are public figures. Everybody knows the direct policies of the two who have left and the two who have come in. The latter two will be able directly to reinforce the ALP's policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to follow Senator Teague in this debate and to congratulate him on the force and on the power of what he had to say. I suggest to Senator Grimes, who was asking whether the money was going into poor Catholic parochial schools, that he might care to consider why the Catholic bishops of Australia will not have a bar of the policy which the Government has put up and why a pastoral letter was read from every Catholic pulpit in Victoria on 9 October condemning specifically two of the central proposals backing the argument put by Senator Teague and rejecting the implication in what Senator Grimes had to say. This is an important debate. I want to congratulate Senator Teague for his continuing and unremitting support of non-government schools. I say to the Government that we will return again and again to this theme. It is an important theme. It is a story of broken promises and betrayed trust by this new Government which will require to be set out in this Parliament and in every place possible across the community.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that my colleague Senator Harradine is present in the chamber. He will recall an evening which we spent in Albury some two or three weeks ago. He will recall the message that the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan), sent to that meeting. Senator Harradine might correct me if I get it wrong, but she said that she would not be turning up herself and would not be sending a representative to speak on behalf of the Government because the matter was too delicate. Honourable senators should have heard the parents at that meeting, 950 of them, laughing to think that a politician holding an important portfolio in government, changing policies and disadvantaging people, not only would not turn up herself but also would not send a representative because the matter was too delicate. It was too delicate because so far the Minister has been disinclined to face the parents out in the community. I acknowledge that the Government of New South Wales sent one of its politicians, Mr McGowan, to the meeting. Mr McGowan did not have an easy time at that meeting, but he conducted himself with dignity and courage. I think that he gained from that audience.

In this Budget debate I want to speak about jobs. I remind the Senate that just over six months ago this Government was elected on a promise-yet another promise that is unlikely to be kept-that it would provide half a million new jobs for Australians in three years. Before the election the Australian Labor Party said that the provision of these jobs was Australia's overwhelming need. In February, during the campaign for the general election, the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said:
There are tremendous issues involved in this historic election of the fifth of March-first and foremost, the right of all Australians to a job.

That was the rhetoric which the present Prime Minister took to the election when he was seeking the votes of Australians. We know that Australians place unemployment at the top of their concerns and of the issues which are worrying them. We know that Australians are concerned about jobs. They were interested in this promise of the then Leader of the Opposition and the now Prime Minister. In March this year the people elected this Government, partly on a policy of full employment, in accord with the promise which the ALP gave during the election and in keeping with the assurances it gave.

Let us examine for a few moments what has been the Labor Government's delivery on this promise since March. What has this Government done to redeem that promise, or is this just another one of the many broken promises which are characterising this Government at this early stage? Let me say something about these promises. Many of these promises are not expensive ones to implement. I was interested in the debate yesterday on Labor's broken education promises. We were told that some of them could not be redeemed because of the costs involved. Some of the promises which Labor has failed to keep do not involve money. They involve redeeming promises about due processes, about the way in which things are done and about procedures. On those promises the Government really does stand condemned. I go back to the education area, where there was a promise not to do certain things to harm the non-government schools until certain consultations had taken place. That promise, of course, was ignored.

Let me return to jobs. What has the Government done since March to redeem the promise and to fulfil the expectations which it raised among the community, particularly in the minds of those unemployed people who want to work? Its first opportunity came at the much heralded National Economic Summit Conference. At that Summit Mr Hawke repeated his election pledge. So not only was it on record during the election campaign but it was also repeated at the Economic Summit, not only by Mr Hawke but also by the President of the Australian Labor Party, the Premier of New South Wales, who at the Summit said that the issues were ' jobs, jobs, jobs'.

What happened at that Summit? The Summit was presented with three scenarios. Only one of those scenarios was likely to provide the conditions for improved employment. Only one of those scenarios went anywhere towards making hard decisions in terms of wage levels, inflation and spending. Only one of those scenarios offered any kind of hope for jobs. That was the scenario which the Government did not take. One of the scenarios, the soft option, the trade-off between the Government and the employed, the scenario which offered no hope to the unemployed, was the one the Government took. It took scenario A, the soft option. It was interesting at that Economic Summit to hear the input from some of the leaders from outside government and of Sir Keith Campbell, who died tragically just a week afterwards. People said they believed there should have been a fourth scenario, one that really did provide some hope for the return of jobs and employment. But no, the Government went for a scenario and for a policy which placed a deal with the unions before a solution for the unemployed. The scenario has ensured that 100,000 fewer Australians will be able to find jobs than would have been the case even under the inadequate but tougher scenario C that was presented to that Summit Conference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or the previous Liberal Government.

—I am interested in the honourable senator's interjections. I say to her that, from her position in a comfortable and secure two-income family, why does she not show a bit more concern about the failure of her Government to help those families that have not even got one income? Her family receives a professorial salary and a senatorial salary which make for very soft, convenient living. The Prime Minister promised 500,000 more jobs. That was the promise of the Labor Government. But, from the Government's own documents-they have come out document by document-under its economic strategies we will see dole queues 26 per cent longer this year. If honourable senators look at the Budget Papers and Estimates and see the estimated figure for the number of people who will receive unemployment benefit and the projections from the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the dole queues will be 26 per cent longer this year. That would not have been so had the Government, at the Economic Summit, had the guts to take the decisions which should have been taken . The dole queues could have been shorter and employment figures could have gone up.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that, in the last week or so, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, has indicated in the Press that a very large real rate of growth will be needed in Australia for a considerable number of years if we are to have any chance of wiping out the lost aspirations of a generation who want jobs. The Prime Minister promised 500,000 more jobs. In the first six months since the election, he has not provided 500,000 more jobs; 68, 300 jobs have been lost. We have seen a drop in the participation rate of people in employment in this country. Far from providing jobs, except perhaps, a job for Senator Crowley, the Prime Minister and Senator Crowley have presided over the loss of 68,000 more jobs. In seasonally adjusted terms over that time exactly 100 jobs have been created in Australia. How does the Prime Minister square the actual loss of 68,000 jobs with the promises he made? How does he square this with the kinds of submissions that the Government made to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission during the recent national wage case? The Government's approach to that case was an accommodation with the employed. It was an accommodation with the haves and a complete ignoring of the promises it made to those in need for whom the creation of the right climate is the only road to jobs.

We know that the Government's strategy is based upon the wages accord. Even if all the pieces of that hold together, the Budget which has been brought down holds out no hope for the unemployed. The Budget Papers admit, as Mr Willis has admitted, that unemployment under the Hawke Government will rise throughout 1983 -84 and will continue to rise in 1984-85. This Budget is a political document. It aims to appease the employed. It does not aim to help the unemployed. I have said that there has been a loss of 68,000 jobs since March. The figures show that the position is getting worse. During August, there was a loss of 52,000 jobs. If this job loss rate continues, not only will it make a mockery of any promises which this Government made before it came to office and a mockery of what it promised to do for the Australian public, but also it will suggest it will lead to such a significant worsening of the situation that those Australians who care for their own jobs and those Australian parents who are worried about the prospects of their children will need to look again at where this Government is leading Australia.

The August figures show that the participation rate in the work force, now down to 59.8 per cent, is the lowest participation rate since official figures were first collected more than 20 years ago. It compares with a participation rate of more than 61 per cent left to this Government by the Fraser Liberal-National Party Government when it lost office in March. If the rate of loss continues-the participation rate is down 2 per cent in six months-God knows how much further it will go down in the next six months, in the six months after that or in the year after that. Are we to have a country in which, under the Labor Party policy and Labor mismanagement, the participation rate will continue to drop?

What does the Government think about all this? Recently, I think on 28 September, the Prime Minister delivered the John Curtin Memorial Lecture. I ask honourable senators to remember that he had promised to create 500,000 more jobs and to remember that he had gone to the people on a policy of full employment. He had said over and over again that jobs were the issue. He delivered the John Curtin lecture on 28 September just six months after he had promised a return to full employment. He said:
Those days are over and must now be understood to be over--
He continued:

However unpalatable it may be, we cannot reasonably expect in the foreseeable future, to return to the experience of the post-war generation where the conventional economy provided full employment, in the historical sense, for everybody who sought work. We cannot reduce the unpalatability of this fact by ignoring it or refusing to face up to it.

It might have been more decent for the Australian people, if those were the views of Mr Hawke, for him to have expressed them in February when people were trying to put together, in their own minds, a balance of views as to how they might vote at the election. But no, during February when it was convenient for an election he said there would be jobs, jobs, jobs and he promised full employment. In September when it was not convenient he said: 'You cannot all expect jobs and you might as well face the fact'. Just over six months ago this Prime Minister told us that we must accept the new inevitability of a reduced level of employment. Just 12 months ago this Prime Minister told us that it was everyone's right to have a job. This kind of convenience and this kind of sudden conversion after the election has not left a lot of people feeling very good about the Labor Party.

The Prime Minister has spoken about ways of reducing demands for jobs. He has tried methods of reducing the size of the labour force. One of the strategies which the Labor Party is examining for reducing the size of the labour force is, of course, increasing participation in education. About this time last year, as Minister for Education, I initiated a publicity campaign to try to encourage people to remain in schools. In fact, that campaign was remarkably successful because, in February this year, when we were still in government, enrolments in years 11 and 12 went up across Australia by, I think, something like 10 per cent or 11 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good.

—That was good. But I want to put before the Senate the argument that participation is not a strategy in itself. Participation is flawed if it is regarded as some kind of answer to unemployment. Before I do that, let me remind the Senate once again of the difference between the rhetoric and the reality of this Government. The Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, soon after her appointment issued a Press release on 16 March. In that Press release, she reiterated some of the promises and some of the goals which she intended to follow as Minister for Education. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's main concern in the area of student assistance is to improve the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme, (TEAS).
In particular, a start would be made on reviewing and upgrading the provisions of TEAS within the context of the 1983-84 Budget.

Now that was the post-election promise of the Minister for Education, and that is a promise which has been broken. It is one of the numerous promises to tertiary students which have been broken and which have not been redeemed. There were a number of specific promises in relation to TEAS-that it would be upgraded progressively, that it would be brought to the level of the unemployment benefit and that the means test would be widened-and all of those promises, had they been redeemed, would have served to have made participation easier for some people in higher education. I include among the promises-I have just read to honourable senators one that was made by the Minister post-election, after her appointment-a specific promise to take action within the context of the 1983-84 Budget. I ask the Government in this Budget debate: 'Where is the provision to redeem that promise?' The answer is: It is not there. The Government has failed absolutely to redeem another specific promise to another group who looks to it for support.

Mr Acting Deputy President, we have low participation in Australia, both in the higher levels of secondary school and in tertiary education-post-school education. It is hard to know exactly what our participation level is and it is quite hard to compare it with the position in other countries. The reason is that everyone seems to measure it in a different way. How do we regard an apprentice who has work release and attends a technical college part time? Is that person in the work force or in education? Some countries would define that person as being in education; some would not. It is quite difficult to make international comparisons. But let us accept that our participation rate is low and let us acknowledge some of the reasons for that low participation rate.

The Sackville Commission of Inquiry into Poverty during the 1970s recorded from students a sense of alienation and hostility towards the education system because what was being offered to and what was being required of students was seen by them as neither appropriate nor rewarding. The Beswick report, entitled 'Studies of Tertiary Student Finances', which was tabled recently and with which I was associated as Minister, identified the sense of alienation and rejection of some students as one of the factors leading to a lower than desirable level of participation. There is widespread anecdotal evidence and there is evidence from many other reports that what is being offered in education in Australia is itself not good enough to attract or to hold all the students that we would like to see receiving either advanced high school training or post-school educational opportunity.

It follows from this that participation in education is not an adequate goal in itself; it is not a complete goal. Participation will only become appropriate or coherent if what is being offered within the educational institutions is seen by the students as being valuable and appropriate and if it is valued by them. Of course for many young Australians at the moment that is the case. Many young Australians participate in education because it is seen to be valuable. But many of those who drop out do so for very good reasons-because the system offers them nothing. There is no point, as part of an unemployment strategy, to direct young 16-year-olds and 17-year-olds back into a school system which offers them nothing of personal value, which does nothing to meet their immediate needs and which does not help to offer to them some future benefit which they would find as important. The difficulty-and this is not a political point I am making at this stage; it has to do with the quality of education-is that the Commonwealth may have a limited capacity to influence what is being offered within State education systems, within autonomous universities or within autonomous colleges of advanced education--

TALK.START.PARA: —It should use what capacity it has.

—Senator, I think it might be more appropriate to say that we should be seeking by means of dialogue and agreement to bring the education system itself to see the problem not just in terms of how to bring students back in but how those who are offering education themselves will alter what they do and what they think and how they approach teaching to give to young people a better opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: This Budget has failed to address the issues of unemployment in Australia. This Budget is presented at a time when unemployment is worsening. This Budget is brought down at a time when participation in the work force is less than it has been for two decades. It is brought down and contains none of the measures required to redeem specific promises for young Australians who might be in education and it does so against a background of qualitative deficiencies in education across Australia. I support the views that have been expressed by my leaders in this place and in other places about what this Budget fails to do for Australia. We look to the Government to do more to redeem its own promises in the areas of jobs for Australians and to do more to help students in Australia get from the Government what they were promised so clearly before the election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to spend the time available to me today during the second reading debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and the cognate Bill speaking about the relationship between this Budget, inflation and interest rates and relate that to what is happening or not happening in the United States of America and then go on to another matter. First of all let me deal a little with the United States recovery, of which we have all no doubt heard. We have heard that things in the United States are going well, that inflation is down and interest rates are down; and because interest rates are down investment enthusiasm and confidence are up. The economy is showing a good expansion. In fact it is showing a very rapid expansion indeed. Yet people to whom I have spoken about the United States recovery say that the uplift over there is due to the low interest rates. They have also pointed out to me that those interest rates have been edging up again lately and some of the people see problems ahead. Most of them say that the United States dollar is over valued at the moment. They point out that when the huge United States deficit is taken into account, interest rates must rise again. They must rise eventually when the Government decides to raise the money to cover that deficit. Many people in the United States feel that once interest rates rise, the present economic recovery will run into trouble. I have read that there is some expectation that the growth in the United States in the first quarter next year could in fact be negative. All of this has come about because Americans have been living at a standard that they cannot afford. There is no easy way out of the mess that has arisen, largely because of the failure of the United States political process to come to grips with the issue of exploding and uncontrolled government spending which has created something like 60 million dependent Americans in that country.

SPEECH.PARA: We, like the United States, have a very large, in fact a huge, deficit. I believe that this Budget has set Australia on the wrong course because it relies on big government spending financed by huge borrowings to attempt to get the economy going. At the end of 1982 we owed more money per head to the international banking community than many other countries. I should like to read some of these figures to the Senate. Poland per head owed $US790; Mexico, $US880 ; Brazil, $US950; Chile, $US1,010; Argentina, $US1,820. Australia, leading the list, owed $US1,880 per head. That was before the effect of this Budget was taken into account. That means that we in Australia owe more than many of these countries that we all hear about as being in a situation that is fraught with danger. I seek leave to have that table incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are a country that is deeply in debt. The situation will probably get worse next year. One honourable senator said that we had left the Labor Government with a huge deficit. I think if we sit down and work out a few projections of where the country is going, we will see that next year's deficit will be worse than this year's. When this Government came to office, it was said that we had saddled it with a projected deficit of almost $10 billion; so any reduction from that amount was made to look like a positive advance. The deficit , which has to be paid back one day, is almost 5 per cent of the gross domestic product. It is the largest since 1975. The borrowings of the public sector will be between 8 per cent and 9 per cent. That is the largest for a quarter of a century. We may soon have the public sector and the private sector competing for available funds. Interest rates will rise and I believe that inflation will rise . We are already ahead of many of our trading partners.

SPEECH.PARA: In one area perhaps the Government has done the right thing. It has left the income tax rates down and it has also left investment allowance and company tax as they were. I think that will help the private sector somewhat. The ominous thing is that the delicate balance of this Budget is dependent upon the agreement with the unions. This is already showing signs of crumbling. Recently we have seen a soft government attitude to some settlements outside indexation principles. The unions in the building, oil, petro-chemical and food processing industries have sought and been granted substantial wage rises, sometimes called special allowances. These may have set a precedent that will lead to a general wage push outside the wage indexation guidelines. Some people also doubt that the unions will be prepared to accept indexation that is based on consumer price index movements because CPI figures significantly understate the actual inflation rate. So we have the risk of another wage explosion which means more inflation, and we have the distinct chance of interest rates increasing two or three per cent in the coming year. If that happens, we have no chance of sustaining any recovery in this country. I suggest to people who may read this speech that they look at the previous speech in which Senator Peter Baume outlined just how bad the job situation is in this country. I believe that our long term growth prospects are in real danger. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a small part of what was said in the Westpac Review No. 12.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Longer-term consequences

By deliberately setting out to force-feed economic growth in the year ahead, the Government may well have truncated Australia's longer-term growth prospects. If an expansionary budget results in the retention of relatively high interest rates compared with those in capital markets abroad, it will tend to increase capital inflow. As a result, the $A exchange rate is likely to appreciate to an extent unwarranted by Australia's international trade performance.

The net effect on the pace of private sector recovery beyond the end of the financial year is likely to be twofold. Even if the government's hopes are realised and the prices and incomes accord effectively negates wage inflation, the real interest rates implied by the fiscal-monetary policy mix may serve to stall the recovery. In any event, high real interest rates are likely to prevent the broadening of the recovery process by dampening business investment plans.

At the same time, the appreciation of the $A will bite into the competitiveness of exporters and import-competing industries and add to the damaging effects of an inflation rate which will still be relatively high in international terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Budget Statement No. 2, the Treasury says this:

SPEECH.PARA: A wages outcome higher than currently assumed would have an especially damaging impact on business confidence and private sector spending propensities. The renewal of pressures on corporate profitability, together with a consequent slackening in private demand, would be likely to manifest itself in a further round of labour shedding and another sharp ratcheting up in the rate of employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unemployment.
—It says 'employment' in this statement, but I think it must really mean unemployment. The document continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Those risks are sufficiently grave in the economic context presently foreseen. They would be magnified, however, should the outlook and demand prove even stronger than presently expected while public sector demands were still growing strongly. For example, an even stronger upturn in the world economy than now foreseen could aggravate the risks within Australia of a renewed wage surge, higher inflation and higher interest rates. Unless these possible consequences were contained, the potential advantages to Australia of the world upturn could then be lost and the prospects of sustained recovery further imperilled.

I am worried about the future of this country. We are spending too much. We are becoming borrowers in the league of some of the banana republics, as I mentioned , and as is shown from the table which I incorporated in Hansard. Interest rates will rise. Investment, I believe, will fall. Unemployment will therefore rise. We could also have increased inflation which would put us at a further disadvantage with our trading partners. As the year goes on, I believe that more and more people will realise that this Budget has failed Australia. It is my belief that while we borrow at the rate that we are borrowing at and while we live on credit the way we are, we are heading this country towards financial disaster and increased unemployment that will eventually destroy this Government . I believe that the economy of this country will destroy this Government, no matter how many sporting functions the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, manages to attend. Let me say that I am not one who says that he should not attend them. I think it is very good that he does.

Once again I want to say something about uranium mining and atomic power. At the outset, let me say that I believe that no one in this world would want to see any of the thousands of present day atomic weapons used. I am a member of the parliamentary disarmament group concerned with the gradual and total removal of all atomic weapons and other weapons. We have all heard of yellowcake. That is somewhat less than one part in 100 of uranium 235. When people talk of uranium enrichment, they do not mean enriching the uranium to weapons grade. What is meant is enriching the yellowcake to about five or six times what it is when it is shipped from the mines. For some reason, lay people are scared of the process of enrichment. I do not think many people in this chamber understand very much about it. It is a relatively simple chemical and physical process. the chemistry is quite straightforward, but the separation of the U235 from the more predominant uranium does take a little physical doing and usually involves banks of centrifuges. It is something which I believe this country should be looking at. On 20 September, in answer to a question by Senator Sir John Carrick, Senator Walsh, when talking about a cutting back of uranium enrichment at the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, said:

That judgment was both responsible and compatible with the policy of the Australian Labor Party. As a result of that, the expansion to a full cascade of the uranium enrichment program which had previously been anticipated was not proceeded with. Some work on enrichment is still proceeding this year. What will happen next year is a matter to be determined at a later date.

I hope that at that date some thought will be given to continuing the enrichment program. I want to make my position quite clear with regard to the use of uranium for peaceful purposes. I believe we should be mining uranium. I believe that we should continue looking at the enrichment process. We should be supplying if not enriched uranium certainly yellowcake to the large number of countries which are using uranium at this time to produce power. I believe that 25 countries are getting their power from atomic stations. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a list of those countries. The list also includes some countries which are constructing power stations.

SPEECH.PARA: As an engineer, I feel that I have a responsibility to try to stop what I call mindless opposition to the peaceful use of uranium. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak for a few moments on the subject of disarmament and this Government's response to that problem. Given the fact that we are on the eve of the United Nations Disarmament Week and the Senate will not be sitting next week, I thought the opportunity ought to be taken now to say a few words about a matter which really touches the aspirations of, I think, all people throughout the world in whatever society or culture they live. One recalls the words of Isaiah in the great Jewish tradition, of course, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . they shall beat their swords into plowshares, and their spears into pruninghooks: nation shall not lift up sword against nation, neither shall they learn war any more.

Senator Robertson thinks I am about to break into a sermon; I am not. What I want to state is that that particular text at least does give us an ethical imperative, an aspiration which I think all human beings can share. The question is: How does the present Labor Government shape up in addressing this particular problem? Already it has taken certain significant steps in relation to a problem which is revealed in the annual publication of World Military and Social Expenditures 1982 compiled by Ruth Leger Sivard. One finds that military expansion in 1982 continued its upward thrust. All the basic indicators show that militarism and armaments, the arsenals of war, are expanding at a terrific rate. Four measurable features of the arms race of the 1980s are astronomical costs, now reaching over $600 billion a year or well over $100m a minute; 25 million people serving in the regular armed forces, backed three to one by reserves, paramilitary forces, and the civilians needed to produce weapons and services essential for their operation; an international trade in conventional arms, now over $35 billion a year, proliferating sophisticated weapons of war into the most remote and least developed areas of the world; and an uncontrolled buildup of nuclear weapons at present equal to an explosive force of 3.5 tonnes of TNT for every person on earth. All those indicators point to what we know, namely, that the growing militarisation and increase in the arsenals of war are continuing to pose a grave threat to mankind's very future. Human history as we know it could be brought to an end.

In that situation, it is pleasing to see that this Government has taken a major step in the appointment for the first time of an Australian Ambassador for Disarmament. Indeed, the appointment of Mr Richard Butler gives Australian diplomatic presence around the world a very high status, a very clear focus. He has been given instructions to adopt an aggressive profile in negotiations. Of course, he is also to return to Australia frequently in order to confer with and no doubt be strengthened by the very wide movement in relation to peace matters which is a feature of life in Australia at the moment-and a growing feature at that. I am not suggesting that this Government is merely satisfying some strident constituency out on the streets, but it is true that this Government, as opposed to the previous Government, is not afraid of that constituency. Indeed, I recall that in a report given after the last United Nations Special Session on Disarmament Mr Street said that the mass movement could distract us from the real issues of disarmament. However, we believe that that mass movement is essential if governments are to respond truly to that deep aspiration of humanity of which I spoke in my opening remarks.

In addition to the appointment of the Ambassador, there has been an allocation of funds in this Budget for the creation of a peace and development research institute at the rate of some $100,000 a year initially. That sum is really quite small in budgetary terms. It is hardly generous but at least it enables us to get that particular project off the ground. I believe that negotiations are well advanced with the Australian National University. Perhaps Senator Georges, who is well known for his great involvement in these matters over the years when it was highly unpopular to be so involved and is, I believe, on the ANU Council, could signal some assent to the fact that negotiations are progressing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—Indeed, they appear to be progressing. It would be pleasing to see such a peace and development research institute established within a university campus to give it the status that is appropriate because it is essential that the research that it undertakes be such that it can command confidence. Part of that commanding of confidence will come from the appointment of a director and staff of international, and certainly high, calibre, so that we can attract researchers and gain credibility for the institute. As I say, the first steps are being taken. There is a need for such an institute. It is no error of judgment that the two questions of peace and development are linked in the very title of the body to be established. Those negotiations are under way as a second instance of the Government's response by way of new initiatives to the whole question of disarmament.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, there has been an allocation of further funds to certain United Nations agencies promoting these sorts of issues and a strengthening of the section within the Department of Foreign Affairs. So with appointments and new initiatives and a strengthening of the professional back-up available to the Minister and, therefore, to the Ministry and the Government as a whole, there will be such an increase in awareness of these issues within the Government, and then a corresponding and supplementing of that awareness within the community, that I believe we can make important advances. The most important of those advances required is the reaffirmation by the international community in 1985 of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. In fact, those negotiations and consultations leading to that reaffirmation and review in 1985 are extremely crucial.

It is not often realised what a tenuous hold that treaty has on the nation states of the world. I refer not only to the super-powers, which are making it more difficult to obtain adherence to the treaty by other countries by their failure to adhere to Article 6, which requires a reduction in their own arsenals of nuclear weapons as a sign of their good faith and, therefore, to encourage those other nations which at present do not adhere not to engage in proliferation of nuclear weapons. Countries such as Brazil, Argentina, South Africa, Israel and Syria have access, perhaps, to the technology, and perhaps they already have the technology available to them to avoid safeguards and create a situation in which these weapons can be produced. They are all in unstable situations which could trigger a conflagration not only between neighbours but throughout the world. It is certainly in our interests that the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty should gain more adherents from among such countries and, of course, that the super-powers take their obligations under the treaty seriously.

The Labor Government has very good credentials in this area. I think that the treaty itself was signed early, but it was not ratified until the Whitlam Government came to power; indeed, it was within a few months of that Government coming to power. With those credentials, Mr Richard Butler, on behalf of the Government, is well placed to undertake the necessary negotiations and representations of Australia's point of view.

The comprehensive test ban treaty remains Australia's real goal and an interesting initiative because, together with New Zealand, we are the co- sponsors within the United Nations forums of the comprehensive test ban treaty, which applies, of course, not only to the banning of tests relating to nuclear weapons but also to any explosion involving nuclear devices. It is thought, of course, that the testing of explosive devices is itself, even if not directly linked to a nuclear weapons explosion, a further perfecting of the technology which allows those weapons to be developed. We have sometimes enjoyed the support of some of the super-powers-the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics at times; I do not think that the United States of America has been very supportive -but the fact is that we press on with that initiative.

In our own region we have been active. Honourable senators and the general public are well aware of the fact that earlier this year, as a clear mark not of our distaste-that would be too weak-but of our abhorrence of the French practice of continuing to test nuclear weapons in the Pacific, we suspended uranium shipments to France. Indeed, that was done by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), face to face in conversation with his fellow member of the Socialist International, President Mitterrand. That shows the strength of the Australian Government's position in relation to our condemnation of that continual testing by the French in the Pacific.

We have tried also, very recently, in the South Pacific Forum to get the agreement of all Forum countries in the South Pacific to acknowledge and endorse the concept of a nuclear free zone in the Pacific. Indeed, in the proceedings of that South Pacific Forum, held only five or six weeks ago in Canberra, it is stated that:
It is recalled that in the communiques issued following Meetings over several years, they-
the members-

had taken a strong stand in opposition to nuclear testing and proposals for storage and dumping of nuclear waste material in the Pacific. Despite these unanimous expressions of view of independent and self-governing South Pacific countries, nuclear practices abhorrent to Forum countries continued.
They commended the Australian initiative-

in receiving consideration of the concept of a nuclear free zone among the Forum members. They expressed appreciation of the Australian working document which had provided the basis for their discussions and which made a valuable contribution to establishing the objectives which a zone concept would seek to achieve.
In order to save time, Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to incorporate the resolutions of the fourteenth South Pacific Forum in Hansard, insofar as they are relevant.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Regional Nuclear Matters

The Forum considered the questions of continued nuclear testing in the South Pacific, the invitation of the French Government to Forum countries for scientists to visit and assess the situation at the nuclear test site at Mururoa , nuclear waste disposal and dumping, the South Pacific Regional Environment Programme, and the Australian proposal for a Declaration of a South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone. The Forum recognised that the French Government's invitation had been made on a bilateral basis and that it was a matter for Governments to respond as they wished. The Forum adopted the following statement of its position on nuclear matters.

The Fourteenth South Pacific Forum: Recalled that in the communiques issued following Meetings over several years, they had taken a strong stand in opposition to nuclear testing and proposals for storage and dumping of nuclear waste material in the Pacific. Despite these unanimous expressions of view of independent and self-governing South Pacific countries, nuclear practices abhorrent to Forum countries continued;

Reiterated they would continue to make the strongest protests and condemnations so long as nuclear testing by France or any other country continued in the South Pacific region. They also reaffirmed their opposition to proposals for the dumping and storage of nuclear waste in the Pacific area.

Commended the Australian initiative in reviving consideration of the concept of a nuclear free zone among the Forum members. They expressed appreciation of the Australian working document which had provided the basis for their discussions and which made a valuable contribution to establishing the objectives which a zone concept would seek to achieve.

Expressed the need for more time to consider the implications of the proposal and to carry out consultations on it. The Foreign Minister of Australia undertook to continue consultations on a bilateral basis to encourage further development of the zone concept both within the framework of the Forum and more widely. He undertook to provide the Forum countries with background on nuclear free zone concepts in other parts of the world.

Noted that there had been a wide agreement on the general principles of the concept as submitted by Australia. It affirmed that in further addressing the zone proposal it would be important to uphold the principles of freedom of navigation and overflight as provided in international law and in the Treaty obligations of some Forum members. It recognised the sovereign right of Governments to make their own decisions on their alliance and defence requirements including access to their ports and airfields by the vessels and aircraft of other countries.

Expressed their commitment to advancing the cause of general disarmament; supporting the negotiations and conclusion of an effective Treaty which would outlaw all forms of nuclear testing by all States in all environments; and preventing the spread of nuclear weapons and nuclear explosive devices particularly through support for the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Wapons.
Decided to place the question on the Agenda of its 1984 Session to provide further opportunity for consideration and examination of the concept of a nuclear free zone.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. What I am trying to point out is that not only have we taken initiatives proper to us as a government and as a nation; we have tried to incorporate in a wider movement the sentiments that have been expressed by individual South Pacific nations. They are now reaching a stage at which I believe at the next South Pacific Forum we may hope to see a declaration by those countries of their adherence to the concept of a nuclear free zone. It is not such a frightening or unusual prospect, although sometimes it is portrayed as absurd and unattainable. Already in relation to the Antarctic there is such an understanding amongst nations. If we can carry that sort of approach through to our own area of the South Pacific, we shall be doing a great service.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the Indian Ocean zone of peace proposal, we have-as was not the case with the previous Australian Government-indicated our support for the deliberations that will need to proceed in order to get that concept back into the international arena of debate.

I could mention one or two other matters but I think that I have stated enough, in the short time allowed in this contribution to the Senate today, to indicate that this Government has taken steps to achieve what we would all wish to see achieved-namely, a reduction in the threat which hovers over the whole of mankind, a threat which could bring human history to an end. The whole question of armaments and the militarisation of the world is being addressed by this Government. I believe that I have pointed out that in quite a robust manner we have taken some new initiatives, within an overall strengthening of the resources of government, devoted to these matters. Therefore, I commend the Government's program and, in particular, the Foreign Minister, Mr Bill Hayden, for his approach to these matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge that we are perhaps breaking a precedent of not debating the outcomes of a conference of the Inter- Parliamentary Union until the official reports are received from the Secretariat , which involves a time lag of six to nine months. However, two of us today will be debating some of the events surrounding this year's IPU Conference. Significant events occurred at this year's seventieth IPU Conference in Seoul, Korea. The condolence motions from this Senate and the House of Representatives following the brutal massacre in Rangoon involving 17 senior Koreans, were passed on to the Government and peoples of Korea by the Australian Delegation, and because of the close bonds of friendship, fostered in war and subsequently in trade relations, the sincerity of those expressions of sympathy was appreciably received.

SPEECH.PARA: Further tokens of the closeness of our two countries was demonstrated several days earlier when the leader of the delegation, Ralph Jacobi, laid a wreath at the Kapyong Memorial and 8 kilometres to the north I placed one at the 3rd Royal Australian Regiment Memorial where Australian bravery touched the hearts of the Korean people. Both these two solemn events were attended by the whole of the Australian delegation who were escorted in a dignified manner through a guard of honour of Korean school children in national dress and Korean soldiers to appropriate music played by the local school bank.

Korea, rapidly emerging from a developing to a developed nation, demonstrated to the delegates a most generous hospitality. It delivered a highly sophisticated organisation structure supporting the conference, and continuously demonstrated its rich cultural heritage. The consensus among delegates was that this seventieth Conference of the IPU was one of the best organised and, until the brutal massacre at the Rangoon Martyr's Mausoleum, the most congenial of conferences. Despite that shocking and momentous event, our Korean hosts ensured that the program was continued with dignity and a calmness of the highest order.

Korea is one of the economic miracles of the modern world. Although the country has a history of 5,000 years, during the last 1,000 it has endured over 900 years of aggression and not on one occasion did it wage war against its neighbours-it was always the victim. In recent time it suffered 36 years of oppression under Japanese colonial rule. It was almost overrun by North Korean forces but for about a 10 per cent area around the Port of Pusan from which the United Nations forces began the push that succeeded in driving the North Korean aggressors across the thirty-eighth parallel, a very artificial demarkation line that was devised by the great powers after the Second World War which divided North and South Korea. Similar divisions have caused traumatic problems in other countries-for example, East and West Germany, Berlin, and North and South Vietnam.

Military and political confrontation between North and South continues to this day with North Korean forces having a superiority of equipment in the ratio of 2 :1. The International Institute of Strategy in London indicates the North Koreans as having 2,500 tanks, 740 fighter aircraft and 450 naval ships-far more than it needs to defend itself. However, with a highly disciplined army supported by 40,000 United States troops, the boundaries of the Republic of Korea are secure. However, the government is very conscious of undermining elements within society, initiated often from the Democratic Peoples Republic of Korea, commonly known as North Korea. This caution is understandable since the capital, Seoul, is only 45 kilometres from one of North Korea's tunnels which, when discovered, was large enough for tanks and other heavy equipment to drive through.

The border situation is still precarious as 13 of the Australian party discovered when visiting the armistice centre on the border at Pan Won-Jong the day after the assassination attempt on the President. With the internal feud in North Korea triggered off by Kim Il-sung's scheme to put his son Jong-il in his place as hereditary heir in a communist hierarchy, and with a worsening economic plight imposed on the populace, Pyongyang could well try and divert the domestic unrest by resorting to their time-old tactic of embarking on a military adventure. We live here in Australia enjoying a security unknown to most of the countries of Asia whose borders are under pressures. We often do not appreciate the attitudes of others who live in countries whose security is continuously under threat. The 1950 Korean war rendered 10 million people separated from their families and left a largely agarian supported population hungry. Due to its determination Korea is now a successful industrial power presenting both challenges and opportunities for Australian business.

South Korea had to fight hard to prove that it could host an IPU conference. It suffered abuse at Rome and Helsinki when principally North Korea and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics delegates attempted to remove the venue from Seoul to an alternative site. So desperate was this attempt that North Korea offered financial inducements for delegates to vote against the motion and a lesser payment for an abstention. Despite these pressures a big majority of nations remained firm and it could be said that it was a diplomatic success for the Republic of Korea. Since that time South Korea has suffered two major tragedies, the participants of which came from Russia and North Korea. The first was the destruction of a civilian 747 airliner with the loss of 269 lives, including five Australians. This barbaric action left a cloud of suffering and tension hovering over the whole of the Korean Peninsula.

The second was the brutal massacre at the Martyrs' Mausoleum in Rangoon involving 17 high ranking Koreans, including four Ministers. I am proud to say that the Australian delegation, led by the determined and indomitable no- nonsense approach of the honourable member for Hawker, Ralph Jacobi, was instrumental in strengthening a rather weak Swiss resolution against the first atrocity. I seek leave to incorporate the resolution in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Deeply deploring the brutal destruction of a Korean Airlines civilian aircraft on Sept. 1983 by a Soviet fighter plane, resulting in the death of 269 innocent men, women and children from 15 countries on board,
Noting that this tragic incident calls into question the safety of civil aviation and constitutes a grave violation of international conventions and customs, as well as of humanitarian principles.
Expressing its indignation at the flagrant disregard for human life shown by those Soviet authorities responsible for this tragedy,
Emphasising that such action in these difficult and dangerous times is not the way to contribute to the cause of international peace and co-operation,

While recognising the importance of the principles of territorial integrity, emphasising that only internationally agreed procedures should be used in response to intrusion into the airspace of a State,
Desirous of being fully acquainted with the facts of the matter,
Stressing the necessity for a comprehensive and adequate explanation based on an independent and international inquiry into the facts related to the incident,
Stressing the importance of adhering to international civil aviation laws and procedures purposefully designed to secure the safety of international air traffic,
Noting that the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has initiated timely action on the incident with a view to preventing any recurrence of similar tragedies,
1. Expresses its profound sympathy to the families of all the victims of the 15 nations involved, to the National Assembly, the Inter-Parliamentary Group and the people of the Republic of Korea;

2. Calls on all governments and the ICAO to ensure greater safety for civil air traffic, such as through an international communication and navigational system for civilian aircraft, including those which may stray accidentally off course into closed airspace of high political and military sensitivity;

3. Appeals to the Governments represented in the ICAO to support the proposed amendments to the Chicago Convention of 1944 on air transport in order to avoid the repetition of such a tragedy; these amendments relate to the following points:
(a) An undertaking to refrain from the use of force against civil aircraft;
(b) An obligation to take measures ensuring better co-operation between civil and military aircraft;
4. Also appeals to all Governments to give an assurance that the internationally recognised codes of behaviour relating to civilian aircraft will be observed in the future;

5. Demands a full and fair international inquiry into the incident, such as that of the ICAO, and expects the full co-operation of all parties concerned including the Soviet Union with all aspects of such inquiries, including the recovery and disclosure of all material evidence;
6. Insists that full and just compensation be paid by the Soviet Union to the families of the victims according to the principles of the rule of law;

TALK.START.PARA: —There will be a long term implication to the tragedy extending far beyond the borders of Korea. For example, Japanese eyes have now been opened to the military realities of its Soviet neighbour. The plane incident is likely to strengthen the hand of Prime Minister Nakasone, who has strongly urged, and has taken some steps in this direction, that Japan should increase its capability to defend itself with its own forces and protect sea lanes for up to 1,600 kilometres offshore. Having previously described the shooting down of the Korean airliner, which crashed into the Sea of Japan not far from the northernmost main island of Hokkaido, as a 'barbaric act and an affront to humanity', Mr Nakasone told the Diet the Japan Socialist Party's platform of unarmed neutrality was unrealistic.

SPEECH.PARA: In closing, I wish to draw the attention of the Senate to words from a President of vision at the inaugural ceremony held at the Se Jong cultural centre where the Republic of Korea President Chun Doo Hwan expressed faith in parliamentary democracy that transcends differences in political and social systems and involves a resolve to deal with the problems of the modern international community through debate and dialogue. He went on to say that trade wars constitute another dangerous dimension of world conflict and that it is always possible for an economic war to lead to a hot war. He has a very realistic approach because he acknowledged that all peoples in the world are inseparable members of one global village. He also acknowledged that the world community has been made interdependent by revolutionary changes in transportation and communications technology, which has expanded the scope of international exchanges beyond anything imaginable in the past.

This far-sighted President said we are all in the same boat and that we share the same common destiny. He said that with instability and uncertainty mounting in the world, the danger of the kind of war that could obliterate the human race lurks everywhere. He pointed out that the global powers are not only in possession of nuclear weapons that can instantaneously destroy the world; they are accelerating the arms race. He went on to say that the mutual knowledge of the destructiveness of nuclear weapons makes it impossible for a nuclear war to break out. He also said that conventional wisdom says: 'That which is unthinkable to most people will not happen'. However, he said that the unthinkable is not impossible and that this is a warning to those with any easy going attitude about nuclear war, because such a lax and deceptive attitude could invite disaster. The President said that in the history of human conflict no country has ever developed and stockpiled a new weapon only to scrap it without ever using it. I believe that we should long remember those words.

In conclusion, the Seoul Conference of the IPU was well organised and gave new blood and new life to the Union, making it a global forum useful for discussing many international issues. I wish to thank my colleagues, particularly the leader, Ralph Jacobi, Senator Ron Elstob, and the members of the House of Representatives-Peter Coleman, Bruce Goodluck, Russell Gorman, Noel Hicks and Len Keogh. I wish also to thank support staff David Nimmo, Bert Nicholls, Douglas Blake and foreign affairs adviser, Michael Potts, for their contribution , co-operation and good fellowship. We look forward at a later date to resumption of the President's visit to South East Asia and Australia with his intended promise to promote peace and to orientate regional collaboration in a multi-polarised world community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to give my thanks to the South Korean Government for organising the very fine Seventieth Conference of the Inter-Parliamentary Union. It was undoubtedly one of the best organised conferences that I have been to or read about. It was of great credit to the South Korean Government, which went to a lot of trouble to welcome delegates from all countries. It is unfortunate that Russia and the Eastern bloc countries did not attend that Conference. The IPU enables politicians from all countries of the world to get together to try to resolve the many problems that beset the world. I believe it is an important forum. I would like Australia always to participate in these meetings. In the past, politicians from all sides have condemned the IPU on the grounds that it is not worth while. I do not take that view. I believe that Australia has a point of view to put and that it should be put internationally.

SPEECH.PARA: Having attended IPU conferences at Helsinki and Seoul, I believe that Australians are well respected throughout the international community. On all occasions, the word of the Australian delegation is taken. On many occasions, its advice on resolutions that have been passed has been fully agreed with. As Senator Watson has said, Australia played a great role in strengthening the contribution of the Conference on the destruction of the South Korean airliner that was shot down by the Russians. Not only did we insist that that action be condemned but we looked to the future to see that people travelling on civilian airlines would travel in safety. We asked that the international communications and navigational systems for civilian aircraft-including those aircraft which stray accidentally from their courses into closed air space of high political and military sensitivity-be guarded so that incidents such as the one in question which led to the death of nearly 300 people will never be seen again.

The Australian delegation was very forthright on many issues and played a prominent role in the IPU conference. As I said, it had the respect of people from across the world who attended the Conference. We all worked on different sections of the matters before the Conference. I worked on the committee dealing with education, science, culture and environment. I believe that the world must resolve the problems in these areas. We must solve the problems of war. We are currently spending $1,300m a minute on defence preparations. I do not believe we can continue to do that. That is why it is very important for all politicians to meet from time to time to try to reduce the amount of finance that we are spending on armaments. If some small portion of this huge sum of money that is spent on war and the preparation for war were spent on education and relieving the poverty of the world, I believe that the world could start to live in peace. I do not believe that the world can live in peace while there is poverty and ignorance. We must put a large portion of the finance spent on war and defence into other avenues. I believe that there is plenty in this world for all if it were better organised.

It is at conferences such as the IPU that ways for doing this can be found. It is important to have dialogues between politicians from every country in the world. As I said earlier, I was disappointed that the Russians and the countries of the Eastern bloc did not attend. Certainly the Russians would have been criticised for shooting down the South Korean airliner, but I believe that one must face up to one's actions. Any government that commits such an atrocity must face up to its responsibilities. Any person who attended the IPU had to come away from that Conference better informed and better able to discuss problems of international concern. I met Mr Lee, the Korean Defence Minister, some days before he left with the President of South Korea on the trip to Burma. I had long discussions with him. He and my wife had lunch together. We had our photos taken. Forty-eight hours after that, he was killed. That is the tragedy. It is a hopeless situation when politicians trying to resolve problems in the world must face the possibility of assassination. The attempted assassination of the President reminded everyone at that Conference that all of us could be vulnerable at some time or another.

I met many other people at the Conference. I met Mr Chi, who was scheduled to come to Australia. Naturally, he did not come. Mr Chi is a friend of Australia, as are many other politicians. I found that the Korean politicians were alarmed that very little contact had been made with the Australian Labor Party.
