We did not feel any concern about that in the Labor Party, but the South Korean politicians were concerned about it. They had paid attention mainly to the parties of the former Government before the last election and they had neglected the Australian Labor Party. I informed them that to the best of my knowledge there was no concern on our part. We wanted to have dialogues with every country on earth. We did not hold it against the South Koreans that they did not make contact with the Labor Party. They said that in future they most certainly would contact people of all political persuasions.

That is the type of attitude to be found and the sorts of problems that can be overcome at such conferences. With better understanding we can help each other. We can probably trade better with other countries and have friendlier relations with them. We can reduce tensions and consult each other about problems and hot spots that might arise, especially in our area. After talking with representatives of many of the smaller nations, which I will not name, I found that small nations, by talking to Australians of all political persuasions, accepted very well the Australian point of view. Smaller nations have a fear of super-powers. I found that the United States and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics are great dominant powers in the eyes of smaller nations. I think it is important for Australia to keep contributing to these conferences because Australia's point of view is taken seriously. I think that is important. We can help reduce world tension by talking to people.

Australia offers an alternative. It has always had the attitude of the desirability of giving the other bloke a fair go. I think that attitude flows from the delegates, of whatever political persuasion, who represent this country . All delegates who represented Australia did a very good job. We were as one people putting a point of view, trying to bring about better understanding. That was the important thing. I have always believed that Australia should project itself a lot further. I am a member of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, and in future I would like to see politicians at times go out and talk to people from other countries. As I said, I think we have a point of view to put, and we can help reduce world tension. I also believe that we can increase trade and thereby help ourselves. That should be a joint effort by people of all political persuasions, and would only improve the world situation.

I would also like to thank all of the staff who worked with the delegation. Mr Bert Nicholls, the Deputy-Clerk of the Senate, was secretary to the delegation and did a magnificant job. Without his help the work of the delegation would have been impossible. Mr Douglas Blake, from the House of Representatives, and Mr Potts and Mr David Nimmo all played a very important part. I must congratulate all of my parliamentary colleagues. I will not name them all; Senator Watson has already done that. They set a good example on behalf of the Australian Parliament. They served the Parliament well and served their country well, and that is how it should be with international delegations. As I say, I hope that the Australian Parliament always sends delegates to the IPU. At least we have access to other politicians and we can put points of view. That will lead to an improvement in our world. When the report of this 70th Inter- Parliamentary Union conference comes down I will make a further contribution. I have much pleasure in supplementing Senator Watson's comments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to use the opportunity of this first reading debate on the radiocommunications legislation to join with my colleague Senator Tate, from Tasmania, in drawing attention to the fact that the General Assembly of the United Nations has designated the week beginning 24 October-United Nations Day-as Disarmament Week. Disarmament Week will provide an opportunity for governments, peace and nuclear disarmament organisations and others to increase public awareness of the dangers of the arms race, to mobilise public opinion and to create an atmosphere conducive to progress in disarmament negotiations. It provides for mobilisation of world public opinion, and at no time has that been more urgent than it is today.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some of the reasons. The United Nations, in a report published in 1981, compiled some numbing facts on the relationship between disarmament and development. The arms race continues unchecked. I would like to use some figures from the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute-SIPRI. It points out that world military spending totals $US625 billion. That is at least $110 for each man, woman and child on earth. Fifty million people are directly or indirectly engaged in military activities. In a world where energy resources are supposed to be in scarce supply, 6 per cent of the world's petrol consumption is used for military purposes, and one quarter of all research funds goes to military research and development-surely a shocking indictment of the world that we live in today.

The international trade in conventional arms is staggering, amounting to $US26 billion a year. Trade in arms traffic is carried out by both developing and developed countries, particularly the Soviet Union, the United States, France, the United Kingdom, Italy, Brazil and Israel. No one needs to be reminded that the development of nuclear weapons technology has reached frightening proportions. Nuclear over-kill is the hallmark of today's arms race. Fifty thousand nuclear warheads are now deployed. Their combined explosive power is one million times greater than the bomb dropped on Hiroshima in 1945.

Up to 8 per cent of the world's total output is spent on the arms race. Yet the United Nations points out that one child in four suffers from malnutrition; four out of five children in rural areas do not have adequate water or sanitation; two out of five six to 11-year-olds do not go to school; and four out of five children have no modern health care. In fact, the world's military spends every four hours the equivalent of the total budget of the United Nations Children's Fund. The building of one strategic bomber costs more than the $US100m that the World Health Organisation spent wiping out smallpox. The Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Susan Ryan, in a speech in Canberra to the International Symposium on the Consequences of Nuclear War for Australia, revealed that even in our own affluent country the Government spent in excess of $4 billion on defence in 1982. This is when homelessness, unemployment and poverty have been increasing daily over recent years. So where are our priorities? Are we really committed to ensuring decent health, education and nutritional standards for all-that means all the people of the world-or do we see world survival only through the myth of military superiority?

Unfortunately the statistics I have just presented speak for themselves. Efforts to ensure arms control and disarmament are deadlocked. The Stockholm International Peace Research Institute, in its 1982 year book, stated succinctly that the state of play was, as it summed it up, that no progress had been made. Relations between the United States and the Soviet Union are at an all time low. The Soviet Union is threatening to walk out from the Intermediate Nuclear Force negotiations as a reaction to the deployment of missiles in Europe, and the Strategic Arms Reduction Talks-START-which reconvened in Geneva earlier this month have come to a stop. The talks are certainly at a very critical stage. It cannot be emphasised enough how crucial progress in super-power dialogue is in the achievement of disarmament. Yet the dialogue between the super-powers is sadly lacking. President Reagan, in his address to the 38th Session of the United Nations General Assembly, stated:
. . . progress in weapons technology has far outstripped the progress towards peace.
Of course many people in the United States are critical of President Reagan. In an article in the International Herald Tribune, headed 'When Talk Undercuts Arms Talks', Anthony Lewis said:

It is a more dangerous world today than when Mr Reagan took office in 1981. Ordinary communication with Moscow has virtually ceased. US leaders talk about the relationship more and more in military terms-compelling the ordinary citizen , as Mr Kennan says-
referring to the former United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union-
'to conclude that some sort of military showdown is the only conceivable denouement'.

So responsible people are very concerned about the situation. However, I think there is a great deal of hope in the United States for the discussion that is taking place there. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a document from the House of Representatives in the United States headed 'Calling for a Mutual and Verifiable Freeze on and Reduction in Nuclear Weapons'. It is a report of the Committee on Foreign Affairs to the Congress itself.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
CALLING FOR A MUTUAL AND VERIFIABLE FREEZE ON AND REDUCTION IN NUCLEAR WEAPONS

The Committee on Foreign Affairs to whom was referred the joint resolution (H.J . Res. 13) calling for a mutual and verifiable freeze on and reduction in nuclear weapons, having considered the same, report favourably thereon with amendments and recommend that the joint resolution as amended do pass.
The amendments are shown in the reported resolution, with the matter proposed to be stricken shown in linetype and the matter proposed to be inserted shown in italic type.
PURPOSE OF THE RESOLUTION

The purpose of the resolution is to mandate objectives for the conduct of the Strategic Arms Reduction Talks (START) between the United States and the Soviet Union. Much as the legislation ratifying the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty ( SALT I) did for the SALT II Treaty, House Joint Resolution 13 mandates objectives for the conduct of the START negotiations. These objectives are specified in House Joint Resolution 13 and described in the committee comment.
COMMITTEE COMMENT

The Committee on Foreign Affairs believes that progress in arms control and reduction is essential. Congress has a clear responsibility to help formulate a START negotiating posture that contributes to such progress. Since Congress will have to approve the eventual final product of START, it should help form the U.S . negotiating posture if arms reduction is to receive broad bipartisan support.

House Joint Resolution 13 accomplishes this purpose by mandating objectives for the conduct of the START negotiations, including the negotiation of an immediate , mutual, and verifiable freeze on and reductions in nuclear weapons and their delivery systems.

OBJECTIVES FOR START-A MUTUAL AND VERIFIABLE FREEZE ON NUCLEAR WEAPONS The major contribution of House Joint Resolution 13 is the establishment of general objectives for the conduct of the START negotiations.
The guidelines for START in House Joint Resolution 13 as amended are:
(1) Pursuing the objective of negotiating an immediate, mutual, and verifiable freeze.
(2) Deciding when and how to achieve a mutual verifiable freeze on the testing, production, and further deployment of nuclear warheads, missiles, and other delivery systems.

(3) Consistent with pursuing the objective of negotiating an immediate, mutual, and verifiable freeze, giving special attention to destabilizing weapons, especially those which give either nation capabilities which confer upon it even the hypothetical advantages of a first strike.

(4) Proceeding from this mutual and verifiable freeze, pursuing substantial, equitable, and verifiable reductions through numerical ceilings, annual percentages, or any other equally effective and verifiable means of strengthening strategic stability.
(5) Preserving present limitations and controls on nuclear weapons and nuclear delivery systems.
(6) Incorporating ongoing negotiations in Geneva on intermediate-range nuclear systems into the START negotiations.

The objectives for START outlined in House Joint Resolution 13 incorporate the central elements of the nuclear freeze proposal. While much has been made of the grassroots nature of the freeze movement and its growing political popularity, far too little attention has been paid to the fact that a mutual and verifiable United States-Soviet nuclear weapons freeze is a sensible and workable arms control proposal.

A United States-Soviet nuclear weapons freeze is based on three fundamental principles: First, it is grounded in the consensus view that nuclear parity presently describes the overall nuclear balance between the two superpowers; second, a freeze must be mutual to be successful; and third, a freeze must be adequately verifiable.
The existence of parity has been confirmed by high-ranking officials in both Republican and Democratic administrations. Officials of the Reagan administration have also acknowledged this fact.

None of the present Joint Chiefs of Staff have expressed their willingness to trade overall U.S. capabilities for those of the Soviet Union. The committee has also explicitly stated that the objectives of House Joint Resolution 13 must be pursued consistent with essential equivalence in overall nuclear capabilities.

This consensus view is confirmed by the current structure of United States and Soviet strategic forces. While the Soviet Union has more intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) and submarine-launched ballistic missile (SLBM) launchers, the United States has more heavy bombers and more strategic nuclear weapons. The Soviet Union has an advantage in missile throw-weight; the United States has an edge in missile reliability. The United States also has a far greater number of SLBM's and heavy bombers ready to launch at any one time.

Much discussion in the past few years has centred on the possibility of a '' window of vulnerability'' whereby the Soviet Union could theoretically destroy U .S. missiles in their silos in a first strike, leaving the United States the choice of destroying the Soviet Union in a second strike, knowing the United States could be similarly devastated in a third strike, or reaching an unfavorable political accommodation with the Soviet Union.

This scenario the committee believes, is divorced from reality. To destroy the 1,052 U.S. ICBM silos, the Soviet Union would need at least 2,000 perfectly coordinated warheads, all of them spaced and timed to avoid mutual destruction by the phenomenon of ''fratricide,'' which can cause the nuclear explosions of some warheads to affect other warheads before detonation.

In addition, the largest Soviet flight test has involved less than 1 percent of the number of missiles that would be required for a disarming Soviet first strike. Even if all of these extreme obstacles were overcome, the Soviet attack would kill 7-15 million Americans immediately and perhaps up to 20 million more through secondary effects.

These casualty rates are 10 to 20 times the number of American combat deaths in World War II. To assume that, first the President would blithely ignore the incoming Soviet missiles and not order U.S. ICBM's launched, and second, not retaliate when faced with 17 to 35 million American deaths, is an incredible scenario with no basis in reality.

Finally, the ''window of vulnerability'' is reciprocal. While the Soviet Union has more ICBM launchers, it has achieved this advantage by placing 75 percent of its strategic nuclear forces in vulnerable ICBM's. The United States has placed only 24 percent of its nuclear weapons in its ICBM force. Aside from providing the United States with a staggering, versatile retaliatory capability, existing U.S. short-range attack missiles and Minuteman III ICBM's give the United States significant counterforce capability against three-quarters of the Soviet Union's nuclear arsenal. In contrast, the majority of U.S. retaliatory weapons are on stations in invulnerable submarines. Thus, the theoretical window of vulnerability is reciprocal and makes any first strike a dangerous gamble with unacceptable risks.
The inescapable fact of effective nuclear parity in United States-Soviet nuclear arsenals leads to the second fundamental concept on which a freeze is based; that a freeze be mutual to be successful.

The nuclear freeze as proposed in House Joint Resolution 13 will not unilaterally preclude any defense program proposed by the Reagan administration. Issues such as when to implement a freeze and how to deal with replacement of older nuclear systems must be negotiated in the START framework. A freeze agreement would come after negotiations which will be mutual and will not be unilateral.

Contrary to the contention that the United States has engaged in unilateral disarmament during the 1970's, both the United States and the Soviet Union made major improvements in their strategic nuclear forces in the 1970's. While in the last decade, the Soviet Union deployed 5 new ICBM's, the United States outproduced the Soviet Union in numbers of warheads by 1,100 introduced Poseidon and Trident SLBM's, upgraded its ICBM force, and added over 1,000 short-range attack missiles to the B-52 bomber force.

These improvements on both sides have brought nuclear arsenals to a level well beyond what is needed to preserve deterrence. The central reality of the strategic balance today is that neither side can start and win a nuclear war. One Poseidon submarine with Trident missiles can cause at least 25 million Soviet fatalities. 5 million more than the Soviet Union suffered in World War II . Standard computations of destructive power continue to show that each of the three legs of the U.S. strategic triad can kill one-third of the Soviet population and destroy two-thirds of its industry even after a Soviet first strike.

New U.S. weapons as bargaining chips are alleged to be necessary to achieve prohibitions on new Soviet weapons. But by banning new Soviet nuclear weapons en bloc, the freeze renders this theory obsolete. Soviet efforts to gain a unilateral advantage in nuclear weaponry under the current Reagan administration START proposals would be blocked. Near-term Soviet advantages in nuclear weapons systems production could be blunted.

Arming in order to disarm brings only higher levels of nuclear forces. The history of previous arms control negotiations is replete with examples of weapons which began as bargaining chips and became virtually impossible to control once production began. The failure to prevent the development and deployment of weapons systems originally intended as bargaining chips in past arms control negotiations has undermined the security of both sides, symbolized by the failure to prohibit MIRV capability in the SALT I negotiations. This led directly to vulnerable ICBM forces on both sides.
The third fundamental principle on which a United States-Soviet nuclear weapons freeze is based is that of verifiability.

Testing on and deployment of Soviet systems can be effectively verified by U.S. national technical means. In testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, former Under Secretary of Defense for Research, Development, Testing, and Engineering William Perry stated ''at the nuclear weapons production stage, the United States has been able to monitor Soviet activities at the design bureau and production plants so that every Soviet ICBM test has been predicted before if occurs.'' Beyond national technical means, the Soviet Union has agreed to unmanned seismic stations and onsite inspection procedures in the negotiations for a comprehensive test ban treaty. Such procedures would prove highly useful in the verification of a mutual and verifiable nuclear weapons freeze.

It should also be pointed out that uncertainties in verification of nuclear weapons production can be compensated for by the high confidence in verification regarding testing and deployment. Furthermore, a freeze would mean a stop to all activities in any weapons program to be included so that the detection of even one new missile or aircraft would be evidence of a violation. This simplifies the verification over that required for monitoring a ceiling. In assessing adequate verification, the threshold that should be established is confidence that any violation that would significantly affect our security would have a high probability of being detected.

In short, the fact of nuclear parity makes a mutual and verifiable weapons- freeze a workable and attractive proposal. Such a freeze would provide a complete halt to another round of the arms race, thereby enhancing US security.
OTHER OBJECTIVES FOR START

The committee realises that a mutual and verifiable freeze on United States- Soviet nuclear arsenals is not an end in itself. For this reason, House Joint Resolution 13 also calls for substantial, equitable, and verifiable reductions proceeding from a freeze. These reductions can best be achieved after a freeze has been negotiated to completely halt the nuclear arms race. The committee recognises, however, and House Joint Resolution 13 states that concurrent and complementary arms control proposals consistent with pursuing the overriding objectives of negotiating an immediate, mutual, and verifiable freeze should also be considered.

Another START objective sought by House Joint Resolution 13 is the negotiation of limits on destabilising weapons, especially first-strike weapons. Destabilising weapons are those which have the capability of destroying the other side's strategic nuclear weapons thereby reducing confidence in their deterrent value. Weapons with a combination of high accuracy, multiple warheads, large explosive force, and short flight time are the most threatening of these weapons, since they have the potential capability of destroying protected hard targets like ICBM silos and command posts in a disarming first strike. In particular, the committee believes that such first-strike weapons, which give either nation capabilities which confer upon it even the hypothetical advantage of a first strike, should receive special priority in the START negotiations.

Other weapons such as antisubmarine warfare technologies and sophisticated air defenses which could prevent nuclear weapons from being launched or reaching their targets could also be destabilising if breakthroughs in these technologies provided high confidence in their success, and it is the committee's intent, therefore, that every effort should be made to reach agreement on such systems as well.

Finally, the commitee believes that the START framework should incorporate ongoing negotiations in Geneva on intermediate-range nuclear systems. These systems are inextricably linked to strategic nuclear forces on both sides and negotiations on these systems should be integrated with START. Such incorporation would strengthen the linkage between US strategic and theater nuclear forces and therefore strengthen the political cohesiveness and unity of the NATO alliance.

The committee also believes that the US position in the negotiations of START must be the product of close consultations with the NATO allies to insure that a common position on START can be developed that is not inconsistent with existing US commitments to those allies.

In conclusion, the committee strongly reiterates that House Joint Resolution 13 is a bipartisan arms control approach. Both committee Democrats and committee Republicans have supported this joint resolution and believe it establishes the objectives that best insure the results at START that the American people have demanded.

TALK.START.PARA: —The document refers to the world-wide movement which is becoming a common denominator in discussions in an attempt to have a nuclear freeze movement. The United Nations is a forum that can make known the shared concern of its member nations on issues such as disarmament. The United Nations devotes a considerable amount of its time to discussing disarmament. In 1978 the General Assembly convened specially to discuss the arms race and the achievement of disarmament. In 1982 the Second Special Session on Disarmament was convened. A feature of this session was the strong march for disarmament in New York of a million people. Yet, in spite of mass support for peace and disarmament and the high hopes of many United Nations members, the Second Special Session of the United Nations was a failure. No agreement was reached on a comprehensive program of disarmament. Everyone, of course, supports and accepts the need for disarmament. Yet many nations are reluctant to put their words into action. Efforts must be exerted to ensure that the principles and resolutions of the United Nations are adhered to by all member nations. Australia is such a nation. The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Bill Hayden, in his address to the United Nations General Assembly on 4 October 1983 pointed out:

SPEECH.PARA: We have the charter. We have the principles. What we lack is the consistent will to implement them-a sufficient commitment to this institution which is the real and only expression of the international community.

There is a recognition that the United Nations has a central role to play in negotiations to bring about disarmament. This negotiating role is largely carried out by the 40-member Committee on Disarmament, which is known also as the Conference on Disarmament, which is based in Geneva. The Committee on Disarmament is the main multinational negotiating forum on disarmament matters. It was constituted following the 1978 General Assembly Special Session. All five nuclear weapon states-that is, the United States, the Soviet Union, France, the United Kingdom and China-are involved in the negotiations. The 157-member General Assembly can also consider questions on disarmament, arms control and the maintenance of international peace. The General Assembly's First Committee devotes its entire agenda to disarmament and international security matters. The General Assembly also has a subsidiary body known as the United Nations Disarmament Commission. Its function is to make recommendations on various disarmament issues. It also follows up the relevant decisions of the General Assembly's 1978 and 1982 special sessions on disarmament.

I am pleased to say that the Australian Government is committed to the arms control and disarmament goals of the United Nations. Foreign Affairs Minister, Bill Hayden, in his address to the General Assembly, stressed that these goals should be developed further and urged all nations to adhere to them. Evidence of this Government's commitment to disarmament is the announcement of the appointment of Richard Butler as Ambassador for Disarmament. As my colleague Senator Tate said, Ambassador Butler is already in New York representing Australia at the General Assembly's First Committee discussions. He will also be the Australian representative at the Geneva-based Committee on Disarmament and will be liaising with peace and disarmament groups in Australia.

Within the Department of Foreign Affairs, the section on disarmament and arms control will be strengthened and upgraded. Efforts are now under way to establish an independent peace research body. I was fortunate in July of this year to see the SIPRI, the Swedish organisation. I believe it will be a great acquisition to the movement for peace and disarmament in Australia to have such a body operating. The feasibility of introducing peace studies in schools and tertiary institutions is also being considered by the Labor Government. The Labor Government intends to take a leading role in demanding a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty which will ban all nuclear tests by all nations in all environments. This is vital if France is to cease nuclear testing in the Pacific . The Labor Government supports proposals for an Indian Ocean zone of peace and a South West Pacific nuclear free zone. A priority of this Government is to urge the Committee on Disarmament to set up a working group which would negotiate an agreement preventing the spread of the arms race into outer space.

I refer to the platform of the Australian Labor Party because it refers to a significant part of our objectives as being the maintenance of world peace, an independent Australian position in world affairs, recognition of the right of all nations to self-determination and independence, regional and international agreement for arms control and disarmament, and the provision of economic and social aid to developing countries. I mention this because under the heading ' Principles of Action' the objectives of the Australian Labor Party are set out. We there refer to the need for constitutional action through Australian State parliaments. We refer also to the ongoing action by organised community groups, including trade unions. I am proud to say that I participate in this in a dual role. In Sydney I am the convenor of the Nuclear Disarmament Co-ordinating Committee, which husbands the various disparate groups which are involved in nuclear disarmament. I am pleased to say that this Committee represents a broad cross-section of organisations which can put 60,000 people on the streets of Sydney-they have done it for two years in succession-to demonstrate the fact that the people of Australia are concerned about these issues. I believe it is that combination of parliamentary initiative, international initiative and the movement of the Australian people that might give us the opportunity of setting aside the mad race we have in the world today of weapons and nuclear weapons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity at the first reading stage of a money Bill to raise an issue which is causing a deal of concern in my State of Western Australia. That concern emanates from a series of newspaper reports in which the State Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hassell , has been highly critical of the Burke Labor Government. No one would deny the right of the Opposition, particularly the Leader and the Deputy Leader, to be critical of government, but I make the point that Mr Hassell is being totally destructive of those people whom he has chosen to get into his sights. He has always demonstrated a tendency not only to put his foot in his mouth but also to make sure that the entire leg goes in. Perhaps honourable senators remember that when he was Minister for Community Welfare he issued a directive to his department, the Department of Community Welfare, that when a woman found that she had to leave a domestic situation because it was abhorrent to her, even if she had to take the children, she was not to receive financial support from the Department until such time as the husband had been consulted. Many women and many refuges, of course, were disadvantaged by this action.

SPEECH.PARA: As I am sure the Senate will appreciate, when a woman chooses to leave a domestic situation, particularly if it happens to be in the middle of the night, it is generally because of one of a number of reasons. It could be because of violence being demonstrated to either her or her children, alcoholism, or a number of other matters. To deny those people financial support at that harrowing time is something which I felt was reprehensible. One can only presume that he is Deputy Leader of the Opposition because of his tendency to put his foot in his mouth every time he opens it. I have no doubt he will remain in opposition for a long time.

Mr Hassell is endeavouring to ensure that when the Government makes grants or opportunities to organisations with which he has a disagreement he gets the most insulting publicity in the newspapers. A grant was made to the Homosexual Counselling and Information Service for a community education program. This money came from the wage pause grants. It was money that had been agreed to by a very well represented and community-based committee which views all of these determinations. That committee had decided that this amount of $30,820 should be used by the Homosexual Counselling and Information Service for a community education program. The headlines to that article in the Daily News relating to that grant stated: 'Gay Grant an insult-Hassell'. Mr Hassell said in that article:
My God, what are they advocating? The spreading of AIDS?
Obviously the Minister is only demonstrating a lack of awareness of how AIDS is transmitted as well. This was a grant for counselling and information.
The second matter comes under a heading in the West Australian where he was angered by a Trades and Labour Council job cost. The money was allocated from the wage pause grants. The article stated:
. . . the Government had allocated $10,645 to the TLC to employ a library and research assistant.
This money had come from wage-pause savings and was supposed to be used on job- creation schemes.

I do not know what Mr Hassell thinks a library and research assistant is. Obviously he does not believe that it belongs to a job creation scheme. It is a paltry sum of money. The important thing he forgot to mention was that, once again, the allocation was recommended unanimously by a broadly based community representative consultative committee.

Because of the limited time that honourable senators are allowed to speak at the first reading stages of Bills, I feel it is important that the third and most important instance of this foot-in-mouth disease from which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in Western Australia suffers is taken from the West Australian of 23 September. The headline to that article stated: 'Women's group bunch of hobos, says Hassell'. I will quote some of the things that he said because it is important to recognise the type of slurring campaign that is going on. The article states:

The deputy leader of the Opposition, Mr Hassell, last night described the newly appointed Women's Advisory Council as a 'bunch of hobos'. 'You've left out the decent women who represent the views of the community,' he told the Premier, Mr Burke, in the Legislative Assembly.
He continued:
'Why were five members of the Women's Electoral Lobby, a small, left-wing radical group, selected while other bigger, responsible women's organisations were given no representation?' . . .
'Has the selection of membership studiously avoided women who are married with families?'

Presumably Mr Hassell believes that the majority of those women who have been appointed to the Western Australian Women's Advisory Council are, as he termed it, members of that left wing radical organisation, the Women's Electoral Lobby, which, I point out, was the very first organisation in this country to endeavour to educate women who had no political education at all on how they were being affected by politics.

I could take the time to read out the organisations and individuals who made submissions, but because time is limited I will not. I want to go through some of the qualifications of the women on the Council. Firstly, the president of the Western Australian Women's Advisory Council is Dot Goodrick. She is a community planner and works in the planning and research branch of the Department of Community Welfare. She has a background as a social worker, a welfare officer, an international exchange nurse, a theatre sister and a district nurse in London which makes her well-placed to pursue issues of particular interest or expertise such as self-sufficiency for women. This is one woman who was referred to as a hobo by Mr Hassell. Her educational qualifications include a Bachelor of Arts degree from the University of Western Australia in anthropology, psychology, politics and economic history and a Masters degree in social work also from the University of Western Australia. Dot is a member of the Western Australian Institute of Technology Social Work Advisory Committee, the WAIT Social Science Advisory Committee, an executive committee member of the Citizens' Advice Bureau and is on the executive committee of the Western Australian Council of Social Service and is its first Vice-President. Since 1977 Dot has been a consultant to the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific. In that capacity she has visited many countries and taken particular interest in women and development programs in Asia. She won a Churchill Fellowship last year and studied self-help and self-sufficiency for single parents in the United States of America, Britain and Sweden.

For six years she served on a Federal Government committee called the Women's Welfare Issues Consultative Committee. She is also a member of the Western Institute of Self-Help and is a member of the United Nations Association of Australia, Western Australia, and convenes that committee on the Status of Women . In this capacity she chaired the International Women's Year State committee and was the Western Australian representative on the national committee. Dot also has been a member of the Australian Federation of University Women for some years. She is one of the women referred to by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in Western Australia as a hobo.

Helen Cattalini is a senior social worker with the Italo-Australian Welfare Centre. Helen was born in Fremantle of Italian parents and speaks Italian. From 1971 to 1979 she was the senior social worker at the City of Fremantle. She has a degree in social welfare from WAIT and 12 years' experience in the welfare field. She has served on the executive committee of the Western Australian Council of Social Service and has been President of the Ethnic Community Council of Western Australia. She also has membership of the Western Australian Consultative Committee of Social Welfare, the Fremantle Hospital Board and the Community Employment Program Allocation Committee. Helen was particularly involved in Fremantle in setting up the women's refuge and child care centres. She also set up a neighbourhood centre in South Fremantle which is a very low socio-economic area. The area has a high migrant population. Helen was inaugural president of the Fremantle Migrant Resource Centre. She is another woman who was referred to as a hobo by Mr Hassell.

Kath French is another woman member of this group. I am sure that there are not too many women members of this Parliament and probably not too many male members of the Parliament who are not aware of the activities of Kath French over the years.

TALK.START.PARA: —She's a member of the Liberal Party.

—She is a member of the Liberal Party, indeed. I am grateful to the Minister for reminding me of it. Kath has tremendous qualifications for the job as adviser to the Western Australian Government on the Western Australian Women's Advisory Council. She is a full time wife and mother of five. She has a particular concern for women's interests and motherhood. She served on the National Women's Advisory Council for two years and has been a volunteer organiser for community welfare associations. Kath is vice-president and board member of the YWCA of Perth, and organiser and foundation member of the Ryder Cheshire Foundation, a foundation member of the 3LS Club, a speakers club for women, and in 1979 was a member of the Mid-Decade for Women Committee in Western Australia. Kath has been a member of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation and for more than 20 years has been an organiser with the Royal Flying Doctor Service Women's Auxiliary.

SPEECH.PARA: I could go through all members but I recognise that my time will not permit that. I will briefly mention them by name and occupation. Daphne Baldwin is a Wyndham East Kimberley Shire councillor, justice of the peace and librarian aide . Betty Connell is a Roebourne Shire Councillor and justice of the peace. Helen Errington is a part time worker with Disabled Advocates and Self-Help. Helen happens to be disabled. It was heartening to me as a woman who does not suffer from a physical disability to attend Government House at the announcement of the appointment of these people to the Women's Advisory Council and to see Helen there in her wheelchair. I recognised that she has specific expertise that she can bring to any government, either through a committee or directly to a Minister in the needs of the disabled. She is also a secretary of DASH, the Disabled Advocates and Self-Help organisation. Queenie Fogarty is a retired school teacher and school counsellor. Her current occupation is home duties. Rosemary Hannon is a teacher in charge at St Mary's Junior Primary School, South Bunbury. Anne-Marie Heine is a teacher and senior vice-president of the Teachers Union. Pauline Hutchinson is the acting Superintendent of Education, Equal Opportunity. Gillian Kaub is a union organiser with the Western Australian Shop Assistants Union. There are also Dr Gwen Leavesley, Medical Director of the Family Planning Association of Western Australia; Ruth Moira from Borden; Liza Newby, a senior tutor in the Law School at the University of Western Australia; Janet Pine, a research assistant and justice of the peace; and Pat Ryan, retired honorary treasurer of the Christian Television Association. This is a woman who, as I said, was referred to by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in Western Australia as a hobo. Other members are Roslyn Shea, a teacher and relieving deputy principal of the White Gum Valley Special School; Diana Warnock, radio producer and announcer, film critic for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and aerobic fitness instructor; Joan Winch, the co-ordinator, health education, Aboriginal Medical Service of Western Australia Inc.; and last, but by no means least, Judith Siddins, a final year apprentice fitter and first class machinist.

Mr Deputy President, I am sure you will recognise that in our changing society at long last women are entering fields that have never been open to them before, and Judith is one of those women. Judith is a very young person. She has a particular interest in women in blue collar employment and with special emphasis on the problems of women in non-traditional work areas. Her other interests include technological change and occupational health and safety, especially as they relate to women. She has worked mostly in blue collar work and for almost four years has been an apprentice in what has been traditionally a male trade. She has a certificate of trade studies for fitting and first class machining. She has a deep concern and experience of the problems women face who are already in the work force. As I said, Mr Deputy President, I am deeply concerned that women of this calibre, women from every walk of life in the State of Western Australia, who have been gathered together to compose the greatest possible Advisory Council that has ever been available to any State or Federal government at any time, should be referred to in the manner that they have by Mr Hassell, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in Western Australia. I believe it is important that these women be promoted in the jobs that they are doing and that the work they do in turn is promoted, particularly by other women who happen to be members of parliament. I am conscious that my speaking time is about to expire. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the book entitled The Western Australian Women's Advisory Council 1983 and the newspaper articles from which I quoted.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
THE WESTERN AUSTRALIAN WOMEN'S ADVISORY COUNCIL 1983

The establishment of the Advisory Council, and the decision to set up a women's unit and appoint a senior advisor on women's interests within the Department of Premier and Cabinet is the beginning of efforts to redress years of neglect in this area.
The needs of women are inadequately understood because most of the decision makers today are usually male. Too little attention has been given to policy on the subject of women's interest.

The Labor Party promised action in this area and today's announcement shows we are acting positively so that women no longer will be grossly unrepresented at every senior level of the community, including government, business and the professions.

Prior to the 1983 State election the Labor Party endorsed many women for seats in the W.A. Parliament. The ballot box showed our decision was timely and correct by the fact that so many men and women elected them to Parliament.

The Government believes the new Western Australian Women's Advisory Council will make a major contribution to enhancing the status of women in the community and build on the hard-won achievements made by the women's movements in years gone by.
BRIAN BURKE Premier and Cabinet, Treasurer, Minister Co-ordinating Economic and Social Development and Minister for Forests, Tourism, and Women's Interests.
WOMEN'S ADVISORY COUNCIL

The Western Australian Government believes that to be consulted about decisions affecting one's life is a basic right in any democracy. In Western Australia, for historical and other reasons, women have not been well represented in the decision-making machinery of the State. In law, education, medicine, sport, business and commerce, and in politics, women have been noticeably under- represented.
The community has not fully availed itself of the talents and skills that half of its population has to offer.
It is for these reasons that the Western Australian Women's Advisory Council has been established.

A public meeting held in Perth in April of this year to discuss the formation of a Women's Advisory Council was attended by more than 150 representatives from Women's organisations. This meeting gave strong support to the proposal to establish a Women's Advisory Council.
Following the meeting written submissions were received from 60 groups and individuals. These submissions overwhelmingly endorsed the establishment of a council.

The Government has now sought to draw together women with a wide range of expertise and experience, representing different interests and from different backgrounds, to articulate the views of West Australian women. This Women's Advisory Council will serve as a consultative body for the Government. It will offer its opinion and advice on proposed legislation and other Government initiatives as well as drawing the Government's attention to areas where legislation is needed.

The Council will make itself available to community groups and individuals throughout Western Australia. It will listen to the views of women from all walks of life and will take these views into account in its deliberations. It will be able to investigate problems that it considers require attention and will recommend action to the Government.

The Western Australian Women's Advisory Council will offer advice to the Premier in his role as Minister for Women's Interests. It will promote equality of opportunity for women throughout Western Australia.
The Council will hold seminars, produce newsletters, visit regional centres and use all means that it considers appropriate to meet and exchange ideas and information with women.

The Government believes that the appointment of a Women's Advisory Council is a significant event in the history of Western Australia. The Government is pleased that the group of very competent and experienced women who are the inaugural Council members have accepted positions on the Council.
The Government looks forward to working with the Council and wishes it every success in its endeavours.

To assist people throughout Western Australia to have an input into matters affecting women, the Government has compiled this booklet as a public service. The members of the Women's Advisory Council welcome your input.
SUBMISSIONS
This publication is aimed at assisting women, and others, throughout Western Australia to have a direct input into the Portfolio of Women's Interests.

ANNE-MARIE HEINE
Teacher; Senior Vice President of Teachers' Union.
Anne-Marie brings to the Women's Advisory Committee a wealth of experience in education, industrial relations, and women at work.

A recent appointment to the Committee of Inquiry into Education (W.A.), commonly known as the Beazley Committee, Anne-Marie also has membership on the A .B.C. Education Advisory Committee, the Australian Women's Education Coalition, the Australian Labor Party, the Women's Committee of the Australian Teachers' Federation and the Australian Council of Trade Union's Education Committee.

PAULINE HUTCHINSON
Acting Superintendent of Education. (Equal Opportunity).
An ex officio member, Pauline is interested in the education of women and girls , social change and its effect on work and family life.

Institute of Education Administration (Secretary), the Equal Opportunity Resource Centre, the Career Education Association of W.A. and the Australian Womens' Education Coalition and the Business and Professional Women Organisation.

GILLIAN KAUB
Union organiser, W.A. Shop Assistants' Union.

Gillian has particular interests and expertise in the role of women in the workforce and in trade unions. She also is interested in the position of young people in the community. She has many years experience working in the retail industry, three years as a union organiser and has been involved in various community committees such as cubs, scouts and parents and citizens organisations .
Gillian was born in Leura in New South Wales in April 1941, and has passed the NSW Leaving Certificate. She lives in Mundaring and has raised a family of four sons.

Medical Director of the Family Planning Association of W.A.

Her community committee service embraces almost 20 years' involvement with sporting organisations, medical committees and educational pursuits.

RUTH MOIR
Ruth lives and works at 'Chillinup', Borden.

Senior Tutor, Law School, University of Western Australia.

JANET PINE
Research Assistant and Justice of the Peace.
Janet, who was born in Collie, holds union membership with the ACOA.
Janet has a Bachelor of Arts degree, of (UWA) 1980, and works for Senator Pat Giles.

PAT RYAN
Retired Hon. Treasurer, Christian Television Association.
Pat Ryan has a particular interest in Christian affairs.

During WAY 1979 she was executive officer for the Combined Churches contribution to the sesquicentenary celebrations. As a Christian, Pat has taken a particular interest in the growing world ecumenical movement.

Teacher and Relieving Deputy Principal of the Whitegum Valley Special School.

Final year apprentice fitter and first class machinist.

She has a deep concern, and experience, with the problems women face who are already in the workforce. She often gives talks to high school classes encouraging young women to broaden their work horizons and look at less traditional work options.

DIANA WARNOCK
Radio producer and announcer; film critic for the Australian Broadcasting Commission; Aerobic Fitness instructor.
Diana Warnock is well known for her duties as a producer and on-air personality at Radio Station 6PR. She has a particular interest in films, women's issues, literature, fitness, jazz and the media.

JOAN WINCH
Co-ordinator, Health Education, Aboriginal Medical Services.
Joan Winch has a particular interest and expertise in the question of Aboriginal health.
