Joan has a Diploma of Applied Science achieved at WAIT in 1977.
She is an associate member of the Royal College of Nurses (Australia) and has been Secretary for the Southern Suburbs Aboriginal Progress Association.
In 1976, Joan went on a study tour of India looking at health care in relation to Aboriginal health problems.
In 1978 she went on a study tour of China studying possible schemes to be implemented in Australia.
She is associated with the implementation of a newly formed health education programme for Aboriginal workers.
Joan, in previous years, has involved herself in community nursing.
MEMBERS OF STATE PARLIAMENT
The number of women members of State Parliament indicate the progress made in the recognition of the status of women.
Mr Bob Hetherington, MLC, has been a member of the State Parliamentary Labor Party Caucus Committee on women's interests since 1978.
''For every man who put one stone upon another in building the foundations of the colony, there was a woman to put the mortar between the stones to keep them together.''
WOMEN'S GROUP BUNCH OF HOBOS, SAYS HASSELL
The deputy leader of the Opposition, Mr Hassell, last night described the newly appointed Women's Advisory Council as ''a bunch of hobos.''
''You've left out the decent women who represent the views of the community,'' he told the Premier, Mr Burke, in the Legislative Assembly.
Mr Hassell's comments came while Mr Burke was answering a question about the composition of the women's council.
Liberal MLA Peter Coyne (Murchison-Eyre) asked Mr Burke who had selected the 20 members.

''Why were five members of the Women's Electoral Lobby, a small, left-wing radical group, selected while other bigger, responsible women's organisations were given no representation?'' Mr Coyne asked.
''Has the selection of membership studiously avoided women who are married with families?''
Mr Burke said that the question reflected ''the paranoia of the Opposition.''
''In nine years of government you did nothing about treating half the population fairly.'' he said.
''We are now attempting to redress that wrong.''
He said that the Government had considered submissions and names put forward by interested groups and individuals.

The members had been selected on the basis of their expertise and qualifications and what they had to contribute, not according to whether they were already part of existing women's organisations, Mr Burke said.
GAY GRANT AN INSULT-HASSELL
By John Arthur
The State Government was accused today of an ''insulting and contemptible slur' ' on the community by giving money to the homosexual movement.

The deputy leader of the Opposition, Mr Bill Hassell, said he believed the Government soon would announce a grant of $30,820 to the Homosexual Counselling and Information Service for a community education programme.
''I am absolutely amazed,'' he said ''I just can't believe it.
''The Government is taking money saved from the federal wage pause to promote homosexuality, which is an illegal activity in this State.

''The money is supposed to employ two education officers, but I think this is a contemptible slur on the community because the money should be directed to furthering the long-term, secure employment prospects of unemployed people, particularly the disadvantaged.
''Nobody in their right mind could regard this project with any level of priority in an economy as devastated as ours-and the best they can come up with is to spend money for homosexual counselling.
''My God what are they advocating? The spreading of AIDS?''
Mr Hassell said he had obtained a 22-page list of job projects to be funded from the federal wage pause.
He took exception to grants to the Trades and Labor Council ($10,465) to employ a library research assistant,
TLC JOB COST ANGERS HASSELL
The Opposition has accused the Government of spending taxpayers' money to employ staff for the Trades and Labor Council.
The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hassell, said yesterday that the Government had allocated $10,645 to the TLC to employ a library and research assistant.
This money had come from wage-pause savings and was supposed to be used on job- creation schemes.
The move was a disgraceful addition to the Government's already shameful record of jobs for boys and political patronage.
''It must be remembered that the TLC is comprised of the richest and most powerful unions in WA,'' he said.

''It might be good for the person who gets the job, but nothing alters the fact that the Government should be spending taxpayers' money for the good of the public and not for the benefit of the TLC.''
Allocations
Mr Hassell said that there were other blatantly political allocations of job creation funds.
But the Minister for Employment, Mr Parker, said that Mr Hassell had made a shameful attempt to undermine public confidence in job creation.
Mr Hassell had deliberately not said that the allocation was recommended unanimously by a broadly based community representative consultative committee.
Sitting suspended from 1.52 to 2 p.m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) will be absent from this chamber today and tomorrow. Any questions which would normally be directed to him in relation to his portfolio or those which he represents should be directed to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes).

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Resources and Energy. I refer the Minister to his answer to Senator Chaney's question on Tuesday about the market outlook for uranium. Senator Walsh will recall quoting approvingly from remarks which he said had been attributed to Mr Tony Grey of Pancontinental Mining Ltd to the effect that the anticipated demand for uranium in the early 1990s might not now be realised until the end of the century. Has the Minister yet checked the accuracy or otherwise of this alleged statement by Mr Grey in London, as he said he would? If so, does he agree that Mr Grey made no such statement during his address to the annual symposium of the Uranium Institute at the end of August? If the checking process is still incomplete, does the Minister agree that it was irresponsible of him to raise the matter in the way in which he did on Tuesday?

—I asked my staff about three days ago, I think it was, to endeavour to have that report checked out. I presume that, among other things, the Department would have been asked. The checking out process has not been completed. The last part of the question was whether I believe that I acted irresponsibly in mentioning the statement if it had not been checked out. No, I do not believe that I acted irresponsibly because I made it perfectly clear at the time I made that statement that such a remark had been reported and attributed to Mr Grey and that I was in the process of checking it out. That is absolutely correct and there is no irresponsibility about it. I certainly did not assert that Mr Grey had made such a remark. A major reason why I raised the matter is that I would be surprised if Mr Grey did make such a comment.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. Has the Minister seen the headline in today's Daily Mirror which states that pensions and unemployment benefits will be cut as a result of the defeat of the Government's tax Bills? Has the Minister identified the source of this headline? Whether he has or not, is it true that there will be such pension changes in the next 12 months or in the 1984-85 Budget?
—Yes, the headline in the Daily Mirror has been drawn to my attention. I am very surprised that the headline is there and that in fact the article was produced in that way.
—You should not be surprised in view of what Senator Walsh said.

—I suppose I should quote that famous Tasmanian Australian Democrat member of parliament when I read articles such as that and suggest that I wonder what those turkeys have been smoking when they write them. In fact, the article is what is known as a beat-up. It arises from a reply by my colleague, Senator Walsh, who was asked what alternatives the Government has when its revenue is reduced by $207m-odd by the irresponsible action of Opposition parties. Senator Walsh said: 'Oh, well, we have three options. We can cut our cloth to suit the amount of money we have; we can cut expenditure; or we can increase taxes'. Out of this has arisen the article which suggests that we will cut pensions and benefits. In fact, that article is nonsense. We have no intention of cutting pensions. We have no intention of cutting benefits. In the last Budget we in fact increased both pensions and benefits. We are committed to the indexation of pension and the increase of the standard rate of pensions to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. We have demonstrated, by increasing benefits, by indexing unemployment benefits for single people and increasing them by $4-odd a week earlier in the year, by $2 a week in November and by $2 a week in May, that we will not allow disadvantaged people in this community to suffer in the way that the previous Government made them suffer, first of all, by cutting down indexation in one year to only once a year; secondly, by cutting out since 1978 indexation for single people on unemployment benefits; and, thirdly, by failing to increase the under-18 unemployment benefit from 1975 to 1982. It is not people on this side of the House who will cut pensions and benefits. The record shows in recent years that the only people who will cut pensions and benefits in this country are in fact the members of the Government which was in power from 1975 to 1983, when we had seven dark years of government by a discredited former Prime Minister, a discredited former Treasurer and a series of discredited former Ministers for Social Security. Yes, I have seen the article. No, there is no truth in the article. It is what is known as a beat-up. It is an article aimed at selling newspapers rather than bearing any resemblance to the truth.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has outlined the current policy of the Government in relation to indexation. I was looking for an unusual assurance, to kill this rumour, that in fact no change will be made diminishing unemployment or social security benefits in the 1984-85 Budget.
—I thought the Minister had answered it. I will allow the supplementary question.
—Even this far ahead of the 1984-85 Budget, I can give Senator Tate an absolute assurance that none of those benefits will be reduced in that Budget.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy . I refer to the frequent statements of the Government when in opposition that oil prices should be adjusted regularly to conform with the changes in the exchange rate. I ask: Does the Government still support that policy or is it to be another of the many abandoned policies? If the Government still supports the principle, when will the policy be implemented? If implemented on the basis of the current exchange rate, what would be the change in the price of a litre of petrol?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of frequent statements being made over a long period by the Australian Labor Party in opposition along the lines set out by Senator Archer. I do, however, recall very clearly saying myself, and I recall Mr Keating saying, that the import parity price should not have been adjusted upwards on 1 January this year by, I think it was, $3.40 a barrel or something like that, on the ground that that reflected a true import parity price, because , as blind Freddy and his dog knew at the time, the notional import parity price upon which that adjustment was made, which was $34 a barrel ex-Gulf Saudi light crude, was not the price at which oil was being sold in the world. In fact oil was being sold at very much lower prices. That was an assertion which was absolutely proven, of course, within a couple of months when the official Saudi marker price was reduced from $US34 a barrel to $US29 a barrel.

ANSWER.PARA: As to future import parity pricing adjustments, which was the subject matter of the precise question which Senator Archer asked at the end of his question, I do not know what the exchange rate is today but it is certainly higher than it was at the time the import parity price was last adjusted. That price was operative from 1 April at the exchange rate that prevailed at 14 March, I believe it was. If the present Australia-United States dollar exchange rate were applied and all the other practices of the former Government continued, the administered price of domestically produced oil would come down. Whether six-monthly adjustments will be continued is a matter which the Government will decide. One of the factors influencing that decision, as has always been the case, is the revenue consideration-a consideration that is all the more urgent in the case of this Government because of the desperate financial situation which it inherited from its predecessors. At the time when the statements to which Senator Archer referred were being made the public had been told by the discredited former Treasurer that on a no-policy-change basis the country was facing a prospective deficit of $6 billion in 1983-84. The discredited former Treasurer was advised by the Secretary to the Treasury five days before the election that on a no- policy-change basis the prospective deficit for 1983-84 was in fact $9 1/2 billion.

The discredited former Treasurer put to the discredited former Prime Minister whether the public should be made aware of that fact. The Prime Minister said ' No; give them the mushroom treatment. Keep them in the dark. Keep the mugs believing that the real deficit we are facing is $6 billion and not $9 1/2 billion', which was the true figure at that time. Of course, when we came into government we discovered all this. We discovered that we were facing a massively larger deficit than we had expected or that the country had been led by the discredited former Treasurer and the discredited former Prime Minister to expect .

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. It would not be Question Time if I did not draw your attention to standing orders 99 and 100 and to the debating of questions. The Minister consistently continues to debate questions. He was asked a simple question about the policy of adjusting the price of oil in accordance with changes in the exchange rate. We are being treated to a diatribe on general economic policy. I ask you to call the Minister to order.
—I think the Minister was answering the generality of the question that was asked. I shall allow him to continue. However, I ask him to keep within the framework of the question.

—Certainly, Mr President. I would not agree that I was indulging in a diatribe on economic policy. I was putting on the record some historical facts. All the reasons I have given will have to be taken into consideration by the Government when it makes a decision on the timing and magnitude of future changes in the administered price of domestic crude oil.
—I ask a supplementary question. In amongst all that, am I to understand that the policy of the Government is that it will be upholding neither the principle nor the practice?
—The answer is no.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: APPOINTMENT TO THE AUSTRALIAN DIPLOMATIC SERVICE

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs assure the Senate that a full and proper investigation will be made into allegations that the son of Sir Robert Sparkes, President of the Queensland National Party, was recruited into the Australian diplomatic service earlier this year as a result of Sir Robert's influence with Mr Peter Henderson, Secretary to the Department of Foreign Affairs? Does the Minister agree that this example of coalition harmony in Canberra contrasts sharply with the current conflict on show in the Queensland election campaign?

—I will refer that question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs for his answer. I note that it is in line with a number of similar issues that have been pursued by the honourable senator in recent years along the lines of the prevalence of nepotism and undue influence alleged to occur within the Department of Foreign Affairs. Full and proper investigations, to use the language of the honourable senator, have been carried out in response to earlier allegations of that kind. No doubt they will be conducted in similar vein in response to this suggestion.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I hope he is as generous with information in response to my question as he was to Senator Archer. Does the Minister know that discussions between the Australian and South Korean governments concerning uranium shipments have been resumed? Is it a fact that these talks were previously delayed because the Government was unable to brief departmental officers on the policy to be implemented? Is he aware of a lunchtime report, I believe by the Macquarie Broadcasting Network, that the Chairman of Energy Resources of Australia Ltd today told his annual general meeting that there had been encouraging indications of support from the Government towards the uranium industry throughout the policy review? Does this mean that the Government has determined its uranium policy? If not, how can it then be possible that talks at governmental level have now resumed between Australia and South Korea on Australian uranium exports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to be as generous with information to Senator Chipp as I was to Senator Archer, but I am unable to be so because, firstly, I did not hear the lunchtime report and, secondly, I did not know that talks had been resumed. I suppose, from my general background knowledge of the subject, that it is possible that talks have been resumed. It has long been a matter of public knowledge that the Minister for Trade, within whose area of responsibility administratively this question falls-I answer this question as Minister representing the Minister for Trade-some months ago, having previously cancelled the negotiating determinations issued to six companies by the previous Government, reissued negotiating determinations to two companies, one of which was Energy Resources of Australia Ltd. Given that general factual background, while I did not know that talks had been resumed it is not surprising or amazing that talks could have been resumed between ERA and South Korea.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not recall the final part of the question very clearly. Senator Chipp made some reference to whether this means that government policy has been determined, or words to that effect. No, government policy has not been determined. As I stated yesterday, I think, a variety of submissions relating to the uranium question is scheduled for consideration by Cabinet next week and, presumably, for consideration by the Parliamentary Labor Party in the following week. That is a scheduled timetable which neither I nor anybody else can guarantee will actually be met. For example, this week the consideration of the issue was necessarily postponed because of the illness of the Prime Minister. The present proposal by the Government is that it be considered by Cabinet next week and by the Parliamentary Labor Party the following week.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Arising out of the Minister's reference to the timetable, does it not seem rather queer that departmental officers have been given permission to resume talks before government policy has been determined?

—I am sorry; that was the last part of the question which I did not remember clearly. I had intended to say in my initial answer, in any case, that I will refer Senator Chipp's question to the Minister for Trade to see whether he has any additional information to provide. That request, of course, will include the matter which Senator Chipp raised in his supplementary question .

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate in his current role as Acting Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Did the Minister notice petitions from certain women golfers in Tasmania complaining about the Sex Discrimination Bill? Will the Minister explain how the Bill will handicap women golfers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will seek to explain how the Bill, as I understand it, will not handicap women golfers. Clause 23 of the Bill, which relates to clubs, does not impose any obligation on associate members to become full members. What it does say is that a club which has male full members and female associate members will not be able to refuse an application from a female associate to become a full member because she is female. Likewise, if a male wished to apply for assciate membership, his application could not be refused because he was male. Nothing in clause 23 prevents a mixed club from continuing to have categories of full and associate membership with differential fees and benefits, as long as both categories of membership are open to men and women equally.

ANSWER.PARA: I apologise for laughing in the course of the answer, Mr President, but the fact is that I was laughing not about the substance of the answer but about the many references in the answer, which I had prepared for me, to handicaps, clubs and full members.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the Senate Gallery of former Senator Neville Bonner. On behalf of all honourable senators, I extend to him a warm and friendly welcome on his return to Canberra.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy . I refer to the interdepartmental document on uranium requested by the Government and circulated only to the Labor Party Caucus. Why were the resources of the Public Service directed towards serving a purely party political purpose? Why did the Government determine that such information should be the preserve of the Labor Party alone and not made available for study and comment by the whole Parliament and the community?

—To the best of my knowledge, no interdepartmental committee report has been circulated to members of Caucus. Certainly no IDC report has been circulated to members of Caucus by me. I will check with other Ministers, including the Prime Minister, to see whether any other Minister has circulated a copy of that IDC report.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy . It refers to an interview conducted on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio program AM on 18 October, in which Dr John Coulter, senior member of the Australian Conservation Foundation, in discussing the synroc method of storing radioactive waste, stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Before one puts waste into Synroc, one has to put it through a reprocessing plant . . . this is a necessary precondition for the incorporation of waste into Synroc.

Is reprocessing necessary for the incorporation of nuclear waste into synroc? Is it true that plutonium is isolated during this process? Is laser technology available which could be used to convert this plutonium to weapons grade plutonium?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not familiar with the statements by Dr Coulter to which Senator Childs refers. It is obviously a technical question which I do not feel technically qualified or competent to answer. However, I will give some response in very general terms and supply Senator Childs with a more detailed and definitive statement from people who are technically competent to answer such a technical question.
—And all other senators, please. Will you circulate it to the whole Senate?

—All right. I will have it put into Hansard as a supplementary answer, if honourable senators wish. As I understand it, some reprocessing is required for the incorporation of long lived waste into synroc. I do not know whether plutonium is actually isolated by that reprocessing, but I would expect that plutonium would be one of the long lived components which would, in the reprocessing, be taken out with the intention of incorporating it into synroc for long term storage, because it is a long lived radioactive material. I repeat that I will seek from the proper authority-pretty obviously, I suppose, that is the Australian Atomic Energy Commission-a technically qualified answer to Senator Childs's question and have it incorporated in Hansard, as has been done by me in the past, I think, and certainly by other Ministers.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. It is in three parts. First, does Senator Walsh agree that a major benefit for companies of his proposed resource rent tax is that during economic downturns, or other times during which company profits are falling, the tax collected will fall much more than under the present system? Secondly, does he agree that this would mean that the revenue flows to government from such a tax would be much more uneven than under the present system? Thirdly, how does the Minister envisage that this uneven revenue flow will be dealt with by the States , especially in view of the fact that the time when they will need the revenue most will be the very time when it is likely to drop off most sharply?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Baume has drawn attention to some quite valid points, in my view. He is, of course, correct in assuming that a resources rent tax or, indeed, any tax related to profits necessarily at a time of industry slump and low profits reduces the revenue payable to governments, as against a tax related to production. That applies whether the government is State or Federal. That can be seen as a problem, although I believe that there are ways of dealing with it and I shall come to them shortly. But it ought to be noted that it is a benefit for the industries concerned that they not be overtaxed in periods of depressed prices and/or depressed sales. Of course, with a tax related to profits, instead of to production, applied to a cyclical industry such as the mining industry, there will be more variations in revenue than there have been in the past.

ANSWER.PARA: That brings us to Senator Baume's third point-the question of such a tax being applied by the States. However, before dealing with that, let me say, on the basis that it was a Commonwealth tax, that Commonwealth taxation or revenue is subject to wide fluctuations because of general economic conditions. For example , I think that a one per cent increase in gross domestic product, all other things being equal, induces about an extra $400m in Commonwealth personal income tax. It is a figure something like that, anyway. So, within the Commonwealth revenue base there is already the potential for and the actuality of major fluctuations, with which Commonwealth governments cope by varying the size of deficits or surpluses.

With the States it is not so simple, because by and large State governments do not have the capacity to run Budget deficits-or certainly not substantial Budget deficits. To that extent, I acknowledge the validity of Senator Baume's question . However, I do not believe that the problem is unsurmountable. If a State government were imposing a profit related tax or a resource rent tax, it could make a fairly reliable estimate of the average sustainable yield from such a tax and, if it chose to do so, it could pay revenue into a trust account in years when the yield from the tax was above normal and withdraw it in years when the revenue was below normal. That is something that State governments could do. As to whether they would actually do it, I think I sense a cynical response from Senator Withers. I find that the cynicism of Senator Withers is often compatible with the real world. What States might be more likely to do is to take all the revenue in the high income years and expect the Commonwealth Government to fill the revenue gaps in the low income years. I suspect that Senator Withers would share my view on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It refers to the recent warnings by the Secretary-General of the United Nations that new computerised weaponry systems in outer space could eventually escape political control altogether. Can the Minister advise what action Australia will be taking when disarmament issues are raised in the General Assembly of the United Nations? Can we anticipate the Minister for Foreign Affairs making a statement on Australia's role in view of the increasing community concern for international peace and order?

—I am indebted to the honourable senator for his question without notice, and I will refer it to the Minister for Foreign Affairs for a detailed reply. I simply draw to the honourable senator's attention the fact that we now have an ambassador with particular responsibilities for disarmament in the United Nations, and we would expect, as a result of that, to adopt a very much higher profile, both in policy terms and in the vigour with which we express our point of view, than has been the case in the past. As to the particular matters raised by the Secretary-General with respect to weaponry in outer space and the other matters of detail raised by the honourable senator, I will seek an early reply for him.
—My question is addressed to Senator Grimes in his capacity as Minister representing Senator Gietzelt who represents the Minister for Transport .
—Say it slowly.
—Senator Grimes will probably be more au fait with the answer that I am seeking than Senator Gietzelt.
—That is a terrible reflection.
—No, it is--
—Order! Will the honourable senator please ask her question?
—Mr President, those honourable senators who interject will understand when I say--
—Order! I ask the honourable senator to ignore interjections. I remind her that this is Question Time.

—Is the Minister aware that the Tasmanian Government and the Australian National Line agree that there is a need for a second Bass Strait ferry to service Tasmania during the height of the tourist season?
—That is not true.

—The honourable senator should read the Australian Financial Review. Is the Minister further aware that importation of this ferry requires the permission of the Federal Minister for Transport? Is it a fact that the maritime unions will not agree to the importation of the ferry this season because they insist on 100 per cent Australian crewing which, from a time point of view, is now impossible? Finally, will the Government act in Tasmania's interests and allow importation of this second ferry, the charter of which is essential by mid-November?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware that there has been some controversy in Tasmania about the Tasmanian Government's proposal to import a second ferry to carry passengers across Bass Strait in the Christmas season. I certainly do not agree with Senator Walters that the Australian National Line agreed, in the way she says, that it was desirable to import such a ferry in the way the Tasmanian Government wanted to import it. I am also equally aware, as is every other Tasmanian member on both sides of the Senate and in the other place, that what the Tasmanian Government was about, in the lateness of its application and in the delay in replying to the questions put to it by the Federal Minister for Transport, was in fact a political stunt.

ANSWER.PARA: The proposal put by the Tasmanian Government involved a foreign vessel, crewed by foreign nationals, operating in Australian waters. The Commonwealth and the Federal Minister were ready to give sympathetic consideration to the Tasmanian proposal, subject to the Tasmanian Government being able to give the Federal Transport Minister assurances, as required by the Navigation Act, that the requirements of the Act would be met. It is my understanding that the Tasmanian Minister for Transport has advised the Federal Minister that, because of the limited time available to settle the necessary arrangements, including negotiations with relevant maritime unions, and for the selection of a suitable vessel, the Tasmanian Government will not be pursuing the matter at this time. That was not the decision of the Federal Minister for Transport. That was the decision of the Tasmanian Minister for Transport and the Tasmanian Government. He knew and it knew that they put up this proposal too late.

Another question that was raised was a request by the Tasmanian Premier for Commonwealth financial assistance to put this ferry on the run. That needs to be seen in the light of the very generous assistance already given to Tasmania in general funds and also in terms of the subsidy that is already provided for the ferry service across Bass Strait.

TALK.START.PARA: —More than $3m.

—It is $3m now. The estimate for the importation of a new ferry was anything from $3m to $10m. In fact, many of us recognise the need for increased capacity for the transport of passengers across Bass Strait. Many of us recognise that this facility should be introduced with co-operation between the Commonwealth Government and the State Governments so that the people of Tasmania get the increased capacity that they need, at a reasonable cost. We have had a request at the last moment for the importation of a ferry to operate for a few months, when it was known quite well that it would be very hard to meet the requirements of the Navigation Act and that there would be difficulties between the ANL, the new carrier and, understandably, the unions. I think it is a pity that a stunt like this is put up without the Tasmanian Government sitting down and having a sensible discussion with the Commonwealth Government about it.

ANSWER.PARA: I repeat: At no time did Mr Morris, the Federal Minister for Transport, put any objections in the way. He merely said that such a ferry would have to meet the requirements of the Navigation Act and that there were no Federal funds available. That was perfectly reasonable. As soon as he did that, the Tasmanian Government pulled out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Peter Rae would never ask for that.

—I make a final response. It is prompted by an interjection from Senator Tate who, along with Senator Rae and me, was a member of the Senate Select Committee on Passenger Fares and Services to and from Tasmania. If Senator Rae were here, one would be interested to hear his response to such a proposal, knowing his views on this subject.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of Senator Grimes's statement that the State Government delayed and had made last minute requests, I ask: Why has the Prime Minister not answered officially the letter sent to him on 5 August, nearly three months ago, by the State Government regarding the second ferry for the Bass Strait crossing?

—I do not know the exact nature of the letter of 5 August but I would be very surprised if the Prime Minister had not answered that, as he promptly answers all other letters from Mr Gray. All I know is that there was a letter written by the Federal Minister for Transport-I will not necessarily be held to the exact date-on about 14 September asking for details from the Tasmanian Government about its proposal for a second ferry and that letter had not been replied to up to a few days ago. However, I will get the details of that for Senator Walters.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TWIN CITY RELATIONSHIPS WITH SOUTH AFRICA

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware that the shire of Wanneroo in Western Australia has recently adopted a motion in favour of having a twin city relationship with Durban in South Africa? What is the attitude of the Australian Government to such ties in the light of the appalling human rights record of South Africa and the disfranchisement of the majority of the population of that country?

—The short answer is: Not very warm. It is true that the matter of twin city relations is essentially a question for the local government authority involved. But it must be said that the establishment of a close relationship between an Australian city and a South African city is utterly out of keeping with the general tenor of the Australian Government's relations with South Africa which are of a kind that has been described by me in terms that have been less than kind and equally by Mr Hayden in recent times in this Parliament. The municipal authorities in South African cities such as Durban are , of course, representative of the white population only. Under those circumstances, while it is a matter for the local goverment authority concerned- there can be no question of any formal Federal intervention in a matter of this kind-it would appear to be wholly inappropriate for any civilised Australian town or city to enter into such a relationship with a South African purported counterpart.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer . Is it a fact that, as stated by the Treasurer this morning, the loss of revenue in this financial year, due to the defeat of the tax legislation last night, is an estimated $60m? Is it also a fact that estimates of gross domestic product growth have been revised upwards since the Budget and that greater economic growth could quite easily offset revenue losses of that magnitude?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is correct that, had that Bill not been defeated in the Senate last night at the second reading stage by the defenders of tax cheats, $60m would have been collected in this financial year pursuant to passage of that Bill, and ultimately $270m. As to the second part of the question-is the likely increase in gross domestic product which has occurred since the Budget was formulated likely to offset revenue losses of that magnitude-I could not be precise. Over the last six-month period the most significant additional increase in anticipated real GDP growth has come from the agricultural sector and the revenue--
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I have been advised that Senator Walsh mentioned something about people supporting tax cheats.
—No, defenders of tax cheats.
—Oh, defenders of tax cheats. I was asleep at the time. I take exception to that, Mr President, and I ask you to rule the Minister out of order .

—Mr President, I rise on the same point of order. I was intending to do so, but I was waiting for the answer to be given. In fact, the words used were that the legislation was defeated in this House last night by the defenders of tax cheats. That is completely offensive to all honourable senators. I take offence at it and I ask that it be withdrawn.

—Order! I am sorry, if the honourable senator did utter those words, that I missed them. If he did utter those words I would tend to think that they were a reflection on a vote of the Senate, and I ask him to withdraw them.
—Very well, Mr President, I withdraw. I note that a couple of people believe that they have a head that fits the size of the cap.
—Mr President, I take a point of order. We asked for an unqualified withdrawal and the Minister is now adding insult to his original objectionable statement.

—I rise on the point of order, Mr President. We really are getting to a ridiculous state in this chamber, I suggest, when someone with the record of Senator Sir John Carrick, who so often stood up in this place and blackguarded senators opposite-and consistently did so-gets so sensitive in opposition that he wishes to destroy Question Time in this way. I think Senator Sir John Carrick should remember Mr Truman's dictum about the heat in the kitchen and perhaps cop the fact that he is now sitting where he is and that he is sitting there because of the behaviour he indulged in when he was in government before.

—I rise on the point of order, Mr President. The practice of making the contemptuous withdrawal is one which mercifully has been reduced in this place. When withdrawals are made in terms which indicate that the withdrawal is reluctant and then the comments are reasserted, I believe that the spirit of the Standing Orders is being flouted. I believe that the second point of order taken by Senator Sir John Carrick should be upheld.
—I think that the comment of the Minister was made after the withdrawal had been made and was quite separate. However, I ask him to be temperate in his reply and to restrict it to the question.
—I just note for the record that, when Senator Harradine woke up, someone apparently told him what I had said. I mean that quite literally.
—Order! The Minister will answer the question asked by the Leader of the Opposition.

—Thanks to the disruption by Senator Harradine after he woke up, Mr President, I am not quite sure where I was in answering the question. I think I was making the point that additional growth in the farm sector, though it ultimately boosts government revenue, tends to do so in the year following that in which the additional growth takes place. It is quite conceivable, however, that, independently of the farm sector, revenue from other sources could offset that $60m in the present financial year. There has been, however, a number of areas in which there have been some increments in expenditure above those which had been planned in the Budget. I cannot remember how many but I can recall at least five or six areas in which that has happened. There is nothing unusual about that; it has happened under previous governments and will happen under future governments.

ANSWER.PARA: Regardless of all that, the final point still stands. Governments make judgments about the revenue they can get, the expenditure they should make, and what deficit or-something that used to be occasionally seen but has not been for some time-what surplus they should budget for. Irrespective of whatever changes in the growth estimates may have occurred since the Budget or in the last six months, the fact remains that because the Senate last night rejected that legislation which was to collect $270m-

TALK.START.PARA: —Steal it.

—Senator Archer says 'steal'. What the legislation sought to recover was the personal income tax which had been evaded under circumstances, that is wet Slutzkins, which Senator Archer's Deputy Leader described on 21 October last year as 'tax legally payable, the payment of which has been illegally evaded'. If Senator Archer believes that the legislation sought to steal money, he had better take the matter up with the former Treasurer, the present Deputy Leader of his Party.

ANSWER.PARA: Following that diversion, let me say that, regardless of what changes might have taken place in estimates of growth and their effects on government revenue in this or subsequent financial years, the fact remains that, because the actions of the Senate deprived the Government of $270m in revenue, at some time in the future the Government will have either to cut expenditure by a commensurate amount or to impose additional taxes equal to that amount on people who did not participate in wet Slutzkin schemes, who did not benefit from wet Slutzkin schemes and who were not the principal agents in setting up wet Slutzkin schemes, as is the shadow Minister for Finance--

TALK.START.PARA: —You were not even game to have an inquiry. It could be still alive. What are you talking about?
—One or both of those things will have to be done. Senator Harradine now chooses to interject.
—Order! Will the Minister please restrict his remarks to the question asked by the Leader of the Opposition and ignore the interjections.

—It would be easier, Mr President, if you could send Senator Harradine back to sleep; but, as always, I will follow your directive. The Government will have to recover the money from honest taxpayers who neither benefited from nor set up wet Slutzkin schemes-those who did were illegally evading taxation in the process, according to the present Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party-or it will have to reduce expenditure or increase the Budget deficit either this year or in future years. Conceivably, the Government may have to adopt a mixture of those three things.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it not a fact that this Government has, by its own voluntary act, reduced revenue by making changes to its Budget by amounts well in excess of the $60m? Is it not a fact that the same moneys will have to be made up by the same honest taxpayers to whom the Minister is referring? Is it not a fact that in September this year he passed off that question by saying that the money would be quite easily made up from economic growth?
—For this financial year only-of course, the tax legislation rejected by the Senate last night has much heavier implications for the next financial year-the adjustment made to the excise--
—What about the continuing effect of the excise changes? Don't talk nonsense.

—I am coming to that. The adjustment made to the excise resulted in an estimated loss to revenue of comparable magnitude. In answering Senator Chaney's initial question, I said that independently of the farm sector growth I believed that increased revenue, because of revised estimates of economic growth in general, would offset the $60m in this financial year. I do not, however, accept the implication of Senator Chaney's question concerning the remission for legitimate industry of payment of excise on fuel oil and the reduction in that excise from almost 9c a litre to 1.8c a litre; that is, in round terms, a reduction from 9c a litre to 2c a litre. I do not accept the implication of Senator Chaney's question that the justification for doing that-that is, deciding not to impose a very substantial tax on legitimate industry-is in any way comparable to a decision to free from their taxation obligations people who have participated in and benefited from wet Slutzkin schemes and have thereby, according to the present Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party and former Treasurer , illegally evaded taxation. I do not believe that the moral, economic or any other justification for those two actions is in any way comparable.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I ask the Minister: Is he aware of the scare election tactics of the Queensland Premier who is claiming that all pensioners over 70 years of age are threatened with the loss of the pension? I further ask the Minister whether he can inform the Senate how many elderly pensioners in Queensland will be affected by those pension changes. Can he also inform the Senate whether the aged Premier of Queensland, who is in this age bracket, stands to lose his claim to the over-70 pension and whether this pending loss is therefore the basis of his concern?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answering the last part of Senator Jones's question first, I certainly do not know whether the Premier of Queensland, who according to the records would qualify for an over-70 pension, has ever applied for one. Nor do I wish to know and nor will I seek to know. I have a very firm respect for the confidentiality provisions of the Social Services Act. Nor would I expect that he would apply for a pension in view of the denigrating remarks he has made about pensioners, beneficiaries and welfare recipients in the past. However, after hearing this morning the comments of Mr Bingham, the Deputy Premier of Tasmania, who at the same time as his Leader was in Queensland supporting the National Party described National Party members as a bunch of self-seeking crooks out to promote their own miserable ends, I must say that that creates--
—Who said that?
—Mr Bingham made that statement. I must say that that creates some difficulties.
—He was thinking of New South Wales.

—He is your Deputy Leader, ma'am, and he said it. All I know is that certainly under the new income test, which I put to honourable senators is a very generous income test, some pension will still be payable to single people with an income up to a total of $303 a week, and to couples with an income up to $500 a week. I think it is important to remember that under the new income test the Premier of Queensland, on his salary, will not qualify. I suggest that most people in this country would suggest that he should not qualify. I put it to those honourable senators opposite who make comments about this that, if they are to come into this place and vote to cut the revenue by $270m by supporting those who would evade taxation, if they are then to come into this place and suggest that the over-70 pension is unfair and cut the revenue by another $170m, if they also come into this place and say that we should not introduce changes to the taxation on lump sum superannuation, again cutting the revenue by several hundred million dollars, and if they come into this place and say that we should not have an assets test, which would again cut the revenue by another $200m, they should tell us where the revenue is supposed to come from. If they are going to support tax cheats and elderly Premiers of outlying States who wish to receive the over-70 pension, they have to tell us how we are going to support the people who really need support-that is, people without any extra income, people who do not own their own homes and people who through no fault of their own need an adequate pension. That has been the cry of reasonable people on both sides of this House for a long time.

ANSWER.PARA: Pensioners in Queensland who will be affected by the changes to the over-70 pension number in the low thousands-that includes those who will lose the total pension and those who will lose a part of their pension-out of a total age pensioner population in Queensland of 218,000. I think it is deplorable that the Premier of Queensland, with his wealth and with his income, should indulge in scare tactics like this to try to frighten the 70-year-olds, or any age pensioners in Queensland, when this Government is about providing an adequate redistribution of funds so that those who are in most need can get the help they need. I think Mr Bingham's words are very appropriate. I just think it is surprising that Mr Bingham has uttered those words when his own Premier is in Queensland, hand in hand with the Queensland Premier and the National Party people of whom Mr Bingham is so critical.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters. Is the Minister aware of an advertisement which appeared in the Adelaide Advertiser-and presumably in newspapers in other States, including Victoria-on 1 October inviting applications from 'suitably qualified persons who wish to contest' the selection test for permanent appointment to the position of Clerk Class 1? I ask the Minister whether he is aware of the fact that the advertisement concluded with the statement:

QUESTION.PARA: Permits to sit for the test may be collected from the inquiries counter of the office of the Australian Public Service Board-
the advertisement then gives the address in Adelaide-
between 8.30 a.m. and 4.45 p.m. on Monday, 3rd October or Tuesday, 4th October 1983. Permits will only be issued on these two days. Applications will not be accepted in writing or by telephone.
I ask the Minister whether he believes that this last paragraph of the advertisement contradicts in any way the preceding paragraph, which says, inter alia:
The Australian Public Service is an equal employment opportunity employer.

Can the Minister also say whether or not he believes that the short notice given -that is two days- for people to collect permits and the fact that they had to be collected in person discriminated against the many school leavers who live in rural areas and who might want a career in the Public Service but who are unable to go to Adelaide, or to the capital cities in the other States, to collect the necessary permits? What action will the Minister take to ensure that young people in Australia who are already disadvantaged by the distance they live from capital cities are not further disadvantaged by application conditions such as that included in this advertisement?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Haines asks me whether I am aware of a number of matters. I seek, subject to the limitations from which I suffer, to be aware at all times , but I am certainly not aware of all the matters in her question; nor am I prepared to provide an instant analysis of the content of the advertisement in question without careful consideration.
—Go on; have a go.

—I am going to. Senator Haines has asked whether I think parts of that advertisement are discriminatory against certain people. It sounds highly likely to me, on the basis of what she read. She asks me what action I propose to take. I will refer the matter to the Minister and ask him to give her a thorough answer.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does the Minister have the latest information on unfilled job vacancies in Australia? Have changes in the number of job vacancies been uniform between the States over the past 12 months? How do changes in job vacancies in South Australia compare with the general trend?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Regrettably, the latest statistics available, for the 12 months ended August 1983, which reflect changes on the August 1982 figures-in other words, they are figures on the 12-month changes-show that over that period there has been a 22 per cent national decline in the number of job vacancies. It is a matter of great regret to the Government that, nationally, only 17,000 vacant jobs are recorded. Senator Maguire also asked me whether that decline had been uniformly distributed between the States. The answer is no; it has not been uniformly distributed. In the State of Queensland, for example, the decline in the number of jobs available over the same period has been 58 per cent. Fewer than half the jobs available in Queensland, in absolute numbers, 12 months ago are available now. In Queensland, there are 1,300 job vacancies. So if one lives in Queensland and is unemployed, under the present State Government, one has about a one in 84 chance of finding a job. In South Australia the change in the 12 months-I am sure that this will give Senator Maguire some satisfaction-is significantly better than the change nationally. The number of jobs available increased by 10 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: The unemployment rate, measured by the number of applications for jobs as against the job vacancies, on a regional basis, in a number of areas in Queensland is absolutely staggering. For example, in Cleveland there are 78 applicants for every available job. In Chermside the figure is 70, in round terms; in Annerley, 76; in Alderley, 62; and in Redcliffe, 67. In Queensland as a whole the figure is 52. It is 67 in Cairns, 52 in Charleville and so on.

Those figures reflect both the extremely high rate of unemployment currently prevailing in Queensland and, even more so, the way in which the Queensland economy has collapsed, relative to the rest of Australia, over the last 12 months. The traditional excuse used by Queensland for having a high unemployment ratio from time to time-that people were moving up there from the south-does not account for the changes which have taken place in the last 12 months.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier at Question Time Senator Childs asked me a question. I am afraid that if I have more than three pieces of paper in front of me I am likely to mislay one of them. Since I answered the question I noticed that I have a note from the Department of Resources and Energy on the subject of synroc. At the time I answered the question I was not aware of the note. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the text of that briefing note from the Department. If there is anything further to add in reply to Senator Childs's question, I will have it incorporated in Hansard at some later date.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The note read as follows-
SYNROC
The unwanted products of the nuclear fuel cycle can be immobilised by incorporating them in SYNROC and without having to put spent nuclear fuel through a full reprocessing operation

in a paper delivered at an IAEA Conference in May 1983, Reeve and Ringwood noted that a new SYNROC formulation (SYNROC F) is designed to immobilise dissolved but otherwise unreprocessed spent commercial reactor fuel.
the AAEC is currently testing the capability of SYNROC in immobilising plutonium
all of the plutonium in spent fuel would be disposed of as waste if spent fuel was placed directly in SYNROC F.

The Government understands that claims have been made in the US that laser technology offers a possible process for the upgrading of plutonium from nuclear reactors. The Government however has no information which would enable it to assess the practicability of these claims.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the fourth report of the Standing Committee on Publications.

SPEECH.PARA: Report-by leave-adopted.

Annual Report 1982-83

That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few very brief comments about the report of the Special Prosecutor which I have not had the opportunity to read in detail. The conclusion which I draw out of it is that whilst Mr Redlich is of the view that a more robust approach by the national government to the question of setting up some sort of agency to deal with sophisticated organised crime would be a worthwhile matter to pursue, the fact is that he also identifies how both private and public institutions of great importance within Australian society have been manipulated with almost the connivance of those in charge of those institutions. The Age of Thursday, 13 October, under the heading 'Banks rapped over tax-rort accounts', summarised part of Mr Redlich's report. The article stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it was scandalous that at least one of Australia's biggest banks had sanctioned a system of using bank facilitates for 'round-robin' accounts to avoid taxation.
The article continued:
. . . . like the round-robin of accounts, the opening of false bank accounts resulted in higher daily balances for a bank branch.

That is why those activities were connived at by branch managers. There is no doubt that those involved in those banks could have made a reasonable assumption that their system was being abused and misused for the purpose of some sort of tax fraud or some, worse, laundering of ill-gotten gains. Here we had an instance of a private institution, for its own ends, conniving at that arrangement. In relation to public institutions, Mr Redlich referred to Telecom Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you suggest the bank managers could have done?

—I am suggesting that the bank managers and the boards of the banks , which must have been aware of this practice at various branches, should have taken steps to ensure that accounts were not opened in false names and that the authorities which might have an interest in those transactions which bore no relation to ordinary commercial need were alerted, whether they be taxation authorities or others. I am suggesting that the matter of private institutions needs to be looked at. In relation to public institutions, such as Telecom, Mr Redlich suggested that there has not been proper co-operation by Telecom management with the police looking into, for example, SP bookie operations. The real point I want to make is that in relation to public institutions, departments and so on, Mr Redlich made the point that such departments and public agencies operate in fear of trespassing upon the jurisdiction of others. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: They jealously guard their own territory. They frequently lack the basic resources to enable them to discharge their duties effectively, and there is often a division of responsibility which works against efficiency.

He was talking about keeping one's turf sacrosanct, not divulging to others what might be amiss and indeed concentrating too much on the regulatory and the ordinary carrying-out of procedures of the department rather than investigating hints of criminal activity which might be going on. There is not only straight- out corruption within some of these agencies and departments but also there is a lack of administrative supervision and robust guidance of these authorities by those responsible for them.

The point of my remarks is that I believe that it would be a mistake for this Parliament to put too much weight on expectations relating to the creation, if it is to go ahead, of a National Crimes Authority; that indeed there are other matters within our grasp as legislators, as creators of government and as administrators of departments and public agencies, which we need to deal with. It would be far better if some of our colleagues in these States got on with the job of dealing with the semi-criminal sub-culture in which marihuana is made available. This would be a very important step in dealing with organised crime in Australia. All we are doing by keeping it as a criminal activity is ensuring a cash flow to these criminal syndicates for their more nefarious activities.

In relation to the administration of departments, it is extremely important that Ministers and those in charge of public authorities read Mr Redlich's report-it is an excellent report in this regard-and take to heart his injunctions and warnings about the need not to be so concerned about the sacredness of one's own turf but to pursue and to enable others to pursue hints and instances of criminal activity or manipulation of the department's procedures for criminal or fraudulent purposes.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report and Ministerial Statement
Debate resumed from 18 October 1983, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Senate take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report is a very important one . The recommendations made by the Commonwealth Schools Commission will form the basis on which the Government will prepare the States Grants (Schools) Bill which will come before the Parliament for determination some time in the next month or two. On Tuesday I spoke briefly on a couple of features of this report. Today I want to talk about two other features only.

SPEECH.PARA: The first concerns the computer education program and the comments by the Commonwealth Schools Commission upon the Government's directions to it in relation to such a program. First, I remind the Senate that the Commonwealth Schools Commission drew attention last year to the need for a computer education program. The Commission, on that occasion, gave some indication of what that program might contain and the amount of resources which it would require. I seem to remember that the Commission called for the commitment of $125m over five years. If that is not correct, it is almost correct. I remind the Senate, as well, that before the last election, picking up that recommendation and working to the capacity of government to respond to it, the Liberal and National parties promised the electorate that we would spend $20m a year for five years-that is, $100m-on computer education. I will talk in a moment about what a desirable content might be.

The Australian Labor Party Government promised much less. It promised only $25m towards computer education in spite of the fact that that would be inadequate, in the best judgment of the Commonealth Schools Commission, to provide an adequate degree of preparation for Australian schools and Australian teachers for what was needed. The irony is that the Government, in bringing down its education guidelines, has not even stuck to that $25m program. It has now reduced that to an $18m program over three years. Instead of its promise to provide $8m in the first year-another promise broken, another promise dishonoured-it has now offered $6m. In terms of what the Commonwealth Schools Commission indicated was necessary, that is an amount which is totally inadequate.

The tasks that need to be fulfilled by a computer education program include computer awareness, making people comfortable with the idea of computers and working with them, the pre-service preparation of teachers, the in-service preparation of those who have been teaching, the provision of computer hardware and the preparation and distribution of computer software programs. Without all those features, there will not be an integrated program. One of the worries of educators has been that the mere provision of computers in schools without the preparation of software or without the assistance given to teachers will lead to machines sitting in corners gathering dust with no one trained to use them or no one confident enough to get the best educational use from them. It is a great pity that the Schools Commission now has to work to such a small program.

The only other point I make is that within two of the programs there is a grossly inequitable distribution between government and non-government schools in their shares of the program. I remind the Senate that there are roughly three times as many children in government schools as there are in non-government schools. One would expect that the funds for some of these important programs would be distributed roughly on a three to one basis. The participation and equity program, the centrepiece of the Government's program, gives only about 11 per cent of the funds, only about $1 to $9, to non-government schools-$4.3m as against $38.4m. I do not know how that will produce participation and equity in the poor Catholic schools. That is where six out of seven non-government school children are. Only about 17 per cent of the funds allocated to the computer program are going to the non-government school system. So there is some cause for concern, ahead of the presentation of the States Grants (Schools) Bill, as to the equity issues which lie behind the distribution of funds as between government and non-government schools and which go as well to the adequacy of the amounts of money that have been provided especially for the computer education program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to comment upon appendix B of the report of the Commonwealth Schools Commission. Appendix B is headed 'Summary of Commission Recommendations for 1984 and Government Responses' . There are 57 Commission recommendations. Honourable senators know that when the Fraser Government introduced guidelines to the Commission, the Australian Labor Party made one invariable response. In the first place, it said that guidelines were wrong and that, in fact, the Commission should be given a free hand. It said that guidelines were restrictive and said that the reports of the Commission should be adopted.
—No, the third bit is not quite correct. That is your version.

—Let me just take up the comment that I am not quite correct. Let us have a little look at that situation. Time after time Hansard shows criticism of the former Government's guidelines. The criticism stated, at the very least, that the guidelines shackled the Commission, they were too restrictive and the Commission's recommendations should be substantially adopted . Does Senator Button agree?
—No. You are qualifying it again.

—I am not qualifying it at all. I am endeavouring to help the Minister because he needs help. I want to give him the result of this situation. There are some 57 recommendations of the Schools Commission. Indeed, it was the advice of this body which the Labor Party said should be taken by governments. Is that modifying it? There is silence from the other side now. The Labor Party said that the advice of this body should be heeded and substantially adopted. What did it do? Let us have a look because the Minister now realises the situation. Fifty-seven recommendations have been listed. Of those 57 recommendations nine were rejected. That word is not mine. The word 'rejected' appears against nine recommendations in that list. Alongside 12 of the recommendations are the two words 'no response'. Nine have been rejected and 12 received no response. Hear those words now that governments should pay attention to the Schools Commission and should heed its advice. Two recommendations have been reserved for funds review, three have been deferred and 11 have been modified. That is a little matter of 37 recommendations out of a total of 57 being either rejected out of hand or substantially modified. Alongside 20 out of 57-35 per cent of them-appears the word 'accepted'.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me put this situation at rest. I have stood in here repeatedly and heard the Labor Party argue against the restrictive nature of guidelines. Here is a classic situation. The Labor Party had its first opportunity in eight years to bring down guidelines. It brought down those guidelines. As a result, 65 per cent of the recommendations of the Schools Commission were either rejected out of hand or not dealt with. Twelve recommendations received no response. I remind the Senate that the honeyed words used by the Labor Party in opposition as to a line of pursuit are ashes now that it is in government. Once again the Labor Party is forcing its policies and, of course, all those words are forgotten. The Schools Commission in the past has been a very valuable instrumentality. Given independence, given a true representative nature-that is something the Labor Government does not understand-the Schools Commission is capable of bringing forward very valuable recommendations. I can only lament the fact that having brought down 57 recommendations, the great majority of them were either ignored or rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to only one aspect of the Commonwealth Schools Commission report in the five minutes that are available to me-the program in relation to participation and equity-and to highlight the problems that occur in schools and the fact that the concentration the previous Government has given to institutions ultimately will fail. I look at one group; I refer to children who come under the guardianship of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West), children who are not eligible for any government assistance to enable them to stay at school. By and large this group consists of, at the present time-this has changed over the years-refugees from South East Asia who have no parents in Australia and, indeed, many who have no adult relatives in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: A very significant number of them have inaccurate dates of birth on their entry papers and are unable to have this rectified. The problem that ensues from their not having any parents or relatives to support them and their inability to determine their correct age is that these children are often not old enough or alternatively too old to receive the appropriate assistance from the Department of Education, and are consequently forced to leave school. If they then receive the unemployment benefit they are able to live. But if they remained in school and in various educational programs it would obviously be beneficial for Australia in the long term and much more beneficial of course for the individuals involved. That problem does not rest only with the schools. It extends to colleges of technical and further education and to other tertiary institutions.

It would seem to be much more appropriate if those children who come under the guardianship of the Minister were more able to partake of schooling and hence to continue in what the Government has suggested is an equity and participation program. Really the only way that those problems can be picked up is by aiming programs at the individual children, not by aiming programs at the institutions. The problem that I have given an instance of is one of many which affect individuals who will fail to be catered for under the program that the Government has developed and for which it has received the support of the Schools Commission. I believe it is a blind spot in educational planning in this country that we have constantly funnelled money through that institutionalised support and have failed to look at broader social and equity policies that will eventually enable people to partake of the institutions which are established. Regardless of how well we finally staff, equip and build our institutions, ultimately that will have negligible effect on the social distribution of wealth in this country. The children of the poor will still be poor and the children of the rich will be well off. One has only to look at comparative educational policies throughout the world to discover that putting one's money into the institutionalised educational framework as a solution to fundamental social problems will not solve those problems inasmuch as the individuals do not have either the capacity or the wherewithal to partake of even the best educational facilities which the country is able to provide.

I suggest, therefore, if the Government is genuine in seeking a solution to these social problems, that it ceases to look through its educational structure to solve them, that it ceases to mount programs such as the one it is mounting here on participation and equity, and seeks rather to establish fundamental social reforms so that the children of the poor are eventually able to partake of the educational system that we have available. Essentially, of course, they are fundamental social policies which would support families and, for example, the children I have just mentioned who have no family structure. Support to the individual is far more important than the support to the institution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, at the risk of sounding tedious, I think it might be useful to remind the Opposition of the fact that the Australian Labor Party came to government with a quite stunning and extremely limiting deficit from which to attempt to make justifiable, sustainable decisions. One might be forgiven for being stuck for words after hearing once again from the Opposition about all the wonderful things that it promised to do for education, for social welfare and everything else it could possibly think of in this country. Yet, when we come to government facing an enormous deficit we are expected to work blooming wonders in the first seven months--
—Just keep your promises; that is all.

—Given time and with the will that we certainly have our promises will be kept. Within the community there is an understanding of the problem that we face, an understanding which the Opposition refuses to acknowledge. We are being strenuously criticised for the fact that in this first Budget we are allocating only $6m to computer education, of which $4.8m will go to government schools and $1.2m will go to non-government schools, a fair sort of ratio I would have thought in view of the fact that we will be adhering to our principle of the most needy schools, requiring the most help, receiving the most assistance. This and all the other programs are available not only to government schools but also to non-government schools throughout this nation. Provided they are registered by their State authorities all schools will be eligible for the funds that are being made available. The mere provision of computers is obviously not the solution to this problem. Over a period of years we just as obviously need to train people and to produce the software. We have to make sure that the hardware is available.

SPEECH.PARA: In this first Budget the amount of $6m is not only probably just as much as we can afford but also probably just as much as we can sensibly spend in the period . Over three years $18m will be provided. Because this is a major new program it is important not to rush its implementation. The computer education program is one of the programs on which the Commonwealth Schools Commission will shortly be presenting supplementary reports.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should have happened seven years ago, Senator. It is a tragedy.

—Of course, it should have, and it would have cost considerably less then I would have thought. Other criticisms that are being made of the difference between what is being made available for government and non- government systems I think should all be seen in the light of what we have referred to continually. That is the fact that the neediest schools will be getting the lion's share of the cake, rather than the money being spread thinly and evenly, which would be in every respect a most inequitable state of affairs. Of the recommendations that have been deferred, many are associated with ongoing reviews and programs which are still in the course of being planned. Once again I think it is quite unfair of the Opposition to expect us to believe all the wonderful things it would have done in the face of a deficit of $9.5 billion. We cannot ever get the proof of that, of course. It is very easy for them to talk. But I strongly believe, and people closely involved with both non-government and government education systems will agree with me, that there is a heck of a lot greater chance of equity and justice within the state school and the non- government school systems within the term of an Australian Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I would like to agree very strongly with Senator Macklin when he points to the inadequacies of institutional solutions to fundamental social problems and calls for fundamental social reforms. I should like to remind the Senate of the fact that to supplement our efforts in the course of developing youth policies the Labor Party has asked an Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development team to visit Australia. This team will be bringing experts to review our current policies and to provide assistance for planning for the future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report and Ministerial Statement
Debate resumed from 18 October 1983, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Senate take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to make a brief comment on the remarks of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission on the quality of access. We in the Australian Democrats are extremely pleased to see that the Commission will continue its work in this area. We note its particular emphasis on Aboriginal, migrant, low income groups, women and disabled people who continue to be under represented in our tertiary institutions and the endeavour that the Commission suggests that we need to make to advantage their access. In particular, I am deeply concerned that the Aboriginal people are still finding so many difficulties in gaining access to tertiary institutions and tertiary education. There is an urgent need that the Aboriginal peoples have people of their own race qualified in so many areas, particularly, at the moment, in the area of medicine. The problems that continue to occur in the area of Aboriginal health, I believe, will ultimately be solved only by the various Aboriginal health services having Aboriginal doctors who are able to integrate both traditional medicine and Western medicine.
