SPEECH.PARA: Another matter relates to the problems of the qualifications of Aboriginal people in the area of child care. There is at the moment some real pressure being put on a number of child care institutions to transfer their facilities to Aboriginal control. The Democrats support that, but much depends on the speed with which it is done. Very severe problems could arise because of the lack at the moment of suitably qualified Aboriginal child care people. I think that raises yet again the fact that in the past we have done so little to have suitably qualified people from the Aboriginal race in these areas.

I refer to another problem which has arisen in quite a number of institutions. This involves the over-emphasis which has been given to the leaving certificate or the higher school certificate or its equivalent in the various States. Many mature age students are seeking to enter into various faculties in tertiary institutions. I refer, in particular, to medical faculties. These students find that the qualifications they had when they left school are insufficient for them to gain entrance to schools of medicine, in particular around Australia, because of the very high pressure on those schools. Invariably, the advice has been given to them that they ought to go to one of the other faculties within the institution. For example, it is generally suggested that they undertake a general science degree, which many people do. Some have undertaken, for example, a degree in veterinary science, which has similar basic components. At a later stage these people have reapplied for entrance to medical school and more often than not they have again been knocked back on the basis that they still have, of course, as is inevitably the case, a low leaving certificate or higher school certificate score. What is not taken into account is the fact that these people are now mature age students. They have shown that they are able to partake of tertiary education, that they have the qualities to undertake the study at that level and, what is more, they have shown a remarkable determination to want to get into a medical school.

All studies have shown, without exception, that the mature age student is a better bet than anybody else for tertiary education. These students put their heads down and they get into their studies and they get through them in a minimum amount of time. It seems to me, particularly in the area of medicine which has such high pressure on entrants, that the people with those types of backgrounds, who are looking at going to medical school and who have attempted to go through all the proper steps ought to have a much better chance than they currently have of gaining admittance. The Federal Government, through its funding policies, has a great deal of control over what goes on at these institutions. I am not suggesting that it ought to dictate to the universities but I believe that a greater liberation of the ability for mature age students to enter into those medical faculties would certainly be to the benefit of this country.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STUDY OF LIVING AWAY FROM HOME FACILITIES FOR ISOLATED CHILDREN

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report
Debate resumed from 18 October 1983, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Senate take note of the paper.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.
Report 1983
Debate resumed from 18 October 1983, on motion by Senator Archer:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was speaking on this matter on 18 October and had almost drawn my remarks to a conclusion. I will conclude by saying that I urge that the industry should keep its discussions going and that it should always be ahead of the Government, and not waiting on government direction. Much in this report by the Industries Assistance Commission on the wheat industry leads me to believe that the industry will have to lead itself through the minefield that it is in.

SPEECH.PARA: Page 54 of the report discusses the wheat finance fund. Various alternatives for distributing the $100m or so that will be left in the fund when it is wound up were presented. Although it was suggested in one place that the fund could be used for industry management, I believe that this would not be fair to the growers over many years. I believe it should be returned to those who contributed to it. But of course I leave this in the hands of the industry to make that decision. Above all, the wheat growers must continue to demonstrate their efficiency. The Board must be seen to be as efficient as it is possible to be. It must be able to demonstrate that it is operating in the best interests of the growers and, of course, in the best interests of the country at large. I think the document is a valuable discussion piece. I hope that it is able to assist the industry in due course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Australian Democrats welcome the Industries Assistance Commission report which has already become an extremely controversial report within the wheat industry. I wish to draw attention to one item only which was dealt with in the report, that is, the monopoly that the Australian Wheat Board has on sales of wheat within Australia. This is an extremely important issue. It has relevance to many rural producers, especially given the fact that the principle raised here is one which becomes much more relevant in other areas of private production. The Australian Democrats believe that it is time to have a thorough investigation of the appropriateness of the orderly marketing arrangements within the rural industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bureau of Agricultural Economics, which recently conducted an experiment with the ORANI model, was referred to in the report. It was suggested that wheatgrowers were disadvantaged by the existing structure to the extent of $134. 62 a week for each grower. That is an extraordinary possibility. To be fair, of course, the Industries Assistance Commission queried the validity of that price. Nevertheless, a publication of the New South Wales Department of Agriculture suggests that out of an expected price of about $170 a tonne the Australian Wheat Board would be deducting a total of $49.50 in various costs and charges and that, by comparison, the farmers' costs for materials and machinery were budgeted at about $45 with further costs for depreciation, interest rates and overhead.

It is, of course, possible for a grower to sell his wheat legally. First of all he must have the approval of the Australian Wheat Board and, in practice, this is not often given except in certain circumstances. At a time of increasing costs to the person on the land, the Australian Democrats encourage the Government to look closely at the recommendation which says that private producers should be permitted to operate freely on the domestic market in competition with the Australian Wheat Board. Carrying on from this, we see a need to look constantly at the appropriateness of the form of orderly marketing used in rural industry so that the end result is a better deal for the producers rather than the collection of funds for administrative purposes, the collection of funds for bodies that tend to perpetuate themselves when they are not necessarily doing the best job possible for the producer.

One area in which the rural producer at the moment obviously has been disadvantaged by the Wheat Board is clearly set out at page 18 of the report. The report describes the Australian Wheat Board's policy concerning the sale of wheat for stock feed as the 'opportunity cost of diverting wheat from export markets to the domestic stock feed market'. The IAC appears to be saying that the Australian Wheat Board's determination to get the most dollars possible for its wheat could end up with the rural producer being worse off. This is an absurd situation. We believe that in any orderly arrangement for marketing of any rural product what always must be of paramount concern is that the producer gets the maximum return possible. In the past 10 years producers' costs have escalated beyond imagination and yet the return has decreased. We found in 1972 in most areas that those crossed over. Essentially what it means is that it becomes a disincentive to grow anything in this country because of escalating costs and diminishing returns. We suggest that this particular report ought to be looked at because, if there are ways in which the wheatgrowers can sell on the domestic market, particularly in the stock feed area, such action ought to be facilitated to enhance returns to the growers.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL REFORM

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 19 October 1983, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That the Senate take note of the report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That it is the view of the Senate-

(a) that decisions of the Commonwealth Parliament concerning financial support for government and non-government schools in recent years have been grossly misrepresented to the Public by the opponents of non-government schools; and

(b) that consideration should be given to Commonwealth grants to the States for schools being presented in a new and consistent way by providing for a basic per capita grant in respect of all schoolchildren, whether in government or non- government schools, and by providing for supplementary needs-based grants for schools incorporating the special and supplementary programs of the Schools Commission.

I gave notice of this motion on 21 April, the first sitting week of this Parliament. What stirred me to move it was the preceding election campaign. During the months of February and early March, the Australian Teachers Federation, in particular, various teacher unions and a number of other bodies directly opposed to Commonwealth or taxpayer funding to non-government schools placed advertisements in newspapers and on radio and television which misrepresented the taxpayers support for non-government schools. In brief, the accusation that was levelled by this partisan group was that government schools are suffering because money has been transferred by the Commonwealth Government away from those State schools and given to independent schools. They said that there was a trend throughout the Fraser government whereby more money was given increasingly to the independent schools and that had denied money to the Government schools. This was a gross misrepresentation of the state of public support for schools of all kinds in Australia. I believe that if we were to reorder the way in which Commonwealth money goes to the States and is distributed to the non-government and the government schools we would directly correct that abuse. Let me illustrate the point by referring to just one advertisement which appeared in the Sunday Mail in South Australia on 13 February. The advertisement was placed by the Australian Teachers Federation and was headed:
Our children need to win this election.
The article stated:
As a nation we've tried to offer the best possible education in our government schools. We've agreed that these schools should meet the needs of children and our community.
But the agreement is being torn apart.

At a time when the community faces alarming unemployment and technological change, work on national curriculum and research has been scrapped. In just seven years, $2500 million has been given to private schools at the expense of government schools.
I emphasise that claim again which I regard as a gross misrepresentation:
In just seven years, $2500 million has been given to private schools at the expense of government schools.

The allegation in the advertisement is that the youth unemployment which besets Australia is traceable to an imbalance now in the way in which governments provide funds to the schools. That imbalance arises because the previous Liberal and National Party Government in Canberra was taking money away from the state schools and giving it to the independent schools.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your Prime Minister used to say that unemployment was a direct consequence of the education system.

—No. Senator Button will remember that I stood apart from any such allegation. I was a signatory to a report entitled 'Preparation for the Workforce'. Senator Robertson and I were parties to bringing it before the Senate. I can attest to it as a subsequent Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts. In chapter 1 we placed the blame for unemployment on economic factors, not educational factors. Senator Button will remember, if he goes back in Hansard, that he even acknowledged that ' enlightened Senator Teague at least understands that'. Some people in Australia were alleging that educational factors were to blame. What I am saying is that this advertisement by a partisan group, supporting the Australian Labor Party, is implying that the unemployment outcome is arising because of the way in which education institutions have been funded, and it is deliberately there in the advertisement. It is a gross misrepresentation, equally as gross as the one to which reference has been made and which has said that in past years all of our unemployment problem is directly attributable to the teachers and to the lousy education system. I reject that assertion, and I reject the gross misrepresentation by the Australian Teachers Federation in this advertisement, and in advertisements on radio and television at the time. I continue to quote from the advertisement:

SPEECH.PARA: And in 1982 alone, disadvantaged government schools with 350,000 children received $24m-
only $24m-
while wealthy private schools with 127,000 children were allocated $50m.

That is a gross misrepresentation because already the children in those disadvantaged government schools, so-called, have received about $100m through taxpayer support, in addition to the primary recurrent help for those schools, which is substantial, at more than $2,000 per head. There is a supplementary small program, called the disadvantaged schools program, which happens to have $ 24m allocated to it. The advertisers have chosen, out of context, an amount of $ 50m, which happened to go only as a small part of the total program of cost for independent schools. So the advertisement continues:
These Fraser government policies have caused divisions in our community. Australian teachers believe we need to reverse these trends.

Why it was possible for these lobbies so grossly to misrepresent taxpayer support for Australian schools comes about through the indirect way that the Commonwealth Government makes provision for education in all of the schools in Australia. The Senate is well aware that the Commonwealth gives more than $4 billion in untied recurrent grants to the States. That is $4 billion and more going from the Commonwealth, united, to the State governments to distribute. That amount will more than pay for all of the State school programs in Australia . The direct educational spending of the Commonwealth Government that is channelled through programs of the Schools Commission is supplementary to that, and it is a gross misrepresentation of the Commonwealth's financial support for education if it is said that that is the only money that is going to schools, whether government or non-government.

I am seeking to find support in the Senate for the proposition that consideration be given to Commonwealth grants to the States being presented in a new and consistent way, in a way that incorporates the untied State grants that are then eventually spent on education and the direct Commonwealth grants that go to government and non-government schools alike through programs of the Schools Commission. I am urging that consideration be given to that. I am not saying that the proposal or the model that I am about to put forward is the one that must be followed. I am saying that because the situation has been so grossly misrepresented, not only in the last election campaign but in earlier years, the public has become confused about the source of direct support for schools. Some of it is coming from the States. Some of it comes from the Commonwealth. Even some of the State money is received from the Commonwealth. Then there are some fees coming from individual families as well. To put that all into a single perspective is very difficult because of the indirectness of some of the grants.

Attention has been drawn directly to this matter. It happened a few weeks after a Notice of Motion of mine in the Senate in April, when the Chairman of the Schools Commission, Dr Peter Tannock, delivered a paper in Perth to the conference of the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science on 17 May this year. I shall quote part of his paper. I commend all of it very much to the Senate. I regard all of it as an essential introduction to the matters that I shall be raising later in my speech today. Dr Tannock said:

It is the thesis of this paper that now, 10 years on from the Karmel Report, might be a good time to review the roles and financial responsibilities of Commonwealth and State governments in school level education.

He said that because of the enormous infusion of funds, during both the Whitlam Government period and the Fraser Government period, towards education in Australia, we have reached a situation in which there is a considerable imbalance in the funding responsibilities of the Commonwealth and State governments and there has also been the creation of some confusion about the basic purpose of Commonwealth allocations for schools, and of State allocations for non-government schools. Dr Tannock directly cites some of these imbalances in the following way: First, 24 per cent of Australia's school children attend independent schools; 76 per cent attend government schools. Of the more than $7, 000m that is spent from public funds, out of the taxpayers' pockets, on schools in Australia this year, 1983, $1.2 billion is provided by the Commonwealth and $ 5.8 billion is provided by the States. So the minority part is coming directly from the Commonwealth and the great majority is coming through the programs of the States. Coming to that smaller part coming from the Commonwealth, 58 per cent of it-that is, $562m-in terms of recurrent funds will go to non-government schools in 1983, and 42 per cent will be going to government schools.

That is the matter, that is the rub, that the opponents of the non-government schools have picked upon. They did not tell the public that only $1.2 billion out of $7 billion is coming in this form from the Commonwealth. Of that small part, the $1.2 billion, it happens that a majority is going to non-government schools. So they were able to put forth propaganda to say: 'A majority of financial support going to schools from the Commonwealth is going to non- government schools. It is going even to those wealthy schools that one sees around in the cities. What about the disadvantaged state schools that are getting only 42 per cent of all of the Commonwealth's direct spending on education?' That assertion neglects the fact that the lion's share of taxpayer support for government schools is coming from a different source. We could go on with such contrasts or notes of this imbalance.

In contrast to this breakdown of the Commonwealth program-58 per cent to 42 per cent-only 6 per cent of State education funding is going to non-government schools and 94 per cent, or $4,281m of State recurrent expenditure on schools, is going to government schools. The propagandists of the last election campaign did not refer to that at all. They did not say that, whilst there is this imbalance in the supplementary programs of the Commonwealth through the Schools Commission, there is at the same time an enormous imbalance in favour of government schools in funding by State governments. It is my contention that we will overcome the potential for such misrepresentation only if we put all of the programs together and present them to the public within one perspective.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you ever stop?

—Senator Grimes has just come into the chamber. He was delighted by my speeches on education matters yesterday and this morning. I promise that what I am saying now is new and reinforcing. I am, indeed, putting forward a solution to some of the problems that I was referring to this morning and yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me put this matter into yet another perspective. Over the last six years taxpayers' support for children in non-government schools has been in direct proportion to the cost of providing a state school place. Therefore, the taxpayer provides 100 per cent of the cost of a state school place for 76 per cent of children who attend state schools. However, the taxpayer provides up to about 50 per cent of the cost of a non-government school place. There has been a tied percentage in the proportion of support for non-government schools relative to government schools. This has led to a trend over the last few years in that when there has been an increase in moneys going to government schools there has been a corresponding increase in moneys going to non-government schools. There has been a greater increase for non-government schools in this regard because in all these years increasing numbers of children have enrolled in independent schools. Because of the flow away from government to independent schools there has been a linked automatic increase in the trend of support for non-government schools. In all the years of the last decade-during the Whitlam Government years and the Fraser Government years-the non-government schools of Australia have received, at the most, 60 per cent of their recurrent support from the taxpayer while the government schools have received 100 per cent. It is a gross misrepresentation for the propaganda of the teachers federations, as happened in the last election, to overlook that when trying to persuade the public that changes are needed.

I propose that the basic grant that has been given in recent years to all independent schools be a basic grant for all schools alike-schools in the government sector and in the non-government sector. If this grant had reached a level two years ago of 20 per cent of the cost of a government school place that should be the basic grant that is given to all schools alike. Money could be extracted from untied Commonwealth grants to the States and those untied grants could be reordered. The 20 per cent of the cost of a government school place should be given directly to schools under the same program that gives 20 per cent of the same cost of a government school place to independent schools.

I also propose that in addition to the basic grant to be given to all schools alike there be supplementary needs based grants for schools which in recent years have received level 2 or level 3 supplementation through the Schools Commission or have been the subject of special programs of assistance such as the country areas program, the disadvantaged schools program, the special education program, the multicultural education program and so on. Those grants can fund supplementary programs, and those schools which were regarded as level 2 and level 3 schools and which need additional educational resources would still continue to receive supplementary needs based grants. If grants of all kinds are handled by the one mechanism and within the one perspective, not only will the Parliament understand the matter more readily but also the public will see clearly that there is a reasonable basis for the taxpayers' support of schools in Australia and we will avoid the misrepresentation that we have seen.

Let me refer to the Schools Commission report for 1984 which was debated in the Senate earlier this afternoon. Notwithstanding the ALP Government's guidelines to the Schools Commission, we find that for 1984 government schools will receive a recurrent allocation of $594,952,000 whereas non-government schools will receive a greater amount of $626,772,000. Therefore, the propaganda that the teachers federations put up in heaps to the former Government could equally be put to the present Labor Government and it would be just as gross a misrepresentation. These groups would be alleging that the greater amount coming through the Schools Commission to non-government schools from the Hawke Labor Government-$626m compared with $594m to go to government schools-is an imbalance that needs correction. But in fact, I surmise, the response of the Hawke Labor Government would be the same response as I am giving now and the same response as the Schools Commission would give. That response would be: 'Do not take out of context this rather small amount of support from the taxpayer for schools. It is only $1.2 billion when the total amount exceeds $7 billion. To gain balance in looking at the two sectors one needs to look at the total picture'.

A publication of the Australian Bureau of Statistics in January this year gives the most up to date analysis of government outlays on education classified by economic type. The Bureau indicates on page 5 of that document that in the 1980- 81 financial year the Commonwealth Government provided $2,368m for schools for all types in Australia and that the States, out of their own resources and from non-specific Commonwealth Government grants provided $4,661m. This latter figure could be totally found from Commonwealth untied grants to the States, which in 1980-81 amounted to $6,018m.

It is not possible to show that the States have applied the moneys they received from the Commonwealth through untied grants fully to educational purposes in the States, but if they did they would still have money left over from Commonwealth untied grants and would be able to provide fully for all their spending on education. It could be said, without distortion, that the moneys provided by the Commonwealth completely pay for education in our schools of all types and that the State moneys are provided entirely from the Commonwealth untied grants. It is within these broader perspectives that I bring this motion before the Senate-so that there can be consideration, a fresh look, a review of the perspective in which these moneys are provided to government and non- government schools. I am happy to say that the Chairman of the Schools Commission, Dr Tannock, and the Schools Commission itself have called for such a review and such a reordering. To support my conclusion, I quote again from Dr Tannock's paper to ANZAAS. He said:

As the Commission has pointed out in this report, and in its discussion paper, 'Some Aspects of School Finance in Australia', this pattern of provision for school finance in Australia is unbalanced, somewhat irrational and has contributed significantly to some of the confusions and tensions that surround education policy and public debate on it in Australia. The Commission also pointed out that redressing these funding imbalances may be a necessary precondition to shifting the education debate away from the time-honoured State- aid issue and towards more urgent matters such as the reform of secondary education.
I heartily concur with those remarks. I also note that the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) in mid-May said:

The fact is, the targets set in 1973 by the Interim Committee for the Schools Commission-the Karmel targets as they have been known-have been met. Since the time they were met, the Commission, in major portions of its program, has largely lacked direction. That is, some of its main programs appear, at least, to lack a coherent rationale other than simply providing general contributions to the recurrent and capital support of schools.

The Minister for Education, the Chairman and members of the Schools Commission and those of us in the Opposition all believe that there is a time for a single perspective in educational finance which will be balanced, have clear goals and enable the public to see steps towards the achievement of those goals. Especially, it should be a perspective in which there will not be gross misrepresentation of the kind that we saw during the last election campaign. Therefore, I commend to the Senate the motion that I have moved:

That consideration should be given to Commonwealth grants to the States for schools being presented in a new and consistent way by providing for a basic per capita grant in respect of all schoolchildren, whether in government or non- government schools, and by providing for supplementary needs-based grants for schools incorporating the special and supplementary programs of the Schools Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Macklin for enabling me to enter very briefly into this debate. Because of other commitments, I will have to be extremely brief. In supporting Senator Teague's motion, I observe that I do not wish that support to be regarded as support for an interpretation of the proposal contained in paragraph (b).
—Nor a rejection, I take it.

—Nor a rejection of it; but, as I understand it, the burden of the motion is that the debate on education funding be educated and not misrepresented. I agree with Senator Teague that, in fact, it has been misrepresented. It has been misrepresented throughout the structures of one political party and throughout certain structures of the trade union movement. It has been misrepresented quite deliberately by the New South Wales Teachers Federation. The New South Wales Teachers Federation was responsible for preparing a draft of the Australian Council of Trade Unions Congress decision relating to education. With the exception of me, nobody in this chamber has been a delegate to an ACTU congress. I know what occurs there. Material on education is left to the teachers. Unfortunately, the teachers misrepresented the situation and were not picked up on that misrepresentation. I quote from page 52 of the policy decisions of the ACTU Congress 1983 entitled 'Education'. Paragraph 3.1.2 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Congress declares that the primary obligation of Governments is to provide and maintain government school systems of the highest standard open to all children and that the Australian Government must contribute financial and political resources towards achieving that objective.
Paragraph 3.1.3 states:

To this end, Congress notes the extraordinary state of affairs which exists in 1983 whereby non-Government schools with 24 per cent of students receive more money from the Commonwealth Government than Government schools with 76 per cent of students.

Congress further notes that during the period of the Fraser Government a total of $2,500,000,000 of Commonwealth Government recurrent funds were directed away from the Government School System to Private Schools.

TALK.START.PARA: —How dishonest can it get?

—That is totally dishonest. It is proof of what Senator Teague has been saying. This statement came from the New South Wales Teachers Federation. I would have thought that teachers were bound to teach the truth objectively, not to manipulate the facts for their own reasons. This is precisely what has occurred. That is one example. There are other examples of this that should be stamped upon by people in all political parties and by those in no political party. I believe it is in the interests of people within the Australian Labor Party to be aware of what is going on in this area because certain decisions taken in some States in recent days have been taken on the basis of this dishonest manipulation of the facts. Unfortunately, these decisions will come back to haunt the people. I am sure that members of the Labor Party in New South Wales, for example, are feeling now that they should have acted against the dishonest manipulators in the New South Wales Teachers Federation before this because the Minister in that State is now faced with having to say precisely that to the Teachers Federation. I believe that Senator Teague, in bringing this matter to the attention of the Senate, deserves the recognition of all the Senate. All he is asking of the Senate is that it endorse a proposition which will ensure that the debate on education funding is undertaken in an honest and educated fashion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Teague's motion is an interesting one. I think it is reasonably able to be supported, for two reasons. First, in regard to paragraph (a), I do not think there is a shadow of doubt that opponents of non-government schools have grossly misrepresented various facts to the public. However, that paragraph's one real deficiency is that opponents of government schools have also grossly misrepresented the facts. In any debate about education in Australia the area of funding probably would get a special prize for the way it has led to gross misrepresentation on both sides. Unfortunately, Senator Teague's motion is deficient in that it does not recognise that the type of argument and debate that has gone on has been puerile on both sides, not simply on one side. I do not think that simply saying there has been wrong on only one side contributes very much to getting the debate on to an even keel. I hope he would admit that there has been gross misrepresentation on both sides in this regard.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, this is an area in which statitics have been used to boost particular arguments, and they have misused in many fora. In fact, I remember speaking at a meeting where the argument used to show how poorly non-government schools were treated involved the treatment of only the State funds. This type of absurdity gets us nowhere and really clouds the issue of the correct distribution of funds, which ultimately comes from the taxpayer. Whether they go through State Treasuries or the Federal Treasury, they ultimately come from the same group of people. So I think that one could support proposition (a) but with the reservation that it is a deficient proposition because the gross misrepresentation has taken place on both sides, not only one.

I turn to paragraph (b) in Senator Teague's motion, which I think contains the most substantive proposition; the first one is probably just a little bit of flag waving. In the second proposition Senator Teague puts forward a motion for consideration. If one were asked whether or not there ought to be a consideration of this proposition it would hardly seem to me to be an appropriate response in an education debate to say that one should not consider whatever it is which Senator Teague has spent some considerable time and energy putting together and which he wishes to present. In that sense the Australian Democrats would be happy to support a motion which says that there should be consideration of a particular item.

However, I would like to make a few comments on the proposition that Senator Teague has put forward because I think that it suffers from a couple of very acute problems. Certainly I would be very interested to hear the comments of Senator Baume, as an ex-Minister for Education, on the proposition that State governments would be amenable to this proposition. As I read it, it is an integral part of the proposition that the States would have to acknowledge that the basic grant is their money. Currently in Queensland, where there is to be a State election this week, people are very keen on pointing out how much of the State budget is currently being spent on education. Indeed, some of the parties in Queensland are spending a great deal of money on television advertising to point out that 25 per cent of the State Budget is being spent on education. If we follow what Senator Teague is suggesting, the States are about to lose a large percentage of that money because the Commonwealth is going to say that it is its money. It is not as simple as it may seem to get States to agree that a certain amount of money shall be henceforth acknowledged, publicly, and genuflected to, as being Commonwealth money when the States say that it happens to be their money, that the Commonwealth got its grubby hands on it and is now giving it back to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —It depends where honesty rests.

—Honesty in this area is sometimes something which resides only on Government benches, whether at a Federal or State level. I have heard Senator Baume argue strongly on public platforms about the contribution that the Commonwealth makes and I have also heard his counterpart in my own State argue equally as strongly that the money was really the State's. The proposition that Senator Teague has put forward is a political proposition and we have to meet the issue of where that money will finally rest in terms of the States saying: ' That is out money'. If one follows some of the arguments that Senator Teague presented, State governments could not argue that any of the money is theirs; ultimately, all of the money would be the Commonwealth's. Presumably the overwhelming power of the purse has finally got hold of the federation and there is a final acceptance that all the money really belongs to the Commonwealth. Other people would like to argue that all the money really belongs to the taxpayer. The State governments want to argue that it belongs to them and is only on loan to the Commonwealth. So it is not as simple a matter as waving a wand.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge the proposition lying behind Senator Teague's notion of getting this debate back onto an even keel-as the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans ) would say, it sounded like a good idea at the time-but when we actually try to implement it we would run into the most hairy problems with the State governments. I personally would not like to be in the shoes of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan, when she has to trot off to the State governments-even though the majority of them are Labor governments-to sell the idea to them. I am sure she would be shown the door rather rapidly, whether she be talking to a Labor government, as in most of the States, or the Liberal Government in Tasmania. I do not know what the Government is in Queensland at the moment; it is a bit difficult to pick.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will tell you on Monday.

—It might take a little longer than Monday. The first problem- the political problem-is the acknowledgment of whose money it actually is. That is not an easy matter in Australian federal terms finally to work out.

SPEECH.PARA: The substantive problem is this: The suggestion that we ought to have a base per capita grant can be attacked on a number of equity grounds, not the least of which is that one has first of all to go back another step and say, in regard to the distribution of any funds through institutions for the education of children , that if we wish to achieve ultimately an equal opportunity for every child we have to admit that the funding to any institution must have the capacity to range from zero to 100 per cent. That is a theoretical possibility. We know that will not occur in Australia simply because the funding since 1972 has brought the schools somewhat closer together. As a theoretical exercise, one cannot say that there ought to be a basic per capita grant and still say that one upholds the notion of equality of opportunity.

I can point out some schools in my own State of Queensland-doubtless, Senator Teague can point out similar schools in his State-which fall far behind the standard of other schools. Here I am thinking of a relatively remote school-it happens to be a non-government school; it is a convent school-which I believe ought to have been closed down years ago. The school building itself is a fire trap. I do not think that the teachers in the school have a qualification among them. The pupils are getting a pretty raw deal. That happens to be the case at that particular school which I have in mind. I will not name it because I am sure it would be very demoralising to the teachers to hear those comments, but it happens to be the case. I think that every honourable senator would be able to think of a school in his or her State which is akin to that school, if not as bad.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Teague would say that that is freedom of choice for the children and their parents.
—Freedom of choice in that regard--
—Give them supplementary grants.

—That was not Senator Teague's proposition. The proposition which he put forward was for a basic per capita grant in respect of all children . I am simply raising the theoretical problem that if there is to be a basic per capita grant-he did mention the possibility that it might be about 20 per cent- it could be exceeded, quite readily, in some schools. I do not know whether it would be exceeded at the upper level. However, some schools could exceed it at the minimum level. That aside, let us say that the grant does fall within the range of between 20 per cent and 80 per cent-I grant Senator Teague's point-and take the next step from there. If we are to give that basic per capita grant in respect of all school children, I presume-I was following the tenor of his argument as closely as I could-it will still go to the institutions. It does not meet the point that I have raised in the Senate on a number of occasions that a very well off school, or even a reasonable school, be it government or non- government, has within that school children who come from a very wide variety of backgrounds. Let me take as an example the government school which my own children attend. That school happens to be classified as a disadvantaged school. There is no way in the world that anybody would say, looking at my income, that my children were disadvantaged in terms of the distribution of incomes in Australia.
—Only through inheritance.

—That is a very unkind remark by the honourable senator regarding inheritance. My children may think that they are also disadvantaged because of that. I have not asked them. I will have to ask them when I see them. For example, let us consider the government school, the disadvantaged school, which my children attend. My children are not disadvantaged in terms of income. I am able to supply them with a whole range of educational opportunities, not the least of which is that my own and my wife's professional backgrounds are in education. We are able to provide them with a whole host of other possibilities which lots of children in Australia do not have. Yet the school itself is designated as a disadvantaged school. I expand that further by saying that in many ways that school is not disadvantaged. The reason why it is classified as disadvantaged relates to the ethnic background of many of the children who attend that school. The school has a very large Aboriginal and Greek population. It happens to be in the area which is the well in which new migrant waves come. At the moment there are many Vietnamese children in the school.
—To be fair, the term 'disadvantaged' there is a funding convenience, not in respect of social status.

—Yes, I am coming to that. That is what I am developing the argument about. That is precisely the dichotomy which I am trying to develop. The school itself provides to my children, who are from an Anglo-Saxon background, a vast array of tremendously beneficial inputs from a whole host of cultures. I happen to believe that my children, in going to that school, are advantaged over most children in Australia. It is a tremendously exciting and vibrant place for my children to be in. That is why I send them there, quite apart from the very high quality of basic teaching that the teachers in that government school provide. Here I am talking about reading, writing and a whole host of other subjects. I mention that because quite a number of comments have been made in this place in education debates which denigrate government schools and teachers in government schools. I wish to put it on the record that I do not go along with that type of wholesale denigration. If one wants to say something about a school, one has to be much more specific and talk about particular teachers and particular schools.

SPEECH.PARA: That school, as Senator Peter Baume has suggested, is categorised as disadvantaged for funding purposes. I believe that it is in no way disadvantaged . I believe it has a whole host of advantages which are not given to other schools. To look at a basic per capita grant and then go on to say that we will have supplementary needs-based grants and supplementary grants under the current arrangements makes the situation very difficult. Essentially we are dealing with institutions, and education deals with kids. That is the dichotomy that we are constantly running up against in these debates.

On the other hand, at the school which my children attend, some children-I raised this earlier when we were dealing with some reports-are recent arrivals in this country from Vietnam. They have no parents and no supporting adults. In fact, they come under the designation of wards of the State-that is, of my own State-and a range of supplementary grants is provided to them basically through the Department of Social Security. Those children are in very difficult circumstances in the initial year at least in which they arrive in Australia. They will always suffer from the problem of the war in Vietnam, the breaking up of their families and being deprived of their parents and other adult figures in their lives. That can never be supplemented by finance. But essentially, of course, their problems can never be picked up-no matter how good the school is. They can only be picked up by providing them with other social needs, that is, love and security, which are provided by a family arrangement. No matter what we do with the funding of a school at that level it does not help that child. In essence, the suggestion that we ought to have this basic grant and then add supplementary needs based grants does not get at the real problem. I do not think it will help in actually restoring any sanity to the education debate. In that way, I do not really feel that it would meet the type of very laudable criteria and goals that Senator Teague was wishing in bringing forward this notice of motion.

On a number of occasions I have outlined-I will not do so now-the way in which we really do need to move forward. It is not by putting down a priori funding possibilities in this Senate or elsewhere. Quite frankly, I think we have moved beyond that. The level of the sectarian debate and the level of acrimony in the whole operation will not be solved by coming up with these types of propositions . Essentially, we have to go back to the groundwork. We have to say that there is one criterion that everybody has to accept before we can have a reasonable conference, that is, that non-government schools are going to continue and so are government schools. Given that basic groundwork, we then have to get people together from non-government organisations, non-government parent organisations in schools, teachers' unions and a variety of other people, regardless of the pontificating which they all go on with in public. That is the type of situation that politicians know fairly well because it occurs all the time in our profession. One makes certain public commitments but, if one can get away from the glare of the media and get down to the basic items, one can often find, as the Senate finds in its committees, a great deal of common ground.

TALK.START.PARA: —A low key education summit.

—Yes. We need an education summit, but we do not need an education summit like the National Economic Summit Conference. The last thing we need in education is any more grandstanding. We have had enough of it. Basically , those people have to get away from the media-with all due respect to the media -because the media pushes people into firm positions that they do not necessarily want to hold to in the ultimate. Every person going into that conference ought to say that they will not divulge outside the conference the workings of that conference, that there will be a communique agreed to at the end of the conference, and that will be it. The only things that should be included in that communique are those things on which the conference has agreed, no matter how few they are. All other matters should be put back into the melting pot to be dealt with at some time in the future. People would have the opportunity, at such a round table conference, to explore.

SPEECH.PARA: I have floated a number of matters in this place for debate on a number of occasions. For example, a matter to be discussed could be the non-government schools giving away their right over the entrance and exit qualifications, so that they can no longer say: 'We will receive only these children with particular religious qualification or some other type of qualification. For that we are willing to do something else.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is almost on the road to an integrated system.

—Yes. I suggest an integrated system has worked in other countries. I am looking at the integrated system which is acceptable to the types of people which Senator Baume has been quoting in debate. In Scotland the Catholic bishops strongly support an integrated system; in New Zealand they do not; in Canada they do. There is a whole variety of systems. We cannot adopt, wholesale, an integrated system from another country, but we could establish our own. I think we could establish one which would finally put the lid on this absurd, stupid debate about the schools. We could only do it with goodwill and away from the Press. Only then could people explore the possibilities and the compromises that might be able to be entered into to see whether there could be some meeting of minds. I happen to believe-it might be a vain, optimistic hope-
—A quixotic hope.

—It might even be quixotic, as Senator Haines said. I hope that the people who are engaged in the various educational groupings in this country ultimately are concerned about the kids. I make that statement; I do not necessarily know whether it is true, but I think one has to believe that it is true. If those people who are involved in education, whether it be at government or non-government schools, are really concerned about the education of children in this country, they will come to such a meeting, put their cards on the table, argue about the possible compromises and will be willing to give away things in that type of closed meeting that they could not possibly give away before their constituents. In that type of conference we may then get much further than we would by following the suggestions that Senator Teague has brought forward with all the goodwill in the world.

SPEECH.PARA: We are happy to support Senator Teague because I believe that any proposal that has been well thought out and which has had as much work done on it as his ought to be given consideration. That is all that he has asked. I think the Senate could very well agree that we could give consideration to such a proposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to make a brief contribution to the debate introduced by Senator Teague. I make the point that it will be a brief contribution. I am conscious of the fact that ex- educators in this place tend to speak at some length, although the contribution they make is always valuable. Senator Teague and I share, with many others in this place, an interest in education. I am pleased that he mentioned, in the course of his speech, the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts report: 'Preparation for the workforce'. Like him I would like to give a little free publicity to that report, commend it to honourable senators and suggest that they and others study it.

SPEECH.PARA: I will contribute a few thoughts in this debate rather than counter the arguments put forward by Senator Teague or those put forward by Senator Macklin. The reason for this will become obvious as my contribution proceeds. I make one minor criticism of Senator Teague's speech, if I may. It has already been mentioned by Senator Macklin. I was disappointed that he did not deal more fully , in the body of his remarks, with the respective roles of the Commonwealth and the States in education. No doubt he will make a contribution towards this end in a later debate, although other Opposition speakers may do so. I commend the contribution made by Senator Macklin because he touched on this aspect in the early part of his address.

Senator Teague, in the first part of his proposal, was obviously concerned about misrepresentation by the opponents of non-government schools. It would have to be, of course, misrepresentation outside of parliament by groups or individuals. I notice that Senator Harradine identified one group that has made a number of comments about the system. No political party in recent years has opposed the funding of non-government schools. Some individuals may have done so in the course of debate and some may have done so out on the platform in the community. No party in this place or in the other place has opposed the funding of non-government schools. This does not mean, of course, that some individuals have not been critical of some of the non-government schools. We have to remind ourselves that there are many types of non-government schools, ranging across the spectrum, such as Aboriginal schools, minority religious schools, migrant schools, accelerated Christian education schools and so on. Within the community there are a large number of non-government schools. It is very difficult to generalise about them. Certainly we can talk about the funding of these schools. It is quite clear that, Senator Teague, in his contribution, was looking at the major non-government schools and was looking, basically, at Commonwealth funding because he was speaking about the decisions made by the Commonwealth Government.

Let me briefly present the Government's position on the funding of non- government schools. Firstly, parents are free to select the schools of their choice. We all know that parents have a number of reasons for selecting non- government schools for their children to attend. I suppose the first one would be the traditional one of the children going back to the old school-the father attended a certain school and he wants his son to attend that school; or a mother attended a certain college and she wants her daughter to attend that college. Of course, there are religious grounds for people wanting their children to attend certain schools. They believe that an education should have a religious basis and that the education presented in the government schools does not have a sufficient religious base for them. Many adopt what I call the cynical approach and say that if one attends a certain school one is more likely to get a job in a particular area. It is not too many years ago that certain sections of the Public Service presented a greater opportunity, shall we say, to those people who wore a particular school tie. I will come back to that matter and develop the theme of the freedom of the parents to select their schools.

The Government recognises also the high standards many schools achieve in a number of areas, certainly in academic achievement. Over the years many schools have developed a name for scholarship. They have won most of the bursaries for entry into universities. They have prepared their young people to enter the work force with a number of passes in matriculation or whatever examination happened to operate in a particular State. So many parents will say 'We will send our child there because we want him to have that better education', assessing education by the examination result. There is no doubt that some people chose a school for its sporting prowess. I suppose this was one of the basic reasons for choosing a school in the early days. People sent their children to a certain school because that school had developed a good team in a particular sport and the father wanted his son to continue in that sport. In the same way people sent their children to a particular school because of the attitudes that were developed there. In fact, when I went to university, education was defined as the changing of attitudes. One could debate that at some length, but the educators of that day saw that attitudes would need to change before education could take place. In the same way, I suppose, one could look at the moral and spiritual values of a school for attracting students to the school.

The Government has made its decision about finance quite clear. Our funding of schools is based on a needs principle. There is nothing new about that. It has been in the Australian Labor Party's platform for years. It was introduced in 1972-75 and has been reintroduced under the present Labor regime. We make no apology for this. We believe that this is the correct approach, and I will develop this later on. Senator Teague and Senator Baume yesterday, in the course of the debate on the matter of public importance, made certain comments about the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) and criticised her for not attending a meeting in Albury. At that time they imputed improper motives for her not being there. I am not concerned about that at this stage but the address which she prepared for that meeting, which was a meeting of parents of children of independent schools, is relevant to the debate which we are having today. I will just read parts of it that relate to this debate. I start with the opening two paragraphs:

Firstly, let me apologise for not being able to address you personally tonight. A prior commitment in another State has prevented this. The Chairman, however, has agreed to read the following statement on my behalf which sets out clearly the Commonwealth Government's policy on the funding of non-government schools. Non-government schools can be assured of continued support from the Commonwealth . In 1984 the Commonwealth is providing an overall increase of 1.5 per cent, in real terms, for non-government schools. These additional funds will be distributed within the non-government sector on the basis of need.
Later paragraphs read:

The funding policy of the previous Government was promoting the advantages held by a small number of schools at the expense of the majority of students in the majority of schools. The funding arrangements for 1984 give an extra $5 million to category three schools, in comparison with what they would have received under the automatic nexus formula. This is, I believe, a genuine act of redistribution of resources by a Government which is concerned to raise the standards of low resource use schools.

For 1985, the Government wishes to consider the implementation of a new scheme for non-government school general resources funding. The Commonwealth Schools Commission has been asked to provide advice and options on a more comprehensive approach to the definition of 'need', the establishment of adequate general resource standards against which need may be measured and the categorisation of schools for Commonwealth funding purposes in a manner which provides for sufficient differentiation in relation to the varying needs and circumstances of schools.

Non-government school authorities will be consulted as policy options are developed. They will have the opportunity to put forward any data or proposals which they feel need to be brought to the Government's attention.

That is part of the address which Senator Susan Ryan prepared for that meeting in Albury. Perhaps I should develop the freedom of choice and diversity of schooling aspects which I mentioned earlier. I think it is fair to say that the substantial majority of Australian families send their children to the local government school. Often this is a matter of choice, sometimes it is an economic necessity and sometimes there is no other school. If government schools can be improved so that they offer a broader curriculum and more individual help and are more responsive to the wishes of parents, clearly the educational choices of the majority of Australians will be enhanced. If all schools can provide a sound educational base for all their pupils so that they can go on to choose further learning or be well equipped to look for employment, the choices of those pupils are greatly improved. The Government's participation and equity program is a significant contribution to enhancing the choices of many thousands of young people through offering them a richer curriculum and a better chance to gain work force skills through technical and further education. Similarly, the emphasis in the guidelines on improving the resources of the most needy schools in the non-government sector is a specific contribution to enabling those schools to offer a richer curriculum containing more learning choices for the children who attend them. These dimensions of the discussion about freedom of choice in education are frequently overlooked. The issue becomes narrowed so that its focus is exclusively on the rights of parents to choose a non- government school for their children.

The non-government sector of schooling in Australia has provided an important expression of the diversity of the Australian society. It has offered a real choice to a large number of families seeking schooling for their children with a particular religious or other special character. The Government will continue to support the diversity of character of Australian schooling so that schooling can reflect the range of educational needs, beliefs and backgrounds in the Australian community. This support will reflect the Government's concern to ensure that resources are used effectively and the choices available to all are equitably considered.

I would like to look now very briefly at non-government school funding. The point has been made that in the lead-up to the Budget there was insufficient time for the Government to consult widely with the non-government school community and other relevant authorities on the development of long term changes in funding policy. We are looking particularly here at two areas: First, a community standard of resources for schools; and secondly, a more comprehensive way of measuring the needs of schools against the community standard. The community standard is not the bare minimum but rather an agreed standard. One of the jobs which the Schools Commission has been given is to seek out the standard , to establish the standard and to use that as the basis. So it is clear that the Government has made a number of interim decisions for 1984 and asked the Commonwealth Schools Commission to consult widely with non-govenment schools and other authorities on the options for longer term funding policies beyond 1984. As we made clear in the debate yesterday, the Minister has also consulted with the national and State Catholic education commissions on the guidelines.

A number of decisions have been made by the Government, and I think If I read these quickly from the notes which I have they will be in Hansard for those who have an interest in them. For 1984 the Government decided that additional funds amounting to $7.2m-I might indicate that that is a real increase of 1.3 per cent on 1983-would be provided for general recurrent grants for non-government schools. These additional funds would be provided on a needs basis. The Government decided that per capita grants for the 41 schools whose private income alone is 95 per cent or more of government schools standard costs should be reduced by 25 per cent in 1984 and the savings from this, some $4m, redirected to those in greater need. The grants for other schools in group 1- that is the highest resource category-would be maintained in real terms. Those for group 2 would be increased by one per cent in real terms and those for group 3-the most in need-by 3 per cent in real terms. These funding arrangements replace those of the previous Government under which increases in grants for all non-government schools were linked to increases in government schools costs each year, regardless of the fact that many low resource non-government schools had far greater needs than other high resource non-government schools. In fact, in recent years the gap between low resource non-government schools and government schools has widened.

It is fair to indicate here that, had the previous Government's funding policy continued, the lowest resource non-government schools in group 3 would have received some $5m less than they will now receive in 1984. In addition to these changes the Government took the following funding decisions for 1984 which will benefit non-government schools: The 1983 level of capital grants was maintained in real terms, including the $9m provided in 1983 for new places. Within the total grants $4m will be provided for upgrading of schools serving disadvantaged communities and $2m for capital facilities in schools serving Aboriginal communities. It is rather interesting to note at this stage the attitude across the board-that is, not only in the education area but also in the Aboriginal affairs area-that went into making the decision about Yipiranya school, about which I spoke yesterday. The Government also took the decision on the provision of some $4.5m for non-government schools under the new participation and equity program and $1.2m under the new computer education program. Overall grants for non-government schools will increase by 1.5 per cent in real terms. There will be a reintroduction of retrospective cost supplementation, providing greater certainty for education planning, and a reactivation of the Curriculum Development Centre. This will benefit all schools.

Let me conclude by saying that Senator Teague, in his motion, has sought consideration of a certain funding proposal which he has put forward. Let me assure him, as well as one can do on this side of the chamber without being the Minister, that this will be looked at. In fact, as he will know and as the shadow Minister will know, it has already been looked at by the Schools Commission and will be looked at again in both the government and the non- government areas. It is a proposition which, as Senator Macklin indicated, is worthy of being looked at. When the investigation has been carried out, quite clearly the Government will make a decision, which will be as all government decisions are made, within the parameters of our policy-a policy which I have taken a few minutes this afternoon to place on the record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask for your indulgence for a moment. I think Senator Robertson indicated early in his speech the attitude that the Government would take to the motion. Was it that the Government would not oppose it?
—There is no opposition.

—I thank the honourable senator for that. For my part, there is no need for me to speak at great length. But I do want to support my colleague, Senator Teague, for the motion that he has moved and for the arguments that he has advanced in support of that motion. I will deal with the second part of his motion first. I agree with Senator Robertson that the proposition that consideration should be given to this funding mechanism is one with which no one would want to disagree. Those of us who read the Commonwealth Schools Commission document which appeared in February of this year and which set out recommendations for 1984 will know that the Commonwealth Schools Commission went part of the way down the track that Senator Teague is proposing here today. It put some numbers into its proposition and made some suggestions as to what might be involved. I would like to see this kind of proposition and, as Senator Macklin said, other kinds of propositions which might give us the biggest range of options open to us examined to help us develop the best kind of education policies. There seems to be agreement right around the Senate that consideration should be given to paragraph (b) of the motion. I am grateful to my colleagues in the Senate that that is forthcoming.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the first part of Senator Teague's motion was not about the policies of the former government or the policies of this Government. I do not intend to comment upon the policies which have been put forward-whether they are good and adequate or whether they are not. That is another issue. The first part of the motion asks us to accept as the view of the Senate that over some time:

decisions of the Commonwealth Parliament concerning financial support for government and non-government schools . . . have been grossly misrepresented to the public by the opponents of non-government schools;
Because that is a matter of demonstrable historical fact, I am delighted that honourable senators are disposed to support that part of the motion.

When I was Minister for Education, I had the carriage of the defence of government policy. I had to receive and to respond to much of the misrepresentation to which Senator Teague refers in this motion. Very simply, if we have funding which has three components, a private component-a non-government component-a Commonwealth Government component and a State Government component, that is the totality of funding. For anyone then to base a public case and a public campaign solely on one of those three funding components is to misrepresent to that part of the community which is not aware of the totality of the situation what is occurring and to misrepresent to them where the balance of funding lies. Let me must say again that if one puts together the funding inputs which came from the Commonwealth and the funding inputs which came from the State, from those one derived the total public input into education. When one examined that particular cake of Commonwealth and State funding, a picture emerged which was very different from that which certain people would have us believe was the case in public campaigns which they ran, to the detriment of the Government of which I was a member. In my own State of New South Wales I had to watch television advertisements talking about 'the education cake'. The only trouble with those advertisements was that they were describing only part of the education cake and representing that part as the whole cake. The fact is that that was being done by the teachers federations for what were vested self- interest reasons. I attended public forums. I attended the Council of the Teacher Federations. I remember that I attended an election meeting in Bathurst at which the New South Wales Teachers Federation figured very prominently. That was just before the election. At each of those meetings the Federation officials , and speakers and the speakers in support of their position, concentrated only on one part of the funding and presented it as if it were the total funding. That Senator Teague's motion would seek to recognise what was occurring over several years and would seek to have that accepted as the view of the Senate is something which I believe would be to the benefit of the public argument and to future consideration of education funding.

Finally, without necessarily endorsing the conclusions that Senator Macklin came to-without endorsing his particular prescription-I should like to indicate a general sympathy with the propositions he advanced about some of the problems in education in Australia today and the kind of analysis which he presented, which might help us go towards solutions. It is the kind of analysis which the Opposition is undertaking at the present time. I think there is much common ground between us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I think that we have had constructive debate in the Senate. From the Opposition, from the Australian Democrats and from the Government, there is the same feeling that consideration does need to be given to presenting clearly to the public and to ourselves taxpayer support for education with Australia. We need to put together the various principles that we have debated over recent weeks. I thank Senator Harradine also for his support for the motion that has been moved and Senator Macklin, Senator Robertson and my colleague Senator Peter Baume. I am not wishing in this brief summary and response to the debate to claim that we have all got exactly the same views. I disagree with Senator Macklin's rejection that a basic grant should be able to be received by every child in Australia. At the same time, I am entirely sympathetic with the central emphasis upon a needs based formula for funding. Senator Peter Baume referred to the important matter of gaining equity and reason in the way in which we look at a school as one institution and look at a family within that school. I am entirely sympathetic with that suggestion. I welcome the decision of the Government which responds to the Commonwealth Schools Commission's statements, some of which I cited in my own remarks, and I welcome the decision of the Government, to which Senator Robertson has referred, that there is a review in process that will seek to bring a fresh and sound perspective to education funding in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: At one point, Senator Robert Ray interjected and asked whether this subject would not have been a useful reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts. I acknowledge our personal conversations and that this is a concern that we expressed two years ago and one year ago. But at the time, even in this tolerant and at times enlightened Senate, it was not politically possible to take such a hot potato and carry it forward into a major public inquiry. In principle, I would still like to give that a go. I think Senator Giles, who was also involved in those discussions, would acknowledge that on personal grounds I would very much have liked the information and public input that such a Senate based national inquiry might have gained. I only hope that the inquiry that is now proceeding with the Schools Commission will lead to just as sound a result as we had hoped for in those informal discussions. In any event, I thank honourable senators for their expressions of support for the motion. I look forward to the time when we will have such a sound and clear perspective that the public will understand the way in which taxpayers are supporting both Government and non-government schools in Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move notice of motion No. 33 :

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate condemns the Government for the introduction of a discriminatory wine impost and notes that-
(a) the 1983 Budget imposition of an excise on grape spirit used in fortifying wine places at risk the future of the fortified wine industry in Australia;
(b) the requirement to pay the excise within 7 days of the fortification occurring is inequitable as returns to producers will not be received until the product is sold several years in the future;
(c) the excise will be reflected in increased costs to consumers of fortified wines of up to 100 per cent;

(d) producers of quality ports, sherries, muscats and other fortified wines will be encouraged either to withdraw from the market completely, thereby restricting consumer choice, or to reduce the maturation for such products, thereby reducing the quality;
(e) this excise will increase the costs of production of fortified wines for export, further disadvantaging Australian producers on overseas markets;

(f) the consequential reduction of fortified wine sales will be reflected in reduced intake of grapes from grapegrowers for these purposes, particularly from grapegrowers in the Riverland region of South Australia, the Leeton-Griffith district of New South Wales and the Sunraysia district in Victoria;
(g) this will increase the hardship suffered by grapegrowers in these areas causing severe economic problems in decentralised regions;

and it calls on the Government to either abolish this new impost or, at the very least, alter the payment of excise arrangements so as to only require payment when fortified wines are released for sale on the market.
I also move notice of motion No. 35:
That the Senate, noting that-

(a) at a meeting of winemakers and grapegrowers in the McLaren Vale district during the 1983 Federal Election campaign, the then Australian Labor Party spokesman on Primary Industry stated: 'Industry will welcome Labor's pledge not to contemplate a wine tax';

(b) in its first Budget, the Hawke Australian Labor Party Government imposed a discriminatory tax on wine, namely, the introduction of an excise on grape spirit used in the production of fortified wines; and

(c) in the House of Representatives on Thursday, 25 August 1983, the Labor Member for Kingston who was at the McLaren Vale meeting stated: 'I regard that promise as being completely honoured as a result of the Budget . . . I reject any implication that the Government has not honoured its obligations to the wine industry',
condemns the Government for not keeping its promises and regrets that the Member for Kingston shows such lack of regard for, and understanding of, the wine industry.

These two motions deal with questions connected with the grape spirit and wine industry. Both of them draw attention to the plight of the industry in South Australia. The second motion I have moved, of course, deals with certain promises that were given by the Government before the election and the subsequent breaking of those promises after the election. Most importantly, the first motion to which I would like to address my remarks touches on the difficulties in the industry that have arisen since the introduction of the wine spirit tax in the Budget on 23 August. The problems that are facing the industry in my State of South Australia-of course, these problems are being experienced also in the Sunraysia district of Victoria, in the Hunter River district in New South Wales but more particularly in the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area-arise chiefly from the misunderstanding by the Government of its action in introducing this tax.

In the Budget it announced a levy of $2.61 per litre of alcohol for spirit added to fortified wines or used in the blending and manufacture of such things as ports, sherries, muscats, liqueurs and, in some cases, brandy. The addition of that tax at that time in itself does not sound as though it involves an enormous amount of money. The problem that arises immediately is that within seven days from the point at which that spirit is blended in the making of ports or sherries the excise due to the Government must be paid, notwithstanding the fact that the product of grape spirit such as ports, sherries and so on, would take a considerable time to mature. It may be eight, ten or even fifteen years. It would be that long before the wine industry would see the recovery of the cash outlaid for the excise met at the very commencement of the production process.

For that reason, the industry is suffering and will continue to suffer from severe cash flow problems in the future. The problem will not go away by virtue of the Government's announcement recently that it intends to reduce the rate of duty from $2.61 to $1.50.
