The action the Government took in September by making that statement clearly shows how it misunderstands the problems of the industry. The rate of duty is not the main complaint of the industry but rather the problem is financing that duty over such a long period until the product is matured and until it finally comes on to the market. As I pointed out, that might take eight, ten or fifteen years.

Consequently, last night an Australian Broadcasting Corporation program Countrywide showed the plight of the Riverland grape growers already struck by problems of oversupply and changes in the market place brought about by government actions. They are going to be forced into bankruptcy as a result of this particular action. Already, as was evidenced in that program last night, many people have been forced to accept social security benefit payments merely to exist. The number of properties on the market in the Riverland area in South Australia are growing rapidly. The latest move made by the Government will only increase the trend and the difficulty of individuals recovering the asset value of their farms. For that reason, the Government must reconsider this tax. Clearly, it fails to understand the nature of the problem. One can see absolutely no sense in the Government imposing a levy of this kind and then on the other hand having to pay out social security benefits to people whose livelihood has been destroyed as a result of that action. It is that kind of nonsense in which this Government appears to revel and lacks the will to correct .

I think we should remind ourselves of some of the election promises which were made before 5 March in this connection. During the campaign the Australian Labor Party was very keen, particularly in South Australia, to campaign on the basis that no wine tax would be introduced as a result of the election of a Labor Government. Mr John Kerin, the current Minister for Primary Industry, toured the wine growing areas of my State and categorically said time and again that the Government would not introduce a wine tax. At a meeting at McLaren Vale at the height of the election campaign he said:
Industry will welcome Labor's pledge not to contemplate a wine tax.

Labor not only contemplated it but also imposed it within its first six months in office. Obviously, however, while it contemplated imposing such a tax it did not give it a great deal of thought. That is the main issue in this particular question. If the Labor Party had thought about it in greater depth perhaps it would not have come up with such a discriminatory tax which was set in such a way as to be completely crippling in its effect. Mr Kerin was not the only one who spoke in these terms. In fact the now Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, gave this categoric assurance himself at Griffith in New South Wales on 20 February:
Labor is pledged not to impose a sales tax or excise tax on wine.

How can anybody ever believe that Prime Minister after that kind of statement and following the imposition of this tax in the Budget? One can only agree with the statement made clearly in an article from the Australian National University students' magazine:
He lies and he knows he lies.

It is that kind of statement we must fight in this country. We must make sure that this Government honours its promises. Already people who have an interest in this particular question have been making appropriate representations to the Government. Yet, the Government finds it very difficult to see the nature of the problem and to understand the depth of it. Clearly, Labor members do not understand the depth of the problem. Mr Bilney, the normally invisible member for Kingston in South Australia, has even ventured to try to explain away the excise. In a speech in the House a couple of weeks ago he said:
The promise-
he was referring to the promise given by Mr Kerin at McLaren Vale-
was given . . . that there would be no sales or excise taxes on wine.
He went on, incredibly, to say:
I regard that promise as being completely honoured as a result of this Budget.
Yet, an excise tax was imposed two days before Mr Bilney said that. In the course of his speech he also said:

I do not believe that the electorate was misled. I believe that the promise that I associated myself with has been completely honoured. I reject any implication that the Government has not honoured its obligations to the wine industry.

Of course the electorate was misled by Mr Kerin, Mr Hawke and Mr Bilney. That promise was not honoured. It is not simply an implication that the Government has not honoured its obligations to the industry. If in fact Mr Bilney really believes what he says it just shows the depth of his misunderstanding of the industry. It is also interesting to note that within a month of the Budget an article appeared in the Adelaide News, an afternoon newspaper, which indicated that Labor senators and members of the House of Representatives from South Australia had signed a letter to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) saying that the tax should be lifted. Yet, they had been going around for the previous few weeks trying to sell the people of South Australia the idea that this was in fact a good tax. It is amazing that even in this place when I tried to speak on this matter immediately after the Budget was introduced, a Labor senator from South Australia, Senator Crowley, refused me leave to address any remarks on this matter.

What will be the effects of this particular tax on the industry? Let us look at the effects throughout my State. Obviously this will have a very regional impact , particularly in the Riverland, which, as I mentioned earlier, was the subject of a Countrywide program last night on television, which demonstrated the problems in that area already; and they will be exacerbated enormously by this tax. We can see straight away some of the effects. First, of course, there will be an increase in the retail price of the wine. Secondly, that will obviously allow more imports from cheaper producing countries to flow into Australia. There will clearly be lower sales, which means lower receivals of grapes will be taken in by wine growers in order to make the spirit. Obviously there will be changes in all areas of the wine industry as a result of that, because what will occur chiefly is that, whereas in times of surplus production of grapes wine makers would take in those grapes, process them and make them into spirit, and put that away for later use, that will now not happen and grape production must fall as a result, which can lead only to disaster for the grape grower himself.

It is estimated that the loss of income in the Riverland and Sunraysia districts and in the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area will cost the industry, and particularly the grape growers, about $25 1/2m in their income. No small owner of a small acreage block will be able to survive that kind of drop of income. Obviously, such people will be forced to the wall. That has been clearly demonstrated. Again I make the point: Where is the sense in imposing a tax of this kind, on the one hand, and then, on the other hand, forcing people to accept social security benefits in order to exist? It is an absurd proposition.

But it is not even as though the Government has any clear view of the amount of revenue that will be produced as a result of its action. The Budget Papers led us to believe that the Government intended to raise only $6m. That would have taken into account a massive cut in the production of grape spirit. But subsequently the Treasurer refuted that figure and said that the excise would amount to $13 1/2m at the original rate of $2.61 a litre. But the South Australian Minister of Agriculture, Mr Blevins, said in the South Australian Parliament in September that the old excise rate-the $2.61 a litre rate-would have raised $13m in South Australia alone. This succession of fudges by the Treasurer is designed only to cover up a misunderstanding of the effects of this excise, and clearly the Government lacks the political will to correct a mistake which surely by now it must realise.

I have acknowledged that the Government has reduced the rate of excise a litre from $2.61 to $1.50. But that fails to acknowledge the very important difference between the amount of duty paid and the effect on the cash flow of the grape growing industry over many years, up to maybe 15 years in the case of producers of good quality ports. That is the position in which we find ourselves today. We would hope, as South Australians, that the Government will change its view on this matter. We hope that it will reconsider the imposition of this tax. It has all the hallmarks of a hasty decision made to raise taxes irrespective of the impact on the wine industry, and it clearly demonstrates an ignorance of the industry and its operations. The tax was imposed despite clear, firm and public commitments on the part of the present Prime Minister and the Minister for Primary Industry. Apparently implicitly, at least at the start, it had the support of South Australian Labor senators and members of this Parliament. It has further been evidenced by Mr Bilney's insistence that no tax promise has been broken and that Labor's commitment to the industry has been met. The latest changes by the Treasurer indicate again a total lack of understanding of the problem, and the Government really deserves to be condemned for all its actions in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose Senator Messner's notice of motion. It is interesting to go back into the history of the wine industry in Australia, especially in South Australia. It was in 1970 that the Fraser Government introduced a tax on wine. At that time that brought the industry almost to its knees. In 1972, when the Whitlam Government was elected, the excise on wine was removed. There was also a tax on spirit, imposed before 1970, and in 1972 the excise on spirit was also removed. In 1978, the Fraser Government put a further impost on brandy. That brought the grape industry, especially in the Riverland, almost to its knees. I remember quite distinctly that Senator Baden Teague, in his maiden speech, said that he would never support a tax on the wine industry. However, if one looks up the records, one finds that he most certainly did so. He supported the tax on potable spirit, on brandy, at that time. Senator Messner has said that we have not kept our promises. We have not taxed wine. There is a reason for the tax on the spirit, which he knows full well. It came out of a recommendation by the Auditor-General .
—That is a smear on the industry.

—It is not a smear at all. The avoidance possibilities flowed from the fact that there was a substantial gap between the excise-inclusive value of potable spirits, which attracted rates of excise ranging from $16.69 to $20.08 per litre of alcohol, and the value of excise-free 2J spirit-that is the spirit that is used to fortify wines-for fortifying wine, a little under $2 per litre of alcohol. That is used also to make up or extend potable liquor at a very real cost to Budget revenue. The Auditor-General, in a 1982 report on the efficiency audit on the excise collection, noted:

SPEECH.PARA: In Audit's view, a major risk in this commodity area is the use of what need only be a small proportion of duty free production-be it alcohol produced by the major distilleries or spirit produced by wine fortifiers or vignerons-to extend or make up potable liquor of various kinds.

Also, a spokesman for the potable spirits industry has recognised the potential for this substitution and has recommended that it be reduced by the imposition of a $2 per litre of alcohol excise on fortifying spirit. These recommendations were put to the previous Government and to this Goverment and, since the Budget, similar representations from spirits and brewing interests have been received urging the Goverment not to change its decision on this matter.

Any government that did not take account of an Auditor-General's point of view such as that would be irresponsible. I also believe that the wine industry is a very fragile industry. We all understand that. The spirit industry, whether it is for spirit or for potable spirit which makes brandy, is made up of several specially grown grapes-genache and gordo and a few others that escape my memory. The industry was virtually destroyed when the excise on brandy was increased to such an extent that brandy was dearer than whisky. In these circumstances people just refuse to buy brandy. It is as simple as that. The industry was also being destroyed by an increased importation of cheap brandies. Our law insists that Australian brandy must be made from grapes. However, the cheap brandies that come into this country would never see a grape. They are distilled from grain. We just cannot compete against the imported product. I think that problem also has to be taken into consideration.

The industry recommended to the Government that the rate of excise be reduced from $2.61. I might add that representations were also made by every South Australian Labor Party member and senator. We believed that the industry was being hit too hard, and we made no apology for that. As a result of representations from the industry and Labor politicians, the excise was reduced to $1.50 a litre. I believe that that is a substantial reduction. If it were not for people purchasing the cheaper product I doubt whether this reduction would have ever been made.

I understand the wine industry in South Australia as well as anyone. I realise that it is a very fragile industry, no matter which government is in power. People must understand that changes cannot be made overnight. They must realise that changes have to be undertaken over a longer period-perhaps five years. It takes five years to adjust. I believe that the industry would be well advised to accept some form of tax such as a sales tax. Eventually the industry will be taxed. The previous Liberal Government as well as this Labor Government have been subject to a lot of pressure from brewers and people in the industry. However, the industry will not be able to avoid paying some form of duty in the future. I believe that it would be in the interests of governments of any political pursuasion and the wine industry as a whole to get together and to agree to a sensible form of taxation. I do not believe that it is of any use an industry coming along to any government and saying: 'We do not want to be taxed. No tax is available'. That is the difficulty.

Honourable senators on this side of the chamber refute that the Government did not honour its promises. It did. We simply took into account the recommendations of the Auditor-General. As I said, it would be a very foolish and irresponsible government that did not take that into account. We have to gain revenue. I believe that we have not hurt the industry. This measure will add only a few cents to the cost of a bottle of fortified wine. As I said, it will not hurt the industry at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted under the sessional order for the consideration of General Business having expired, the Senate will proceed to the consideration of other business.

—by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented. I wish to make a personal explanation. My friend and colleague from South Australia, Senator Elstob, referred in the remarks he made a moment ago to the strong protest I made in my first speech in the Senate about the imposition of a brandy tax. It is true that I protested most strongly on the behalf of the Riverland and other grape growing areas of South Australia. I did not make the exact statement that he cited that I would never support a tax upon wine. The words in my maiden speech in September 1978 would indicate that. I am glad that he has the impression that I am a vigilant and strong supporter of the grape growers and wine producers in my State of South Australia.

—by leave-I wish to make a brief personal explanation. In yesterday's Hansard of 19 October my name is incorrectly recorded as a negative vote on the second reading of the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill 1983. My constituents might not consider it such a joke; they might take it seriously. I have checked the Senate record and the mistake was made either in the Hansard report or by the printer. I ask that the correction be made before the weekly Hansard is printed.
—That correction will be made to the Hansard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments made by the House of Representatives be agreed to.

I might briefly for the record describe what is involved. The Government in the House of Representatives successfully moved four amendments to the Freedom of Information Amendment Bill during its passage in that chamber today. The amendments are necessary to clarify the scope of the Ombudsman's new power to represent, or to arrange representation for, applicants before the Amdministrative Appeals Tribunal. The amendments are consistent with the intention of the Committee of the Whole in agreeing to, on the motion of Senator Missen and rather against the inclination of the Government, the insertion of a new part 5A in the Act to expand the role of the Ombudsman. Amendment (1) is to clause 27 of the Bill. It constitutes new section 52E of the parent Act. It makes clear that the Ombudsman cannot represent an applicant where the decision under review by the AAT is a decision of a Minister. The amendment is consistent with the exclusion of ministerial action from the Ombudsman's ordinary complaint receipt and investigation jurisdictions.

The second amendment is also to clause 27 of the Bill, new section 52E. It makes clear that the Ombudsman is not excluded from representing an applicant where the decision under review by the Adminstration Appeals Tribunal was made by a person in the exercise of a power delegated by a Minister. Amendments (3) and (4) amend clause 30 of the Bill and insert a new clause 31A in the Bill respectively. These are consequential upon the insertion of new Part VA in the Act, which expands the role of the Ombudsman. They repeal section 57 of the parent Act an accordingly delete all references in that section to the Ombudsman and all references to that section elsewhere in the Act.

I will say one other thing while I am on my feet in relation to a proposed amendment from Senator Haines which I indicated that the Government would give further consideration to in the Bill's passage across King's Hall. In the Senate , Senator Haines moved an amendment to clause 4 of the Amendment Bill proposing a new section 72A that would confine the extension for documents from intelligence organisations to documents that are 'relevant to the work of such organisations'. I gave an undertaking to give further consideration to that proposal before the Bill appeared in the House of Representatives. There are adequate checks and balances in the system to ensure that the provision as it stands is not misused. On consideration of Senator Haines's amendment, the Government takes the view that it would not be appropriate to amend the Bill in the manner she suggests. Appropriate administrative directions, can be given, however, and will be given. At the moment I am drafting letters to send to Ministers accordingly. As I understand it, that is consistent with the spirit of Senator Haines's proposal and certainly acceptable to her. With those short remarks, Mr Chairman, I commend the amendments to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is, of course, in support of the amendments that have been moved by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). The Opposition is pleased that the Government accepted the primary amendments-to which these are simply a tidying up-which were moved by Senator Missen in this chamber in the Committee stage of the Freedom of Information Amendment Bill and which were supported by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very interesting and certainly experimental extension of the role of the Ombudsman in several respects, but in particular in his role of counsel, to use a general term. As I said, we wish to express our satisfaction that the Government has accepted this amendment, because although it was passed by the Senate some real doubt was expressed by the Attorney-General as to how far the Government would be able to accept it. It is a pleasing result all round and I trust that this legislation will now be passed without any further delay.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Button) proposed:
That the Senate-

(a) notes that Ministers have provided statements of their private interests, and those of their families of which they are aware, and that copies of those returns have been presented to the Parliament as a matter of public record;
(b) is of the opinion that all Senators should provide similar statements of their private interests, including those of their families of which they are aware, covering the following matters:
(i) shareholdings in public and private companies (including holding companies) indicating the name of the company or companies,
(ii) family and business trusts and nominee companies-
(a) in which a beneficial interest is held, indicating the name of the trust, the nature of its operation and beneficial interest; and
(b) in which the person or immediate family is a trustee, indicating the name of the trust, the nature of its operation and the beneficiary of the trust,
(iii) real estate, indicating the location (suburb or area only) and the purpose for which it is owned,
(iv) directorships in private companies, indicating the name of the company, its activities and the total amounts of its assets and liabilities,
(v) partnerships, indicating the nature of the interest, the activities of the partnership and the total amounts of its assets and liabilities,
(vi) liabilities (excluding short-term credit arrangements) indicating the nature of the liability and the creditor concerned,
(vii) the nature of any bonds, debentures and like investments,
(viii) saving or investment accounts, indicating their nature and the name of the bank or other institutions concerned,
(ix) the nature of any other assets (including collections, but excluding household and personal effects) each valued at over $5000,
(x) the nature of any other substantial sources of income,
(xi) gifts valued at more than $250 received from official sources, or at more than $100 where received from other than official sources,
(xii) any sponsored travel or hospitality received, and
(xiii) any other interests, such as membership of organisations, where a conflict of interests with a Senator's public duties could foreseeably arise or be seen to arise;
(c) agrees that a public register of Senators' statements of their private interests referred to in paragraph (b) should be established;
(d) agrees that Senators should provide such statements on an annual basis and that amended statements should be provided if alterations in circumstances occur ;

(e) agrees that notwithstanding the lodgement of statements by Senators and their incorporation in a public register individual Senators should declare any relevant interest if they participate in a debate in the Senate or vote in a division in the Senate; and
(f) requests the Standing Orders Committee to consider and report upon:
(i) what changes to the Standing Orders may be required to give effect to the matters contained in paragraphs (b) to (e), and

(ii) the desirability of adopting other provisions relating to Members of Parliament contained in the Report of the Committee of Inquiry into Public Duty and Private Interest (except constitutional matters, but including, in particular, a Code of Conduct).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion was put before the Senate originally some weeks ago, I think on 5 October, by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). At the same time he made a statement on the motion and on certain actions which were being taken by the Government relating to the disclosure of interest by Ministers. This is a very important matter for the Senate and for this Parliament. I suppose that it would be possible to debate it in the rather heated terms which have been used in both the House of Representatives and in this place over recent days and weeks on matters of the particular interests of senators and members. But I think that would not be appropriate or constructive. I think it is important that the Senate examine with very great care the propositions which are being put before it by the Government in this motion and endeavour to find some common ground on how we ought to deal with the matters which are raised by the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government, in moving the motion and in tabling certain papers, made some very large claims. I believe the Government said, for example, that never before in the history of this Parliament have Ministers disclosed publicly the private interests which they hold. I think it is true that in the past the systems of disclosure which have been required have been systems of disclosure to the Prime Minister of the day. They have not been matters which have been put before the public. The rationale for what the Government is doing is set out early in the statement made by Senator Button. He said:

The public-the electors of this country-are entitled to have confidence in the integrity of their elected representatives; to know that Ministers of the Government will perform their duties without fear or favour; to be reassured that a Minister's private interests-whatever they may be-do not conflict with his or her public duties in holding the high office of a Minister in the Federal Government.

I think that we would all agree with that statement. It is, therefore, a matter of debating not that objective but the appropriate means which should be adopted by this Parliament to contribute to that worthy objective. The Opposition has reservations about the particular course which the Government has followed. There was an earlier debate in the other place on the matters raised by the motion. I would like briefly to refer to some comments that were made by Mr Sinclair, who led for the Opposition in the House of Representatives. He said:
The Opposition supports the desirability of a way to meaningful disclosure of areas of possible conflict of interests by members of this House.
He went on, however, to point out that we cannot prescribe propriety. He said:

The consequences of public disclosure inevitably are that the dishonest will take steps to make sure that they are not caught out. The honest will reveal their hand and leave their families and themselves subject to the intrusion on their privacy of which the erratic and politically eccentic, regrettably, of our community are capable.
He went on to say:
The Opposition welcomes the concept of this motion and the opportunity to debate it. But in our view it is totally inadequate for the purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—That was Mr Sinclair in the House of Representatives. I would like in the time that I have to give some indication of why the Opposition has some reservations and to support the alternative course which the Opposition will put before the Senate in the form of the amendment which has been circulated in the chamber. We suggest to the Government that the better course would be to refer the issues raised by the motion to the Standing Orders Committee for consideration and report, prior to final decisions being taken by the Senate as to what courses of action should be required of senators. Indeed, the statement which was originally put down by the Leader of the Government in the Senate suggested that, with respect to some of the issues at least, that was the course that the Government proposed. On page 8 of the original typescript of the statement by Senator Button he said:

SPEECH.PARA: One question is whether the registration system should be compulsory or voluntary. If the Senate ultimately decides upon the latter and a senator refuses to provide a statement I am sure that people-especially the electors concerned-will be able to make their own judgment about that particular senator.
Prior to that he said:
The Committee--
that is the Standing Orders Committee-

will also be asked to look at the other recommendations of the Bowen Report ( apart from those relating to the Constitution) affecting senators and members. I shall be presenting a notice of motion today giving further details and proposing referral to the Standing Orders Committee for consideration and report .

What we have in fact is a resolution which does not really refer these matters to the Standing Orders Committee for consideration and report; rather, it refers the matters to the Standing Orders Committee so that that Committee can consider and report upon, to quote from Senator Button's motion, 'what changes to the Standing Orders may be required to give effect to the matters'-matters contained in the earlier paragraphs of the resolution. So we have, effectively, not consideration of the issues by the Standing Orders Committee but simply consideration of the mechanics whereby those objectives are meant to be adopted by the Senate without further discussion or consideration. I believe that is not the right way to be going about it. In fact, Senator Sir John Carrick raised that issue with Senator Button at Question Time on 11 October. He asked whether it was the intention of the Government that the Standing Orders Committee should report on the question of compulsory or voluntary registration and that the report be debated before any decision is made. Senator Button, a week or so ago, said to the Senate:
I do not recall the precise details of the statement--
He went on to say:

But, as I recall, it is the intention of the Government that in respect of non- Ministers who are members of the Parliament the question which Senator Sir John Carrick quoted as one which should be addressed to the Standing Orders Committee should be addressed to the Standing Orders Committee and that consequent upon consideration of that matter by the Committee it would then be debated again in the Parliament.
The answer is slightly equivocal--

TALK.START.PARA: —Meaningless one might say.

—It may be meaningless but it does suggest that these issues shall be given Standing Orders Committee consideration and then debated in the Parliament. It is the objective of the Opposition, in moving the amendment to which I previously referred, that the Standing Orders Committee should consider and report upon these matters before the Senate finally determines its view and makes it known.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, I will move the amendment circulated in my name. It leaves out all paragraphs from (b) to (f) and inserts substitute paragraphs which substantially correspond with the Government's motion but which in all cases permit further consideration of the more fundamental issues to be in the hands of the Standing Orders Committee, report back to the Senate and then, of course, an opportunity for us to determine the final position. I move:
Leave out paragraphs (b) to (f), insert the following paragraph:
'and (b) requests the Standing Orders Committee to consider and report upon-
(i) whether all Senators should provide similar statements of their private interests, including those of their immediate families of which they are aware, covering the following matters:
(A) shareholdings in public and private companies (including holding companies) indicating the name of the company or companies;
(B) family and business trusts and nominee companies- (I) in which a beneficial interest is held, indicating the name of the trust, the nature of its operation and beneficial interest, and
(II) in which the person or immediate family is a trustee, indicating the name of the trust, the nature of its operation and the beneficiary of the trust;
(C) real estate, indicating the location (suburb or area only) and the purpose for which it is owned;
(D) directorship in private companies, indicating the name of the company, its activities and the total amounts of its assets and liabilities;
(E) partnerships, indicating the nature of the interest, the activities of the partnership and the total amounts of its assets and liabilities;
(F) liabilities (excluding short-term credit arrangements) indicating the nature of the liability and the creditor concerned;
(G) the nature of any bonds, debentures and like investments;
(H) saving or investment accounts, indicating their nature and the name of the bank or other institutions concerned;
(J) the nature of any other assets (including collections, but excluding household and personal effects) each valued at over $5,000;
(K) the nature of any other substantial sources of income;
(L) gifts valued at more than $250 received from official sources, or at more than $100 where received from other than official sources;
(M) any sponsored travel or substantial hospitality received; and
(N) any other interests, such as membership of organisations, where a conflict of interest with a Senator's public duties could foreseeably arise or be seen to arise,

(ii) whether a public register of Senators' statements of their private interests referred to in sub-paragraph (i) should be established and whether there should be a private register held by the President,
(iii) whether the provision of material by a Senator to the register should be on a compulsory or voluntary basis,
(iv) whether Senators should provide such statements on an annual basis and whether amended statements should be provided if alterations in circumstances occur,

(v) whether, notwithstanding the lodgement of statements by Senators and their incorporation in a public register, individual Senators should declare any relevant interest if they participate in a debate in the Senate or vote in a division in the Senate and if so what might constitute a relevant interest and in what way should it be declared,
(vi) what changes to the Standing Orders may be required to give effect to the matters contained in sub-paragraphs (i) to (v) of this paragraph; and

(vii) the desirability of adopting other provisions relating to Senators and Members contained in the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Public Duty and Private Interest (except constitutional matters, but including, in particular, a Code of Conduct).'.

I earlier quoted the objectives that the Government set for itself in tabling the statements of the Ministers and in moving this motion. But I believe there have to be very severe doubts that the proposals which are before us actually meet the objective set. What has been exposed by the Government in the motion, in the statement of the procedures which have been followed by Ministers and in the papers which have been tabled raises questions rather than provides the answers which are sought.

I refer to just some of what I see as the deficiencies in the arrangements which the Government is suggesting should apply. One of the deficiencies is that under the disclosure provisions which the Government is urging upon us, a man with $1 will be seen in exactly the same light as a man with $1m. I suggest to the Senate that the public perception would be that a person with $1 in a bank account is in a very different position from a person with $1m in a bank account . Yet, under the exposure provisions which the Government has implemented with respect to its Ministers, under the provisions which it believes must apply to senators and members, there is no distinction between the man with $1 and a man with $1m. Under these provisions there are real doubts about the extent of disclosure by spouses. We find that the Government quite reasonably says that people should disclose. Ministers have provided statements of their interests and of those of their families of which they are aware, but of course that leaves a very large hole. How much are Ministers aware of; how much are they unaware of; and what are the various attitudes of their spouses to disclosure? It is on the public record that some wives of Ministers regard this as an affront to their privacy and something to which they should not be subjected. There is a real issue of principle here, as well as practicality, as to whether what is proposed by the Government is effective with respect to families and spouses.

There is no attempt to expose the quantum of debts. I would have thought that one of the most critical things which might determine whether a Minister is likely to be subject to improper pressure is the extent to which he is in debt. Certainly the fact of certain debts is exposed in the register but the quantum of debts is not exposed and we have the very odd situation that a Minister who is perhaps indebted to the tune of 30 per cent of his asset value appears in exactly the same light as a Minister who is indebted to the extent of 200 per cent of his asset value. There is no comparison between the risk situation involved and the sort of judgment which might be taken. I would have thought that the degree of indebtedness when compared with one's worth is, if any of these things matter, a significant indicator of risk.

I suggest to you, Mr President, that the provisions relating to companies are quite inadequate. The Government has tried to come to grips with some of the recommendations of the Committee of Inquiry into Public Duty and Private Interest of July 1979. Some attempt has been made to get behind the company veil . I refer to the form which the Government is using for the returns which Ministers have lodged. I will turn to Senator Button's return because he has a nil return in this particular part. I have no wish to raise the situation of any particular Minister. Let us look at Senator Button's return. We have a requirement that shareholdings in companies should be exposed. Where there is a beneficial interest held in shares of a private holding company, the name of the holding company and the owner of the shares, and the names of the companies in which the holding company has shares will be disclosed.

So the Government has made some attempt to pursue that line. Senator Button might remember that we asked him some questions about this. But there is no requirement for other interests of companies to be exposed. There is no requirement for the sort of interests which are required of Ministers personally in terms of their investments, their other assets, their other substantial sources of income, the partnerships of which they are members and the liabilities which they might have. None of those things are required to be exposed. It does seem to me that the Government has lifted just one tiny corner of the corporate veil with respect to ministerial disclosure and has ignored other possible very substantial areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I might interrupt, while you are on this point you might help us by telling us what a nominee company is in that form, if you have any views on it.

—That is just one of the many hundreds of questions that I think can be, without rancour, asked about what is being put down. I appreciate the interjection from the Leader of the Government because I think it does advance further the point I am trying to make.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to a few personal matters which are not required to be disclosed but which I believe genuinely go to the extent to which there is a risk of ministerial or other impropriety. From my experience in the criminal law-I am sure all honourable senators will be pleased to know that I have experience in that area as well as in tax--

TALK.START.PARA: —As a lawyer.

—From my experience in criminal law, as a lawyer, one of the high risk elements that appear in the cases of those employees who are charged with stealing as a servant is that they are gamblers and they go in over their heads. That is a very common sort of situation. Is a man a gambler on a large scale? Quite frankly, I suspect that that is a much more significant question to ask if we are concerned about possible corruption than the question of whether a Minister owns a house, a car or has a mortgage on his house. The question of a man's religion might be relevant. A great deal of the issues debated in this place contain elements which give rise to questions of religious concern- prejudice, if you like. Support for church schools is a case in point. I support them because I support that system. No doubt that is something which is related to the particular religion that I profess. That is not required to be exposed. I note there was some reference to that in the House of Representatives by Dr Klugman.
—And a man's sexuality, too, in certain cases.

—Certainly a man's sexuality might be raised. After all, look at Burgess, Maclean, most recently the late Mr Blunt, and all those matters and the arguments that run from them. The situation concerning de factos has been raised in Question Time, too. We have before us the suggestion that the parliamentary superannuation system should be extended to cover the situation of de factos. If we are to superannuate de factos, presumably we will also expose their interests under this declaration. There seems to me to be some doubt there.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the question of current accounts. Short term debts are not required to be disclosed. After a very quick flick through this register, I think that the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, is the only person who has indicated-I speak from memory-the fact that he has a current account. I am sure that all Ministers have current accounts. It does seem to me to be odd that bank accounts of one sort are relevant and bank accounts of another are not. I refer to the existence of insurance policies. Again, I think that only one Minister disclosed that he has insured his life. If I were a Minister in the present Government I would want my life to be insured for a very high amount. There appears to be only one element of disclosure. I do not suggest moral turpitude, but that is an important element of some people's assets. Insurance companies are among the major investors in Australia.

A whole series of questions can be raised. By way of interjection, the Leader of the Government queried certain elements as to what was meant by the expression, I think, 'nominee companies'. It is quite clear that there is a great deal of doubt in the minds of Ministers about what is meant by the requirements that the Government has laid down. I do not want to labour the point, but all honourable senators would be familiar with the fact that there have been 10 amendments to the original declarations. A series of Ministers-I think nine Ministers-have managed to put together 10 corrections in these early days. Again, I do not try to score a point at the expense of the Ministers concerned. All I suggest is that the requirements are rather vague. If it is difficult for Ministers to know what is required of them, I suggest that there is something wrong with this set of rules. There has been some caustic comment that for a Minister to not know that his wife is earning $53,000 a year is a rather extraordinary omission. I do adopt that as a view. I wish that my wife earned $53,000 a year. I would be horrified to think that if she were earning it I would be unaware of it. One could go on multiplying those examples.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you point to the question that elucidates that answer?
—It was very clear.

—That may be very clear. I am grateful for the sotto voce interjection by the Attorney-General. It is clear that it was overlooked. If I am to stand here in an attempt to achieve some agreement in the chamber, I do not wish to raise accusations; I simply want to raise the fact that this is obviously something of a defective system as far as Ministers are concerned in the extent to which it has operated so far. The fact is that there are many difficulties and faults. The fact is that they all need working through. I believe we should adopt the course of allowing an all-party group-I am quite happy for it to be the Standing Orders Committee-to look at these propositions and to come back to us with some, I would hope, agreed solutions to some of these problems. The Government has suggested that, after all, the gentlemen of the Press Gallery ought also to be involved in this matter, but it says: 'Let the Press Gallery come to us with suggestions'. I think it would be appropriate for the Government to say to the Senate: 'Let the Senate come to us with suggestions as to how those objectives can be met'.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not a matter of mere partisan concern, particularly in the context of the current period of sittings. It is fairly difficult to debate this matter because there is so much accusation and counter-accusation flying around the Parliament. Any objections which are raised with regard to the immediate passage or the passage of the Government's proposal are likely to be greeted by cries of : 'Liberals and Nationals have got something to hide'. That is not the case. I have no concern about my personal affairs which I can think of. I refer to some of the objections which were raised by a Labor member of Parliament when the matter came on for debate in the House of Representatives. That speech, which Dr Klugman made in the House of Representatives on 5 October, commences at page 1390 of Hansard and touches on a whole series of points. I do not have time to deal with them all. Dr Klugman pointed out some of the deficiencies in what is being proposed. He said it was depressing that one-third of the Ministers had to correct within a fortnight the statements which they gave. He said it was depressing that a Minister did not know that his wife's income was $53,000. That was considered to be a substantial source of income. He pointed out that perhaps the Government was asking that members of the House of Representatives and senators to provide a similar statement. He said that we certainly would not want similar statements to those which have been submitted by Ministers; we would like something which was a little more accurate in the first instance. Dr Klugman also pointed out that almost everything we do in this place involves a conflict of interest.

Last week the Senate passed a Bill which lifted the wages pause. Nobody in this place acknowledged the fact-I may have referred to it in a speech-that that legislation lifted the freeze on the salaries of members of parliament. It permitted the Remuneration Tribunal to go back to work to look at increases for members of parliament. I am not suggesting that there is anything improper in that. It is just one of a thousand examples of how almost everything we do affects us as well as the general populace. If we adjust the tax laws and do something about the marginal rate of tax for people earning more than $30,000 a year, do we all stand up, one at a time, and indicate that we are all affected by it? There is this sort of endless stream of examples. I think it would be very helpful if honourable senators sat down and worked out just what sorts of conflicts of interests we were concerned about, which ones have to be taken into account and which ones have to be accepted as simply part of the fact that we are all part of the Australian community and are affected by every action of this Parliament.

I turn to the amendment which is proposed by the Opposition. I wish to explain the differences which exist between what we propose and what the Government proposes and also make some queries about what is in the proposal itself. What the Opposition is proposing is not that there should be rejection of what the Government is putting forward, but rather that the Standing Orders Committee should consider and report upon the matters which are being put forward. That is the fundamental difference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or some other all-party committee.

—I have no particular concern about whether it is the Standing Orders Committee. Some all-party group should report back to us on these matters . It should report back, for example, on whether all honourable senators should provide statements of their private interests which are similar to those provided by Ministers, including those of their immediate family, of which they are aware.

SPEECH.PARA: In our amendment we suggest that we should report on whether there should be a public register or whether the register should be private. I would have thought that was a matter which could clearly involve differences of opinion and was one on which we ought to try to develop some common view. There is a difference in our proposal, because we are asking that a committee consider whether the register should be compulsory or voluntary. We are asking for a much more careful approach to the question of declaration of interests. I suggest that the sort of remark that is contained in the Government's statement really inadequately embraces the very real difficulties that exist with respect to the declaration of interests. Anyone who has had experience in local government would know how fraught with difficulty the provisions of the local government Acts are with respect to declarations. With the greatest good will in the world one can foul up or just not follow correct procedures because of the complexity of situations that arise. Let us remember the situation concerning former Senator Webster and the difficulty of applying the constitutional provisions to him which ultimately had to be determined in the High Court of Australia. In that case there was no malice; there was nothing hidden. There was just a great complexity of rules.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a crook judgment by Barwick.

—I will try to maintain the same even stance throughout the rest of the debate. That was a very good example of how there was something which was not hidden, something which had been going on, and there was a very technical question as to what the individual's position was under a conflict-type provision. What we are seeking is some consideration by an all-party committee on what might constitute a relevant interest and in what way it should be declared. I have already given some examples of why I think there are difficulties there. Does a person with children who are attending a private school declare an interest each time we debate education? Does somebody who has a company declare an interest every time we deal with anything that has to do with companies legislation, company taxation matters and so on? The list is endless.

SPEECH.PARA: I would hope that after consideration the Government would be prepared to allow that sort of consideration of this proposal, as is suggested in the Opposition's amendment. Let me make it quite clear that we will put the amendment. If the amendment fails we will not divide on the motion itself. We would not wish to be seen as opposing and we would not wish to be opposed to the principle of disclosure and the principle that we should not act in an area where there is conflict of interest. We are suggesting very seriously to the Government and the Senate that these matters need much more careful consideration.

I raise some of the points which I think need more careful consideration. What is the requirement in sub-paragraph (d) that private companies should indicate the total amount of assets and liabilities? I understood that amounts would not be required. That is what the statement says. The statements of Ministers' pecuniary interests indicate that amounts are not being shown. Yet the statement suggests that the total amount of assets and liabilities should be shown. I think that needs to be examined. I think the exclusion of short term credit arrangements and current accounts needs to be considered. Why is one form of bank account required to be disclosed and another form not? Why is life insurance omitted from the list of things which should be disclosed, given the key role of life insurance companies in investment in Australia? Why should gifts of more than $100 received from other than official sources be disclosed in all cases? I confess to the Senate, Mr President, that on my fortieth birthday my wife bought me a watch which cost in excess of $100. I say that is nobody's business but my own. I have now told the Senate. But I suggest there are endless examples of gifts which it is absolutely ludicrous to suggest that we put on to a register.

Whilst I accept that there is a validity in seeking the disclosure of some forms of gifts, should we not look a little more closely at whether that is a sensible provision? Do we really believe that any hospitality or substantial hospitality should be exposed? Does one have to enter it into the register each time one has a lunch which one does not pay for, whether it is with a trade union or whatever interest group? That sort of question really needs to be considered if we are to get a sensible answer.

I could go on. I simply wish to put to the Senate that there are a whole series of matters which need to be considered more carefully. I think there are real doubts about the effectiveness of the Government's proposal. I think it is ineffective. I think real dishonesty can easily be hidden away. I think there are elements of farce in what we have before us. I find it utterly ludicrous that $1 can be the same as $1m in terms of a register. I suggest that the question needs to be raised: What are the sorts of interests that are most critical? Is the owning of a house in Australia something that is likely to be significant? On the other hand, is something which is not required to be exposed significant? I pick an instance from the recent past. A senior politician had over $4,000 in cash on him in various currencies. I think that most impartial observers would say that, if we are looking at the question of what is likely to indicate a problem, carrying large amounts of cash was more significant than having a house in the suburbs.

I think that this effort which may be, on the part of the Government, an utterly genuine attempt to come to grips with what is seen by some as a significant problem ought not to be allowed to founder by having it thrust down the throat of the Senate when there are significant questions which need to be answered and where, I think, there really would be great value in more sober consideration on an all party basis and a debate which could follow that sober consideration. I commend the amendment to the Senate. I hope the Government will use the period of delay which it is prepared to permit in this matter-we have had it before us for many weeks-to constructive effect by seeing it sent off to a committee for further consideration. I think to fail to do so would be not to display the qualities which the Government claims for itself. I trust therefore that on this occasion the Government will have a second thought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the concept and thrust of the move by the Government. But, at the same time, we agree with everything that Senator Chaney said. I regret that Senator Button, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, is otherwise engaged at the moment. We hope that the Government will sympathetically receive the request from Senator Chaney and the Opposition because it makes so much sense. As Senator Chaney has conceded, all wisdom does not reside in the Senate Standing Orders Committee. But I think the thrust of the Opposition's amendment is that the matter should go to an all party committee to iron out some of the anomalies and some of the requirements in the Government's motion which, to quote Senator Chaney, border on being farcical. However, because of the reason so delicately mentioned by Senator Chaney that we are living in times when accusations and counter-accusations are flung around about members' assets, one dares not take any sort of move that would allow some mischievous person, whether he be in politics or in the media, to say: 'Ha, the Liberals or the Nationals or the Democrats are trying to hide something'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats, whilst supporting the thrust of what the Liberal Party is doing and commending it for that action, will support the Government if this matter is taken to a division. We plead with the Government to look carefully at what Senator Chaney and the Opposition said. I will not repeat what Senator Chaney said because there is no point in doing so. But although we support the concept of what the Government is doing, we note that the provisions of the motion do not, by and large, demand that amounts of money be disclosed. What is the point of being forced or requested to disclose the value of a house if no money amounts are involved? The house could be, to use Melbourne as an example, in a slum area in Fitzroy and worth $20,000 or it could be in the heart of Toorak and be worth $1m. But there is no requirement for the disclosure of value.

We note that spouses have been included in the motion. A reason could be made out for including the assets of a spouse. On the other hand, this impinges, very dramatically, on the notion of an individual's rights. Does not the spouse of a senator or a member of parliament have the right to have her or his assets and income remain private? Indeed, as Senator Chaney said, some spouses-I wish the plural of the word 'spouse' were 'spice'; it would make so much more sense-may well not want to disclose and will, in fact, refuse to disclose to their parliamentary spouses what their assets are. We note that the Government's motion, after providing that Ministers must submit certain statements, requests us to vote today on the provision that 'the Senate is of the opinion'. That is all we are required to vote on now. The motion states that 'the Senate is of the opinion that senators' should do certain things. I note that that is optional. Senator Button made the point that the media and the public can make a judgment about a senator who chooses not to disclose various matters that are listed in the accompanying statement. I hope that the Government will prevent itself getting into the sort of mess it is bound to get into if it does not adopt the sort of suggestion that Senator Chaney made. If the Government tries to enshrine these recommendations in legislation, it will be in all sorts of trouble. At that point, as far as the Democrats are concerned, we would look very closely at what the Government puts into the legislation. For example, the motion states:
That the Senate-. . . .
is of the opinion that all Senators should provide similar statements-
to Ministers-
of their private interests, including those of their families of which they are aware . . .

What is a family? That is a fair question. In the Minister's speech it is defined as the spouse and dependent children. One deduces from that that non- dependent children are not members of the family. What sort of a gaping hole is that for someone, a member of parliament or a senator, bent on mischief to divest some of his assets to a non-dependent child? Are not the assets of de factos and partners included? Obviously in the Minister's definition they are not. Surely there is an overwhelming reason for them to be included.

I notice that liabilities are about to be disclosed, but it does not say whether that means amounts. What is the point of asking that liabilities be declared if no amounts are given, as Senator Chaney mentioned? Then the motion comes to the point of absurdity when it says that the nature of any other substantial sources of income must be disclosed. What does 'substantial' mean? That is not defined anywhere. Paragraph (xi) states:
gifts valued at more than $250 received from official sources, or at more than $ 100 where received from other than official sources . . .

That is a cute one. I assume that means that when members of parliament go visiting overseas, either as leaders or members of a delegation, and are given a gift, that is an official source. I presume that is what it means. To put a value on those sorts of things again brings this matter to a point of absurdity. Strictly speaking gifts of more than $100 from other than official sources include birthday presents from one's wife and children or other family members. Also to be disclosed is:
any sponsored travel or hospitality received . . .

What does 'hospitality received' mean? On the occasions that I visit overseas I stay with friends. Do I ask them what they value their accommodation to be? I understand that several parliamentary delegations are leaving for overseas this week or next week. When all of those members and senators return will they have to disclose the value of the hospitality that they have received? Paragraph (e) states in part:

. . . notwithstanding the lodgment of statements by Senators and their incorporation in a public register individual Senators should declare any relevant interest if they participate in a debate in the Senate or vote in a division in the Senate . . .
What about a pharmacist, for example, who is voting on a pharmaceutical benefits Bill?

TALK.START.PARA: —Or a doctor.

—Or a doctor voting on Medicare, and a thousand other examples? That is not spelt out. I do not need to canvass the ground that Senator Chaney did so competently. All I say is that we support the thrust of what he said, but I do take some heart from the Government's attitude. Senator Button has given his assurance that the matter will be treated reasonably and that Senator Chaney 's comments will be taken into consideration. The motion states that this matter will be referred to the Standing Orders Committee for it to consider and report upon what changes to the Standing Orders may be required to give effect to the matters contained in the paragraphs of this motion. I would not like to be a member of the Standing Orders Committee charged with this job. One would hope that when this matter does go to the Committee, as the motion will be passed this afternoon, members of that Committee would look at the questions that Senator Chaney and I have raised this afternoon to make sure that the thrust of what the Government is doing, which is commendable, makes some sense and does not lapse into absurdity. Therefore the Democrats hope that the Government does pay some attention to what has been said this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILL:
APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 2) 1983-84]
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for lunch I was talking about some of the dangers of acid rain. Some of the areas that are effected by it get rain as acidic as vinegar. In Los Angeles acid fogs with a pH level of up to 2.2 have been recorded. The honourable senators who have any knowledge of a pH scale will realise that a pH of 2.2 is becoming very acidic indeed. I certainly would not like that kind of acidity on my skin or in my eyes or lungs for too long. Of course acid rain does not always come down just where the coal-fired station is. It can be dumped downwind many kilometres away. I would not like to live downwind from a coal-fired station.

SPEECH.PARA: Some people may have heard of the arguments that are going on between the United States and Canada about this matter, and in Europe too, with so many millions of people and so many oil and coal-fired stations and very large populations in small areas. It is not always possible to tell just who is responsible for any acid rain that may fall in a particular area, so we have tension between nations, both in Europe and in the Americas, and not a lot can be done to reduce this problem. Scrubbers can be installed in the stacks to try to get rid of the sulphur emissions from coal burning, but they do not remove all of it and they are very expensive to operate. In fact the cost of acid rain limiting-that does not mean it is got rid of, it is just limited-in the mid- western and eastern United States power utilities would cost somewhere between $ US3,000m and $US7,000m. Of course that would be a cost that would have to be passed on to the consumers.

Even in Australia, with our small population and low densities of industry, the effects of acid rain are becoming known. For Australia, most probably the main danger of burning a lot of coal is the increase in temperature that may result over the long term from that burning of fossil fuels. An article in the Australian today was headed: ' ''Dire consequences'' in global warm-up'. A report was given to the United States Environmental Protection Agency that tells just what kinds of dangers are likely in this world if we continue burning fossil fuels at the expected rate. We need only a small increase in temperature in this world to melt gradually the ice caps in Antarctica. If they were to melt totally, the level of water in the oceans would rise by some 30 metres. Those honourable senators with any knowledge of geo- graphy would realise that that would inundate a lot of very important areas for food growing in this world and would inundate a lot of the areas where people live. The greenhouse or warming effect is something that I believe that the world should be starting to worry about at this time.

As well as acid rain from the coal stations there is of course the ash problem that I think Senator Jessop spoke about the other day. We all hear of coal mining accidents that occur from time to time. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short list of accidents involving working days lost, prepared for me by the Commonwealth Parliamentary Library.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have mentioned just a few of the drawbacks of coal fired stations. I think I should mention also that, although Australia is blessed with great quantities of coal, even those supplies will not last forever, and we should move towards preserving that coal for other purposes. I believe that Australia should be moving into nuclear technology. We should be educating youngsters in our schools that atomic power is an engineering problem and that as time goes on the problems will become fewer and fewer. We should be expanding the physics and engineering schools in the universities of this country so that we can build safe and efficient atomic power stations of the highest standard that has been determined as satisfactory. We should be educating the lay people that atomic power stations are not controlled explosions, that the fuel that is used is nowhere near the weapons grade and that weapons cannot be easily and cheaply made from power-station by-products. Senator Jessop on 7 September, incorporated a document that went into that matter. I draw that document to the attention of anybody who is interested in this so-called problem of proliferation. Anyone wanting to build atomic weapons would build a special facility, not just try to obtain the ingredients from a power-station, as some anti-uranium people tried to imply.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that it is time that we let some of the private enterprise companies of this country decide whether it is economically feasible to develop a uranium mine. I think there is too much government interference in that kind of area. Mining is not the mere pursuit of profit. It is not a sacred right of those who would dig up minerals. Its purpose is to produce resources which are of vital need to the world-wide community of mankind. Many eminent people have agreed that nuclear power is a necessary and irreplaceable source of future energy for mankind in both the short and the long term. Australia, with some 17 per cent of the world's low cost and easily mined uranium, is in a favourable position to supply this uranium for commercial power. It would therefore also be in a position to influence the correct use and development of the stations and play a part in the future international co-operation for nuclear waste disposal. That is a matter which I should like to deal with at some other time.

It is simple logic that as long as nuclear energy remains the only low cost alternative to using our fossil fuels, which are being rapidly exhausted, with the inherent dangers that I have mentioned, we should pursue the opportunities which are offered to this country by its luck in having so much uranium. Some people would be saying, I suppose, that we should be using the wind, that we should be using tidal, solar, or some other kind of power. Some of these things could produce some power but it is not cheap and it is not proven. None of them satisfy or could satisfy the requirement in this world for massive quantities of low cost power. Atomic power has been proven to be the lowest cost, cleanest and best type of power for big quantities, and none of the other sources could possibly go close to supplying the power that would be needed. Sir Barton Pope, on page 7 of the book 'Challenge to Australia' says:

With the notable exception of water and petroleum which must cause concern, Australia is more potentially rich on average than others on mineral resources, particularly for energy related fuel. Australia, or any other country, must not anticipate selfishly withholding its resources from desperate and needy nations. The world must become closer knit and interdependent. Compassion must displace selfishness.
On page 13 he says:

Nuclear energy has got right out of perspective and understandably is clouded with emotionalism with its initial application to war. Science and the world nuclear industry must stand rebuked for remaining so remote from the community at large who have unfairly been left uninformed and vulnerable to misinterpretation.
A little further on he says:
Our very survival may well depend on the use of nuclear power for civilian use.
The world in the next century will become acutely aware of the great debt to nuclear science and will pay tribute to its creators.
Towards the bottom of that page he says:

A Nobel Prize would be totally inadequate recognition for the scientist and those millions so spared would owe a great debt of gratitude to the opponents of nuclear for civilian use who, when better informed, had the courage to reverse their expressed opposition and emotionalism of today.
I should like to remind the Senate of what Sir Mark Oliphant said in the same book. At page 32 he said:

. . . it is impossible to put the clock back, to wipe out the nuclear knowledge which made the weapons possible, or to forgo the peaceful uses of nuclear energy in a world where fossil fuels, especially oil and gas, are being depleted rapidly.
On page 34 he said:
Withholding Australian uranium would not prevent the erection of a single reactor, or the production of one nuclear weapon, in a world where 50,000-60,000 such weapons already exist.
He also said:

As one who has been involved all my life in nuclear physics and nuclear energy, who has participated in many international discussions with soviet and other workers in these fields, and in scientific and technical aid to developing nations, who is committed to the search for peace, I am convinced that Australia would be foolish not to mine, use, and sell uranium. Nuclear power stations are now far less polluting, and are safer, than coal-burning equivalents.

I think I would have to agree with the headline which appeared in the Australian on 13 October, which stated 'There is no alternative to nuclear power'. That was on an article by Des Keagan, an article which I suggest it might be of value for those people who have doubts about uranium to read. Finally I should like to quote from an article Leslie Kemeny which appears on page 13 of the Mining Review of August/September 1983 in which it is said:

The future of the eight billion inhabitants of planet Earth around the year 2020 will be vitally influenced by our recognition of the above facts today. Uranium is not a tool of political gamesmanship. It is the only viable option for the maintenance of the increasing energy needs of mankind for at least the next five decades.

I have tried to cover a few of the points that relate to atomic energy today. There are many others that I should like to go into as time goes on, because it will be a continuing debate and one that should be kept before the people of this country until it gradually sinks through that those who are opposed to the use of uranium for peaceful purposes are a very vocal minority. I believe that they are a dangerous minority because, as I said at the beginning of this speech , Australia is a country that is very much in debt. If we allow these people who would stop our exports of, say, uranium, coal and iron ore, by shipping strikes- Australia has got a terrible record in this area-countries will get those materials alsewhere, and our standing within financial circles will become very bad. We might reach the situation where people will worry about whether we will be able to pay our bills, just as we in this country worry about whether some of the countries in South America can pay their bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —There can be no doubt that the Budget for 1983- 84 must have been very difficult to frame. Indeed, the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) in his speech on the Budget said it:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . . may have been the most difficult to frame in the last 10 years.

I certainly would not dispute that. 'The economy sank deep into recession in 1982-83'. That sentence is a quotation from Budget Statement No. 2 headed 'The Budget and the Economy'. An overview of the economy is given in that statement. I seek leave to incorporate that statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
STATEMENT No. 2-THE BUDGET AND THE ECONOMY
Overview

The economy sank deep into recession in 1982-83 as the forces instrumental in bringing the earlier expansion to a halt-principally large increases in domestic costs, international recession and high domestic and overseas interest rates- exerted a continuing influence, and as widespread drought took its toll.

Private investment fell sharply and private consumption spending weakened. In response, imports fell and stocks were reduced markedly. Fiscal policy became much more stimulative but the impact of this was not felt until the second half of the fiscal year. As business responded to high labour costs, a slump in profitability and weakening demand, employment contracted sharply and unemployment spiralled to rates not experienced since the 1930s.

Finance was readily available over most of the year as reflected in the relatively high growth of most of the financial aggregates. Despite falls in overseas interest rates and the depth of the domestic recession, domestic interest rates remained relatively high under the influence of continuing inflation and large and rapidly increasing public sector borrowings.

Wage increases slowed as the labour market deteriorated and the 'wages pause' took effect in the second half of the year. Inflation continued at a high rate and by the second half of the year was more than double the average of our major OECD trading partners. Increased productivity and a slowing in wages growth brought only a partial unwinding of past increases in real unit labour costs and business profitability and cash flow continued to be depressed. Reflecting these pressures the value of the Australian dollar declined substantially over the year.

A continuing application of fiscal stimulus, the breaking of the drought, inventory cycle effects and a strengthening in the economies of some of our major trading partners indicate an improved outlook for domestic economic activity during 1983-84. However, with uncertainties regarding the durability of the pick-up and the level of labour costs still contraining employers' reactions , and with the labour force continuing to grow, some further rise in unemployment during the year can be expected.

The task ahead is to ensure that the pick-up in domestic economic activity in prospect for 1983-84 is sustained and transformed into lasting recovery. For that to occur it will be essential that the cost and price moderation which began in 1982-83 should continue and be supported by appropriate, and consistently applied, economic policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I draw attention to the first paragraph of that overview in which very briefly the forces bringing about that recession are listed. They include large increases in domestic costs, international recession, high domestic and overseas interest rates and a widespread drought. In effect, what that document is saying is that wages increased but number of hours worked decreased so that the cost of producing goods increased enormously in Australia. At the same time as this country was involved in the world recession, high interest rates continued. The result was the deep recession which has caused us so much concern. The second paragraph of that overview states:

SPEECH.PARA: Fiscal policy became much more stimulative but the impact of this was not felt until the second half of the fiscal year.

The point I want to make to the Senate is that it is clear that the Government did what any driver who was driving his vehicle up a steep hill would do, that is, to change to a lower gear. There has been much criticism of the former Government for its Budget overrun, but it is clear that the reason for that Budget overrun is set out in that statement. Fiscal policy had to become much more stimulative in order to try to resolve the difficulties which this economy was facing. So, the Government changed gear. Budget Statement No. 2 states further:

A continuing application of fiscal stimulus, the breaking of the drought, inventory cycle effects and a strengthening in the economies of some of our major trading partners indicate an improved outlook for domestic economic activity during 1983-84.
We are looking at a better situation during 1983-84. Of course, in the last paragraph of that overview the Treasury put the situation very firmly:

The task ahead is to ensure that the pick-up in domestic economic activity in prospect for 1983-84 is sustained and transformed into lasting recovery. For that to occur it will be essential that the cost and price moderation which began in 1982-83 should continue and be supported by appropriate, and consistently applied, economic policies.

That, of course, has been a major concern of many of us in this chamber and in the other place. We have raised with the Government the question of its supporting a 4.2 per cent increase in wages which must flow into other costs. As I and others have pointed out previously, it will probably result in employers paying 30 per cent or 40 per cent more than the wage increase in trying to meet that bill plus all the extras that go with it. Yet it will result in an insignificant sum being received by the employee.

I recognise the merit of what the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) said on previous occasions when he said that we do live in a real world and there must be, on the part of government, some recognition of the demands of employees.
