Nevertheless, I suggest to Senator Walsh and to the Government that if they had tried they could have persuaded not only the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission but also workers around Australia to accept, for the sake of their unemployed colleagues in particular and for the sake of the economy, a lower increase in their wages at this stage. Perhaps the Government may even have succeeded in deferring the increase until the end of this year. It may very well have been that the Government could have persuaded them that indexation was not essential at this time. However, that is the economic situation which the Government has obtained for itself. The Government is clearly responsible for this increase in wages. The Government will have to carry the burden of that responsibility. I wish it success because, like all people around Australia, I would like to see the economy of this nation improve.

I wish to lay to rest once and for all the allegations and, in fact, misinformed statements about the Budget deficit of $9.6 billion. It strikes me as almost unbelievable that we have honourable senators like Senator Jones and one other Australian Labor Party senator saying in the Senate that the Budget deficit last year was $9.6 billion. They clearly believe that the Budget deficit for 1982-83 was $9.6 billion. I wish that Senator Walsh and other Ministers in the Government who know what last year's Budget deficit was would bring these fellows to heel and tell them to start talking sense. The Budget deficit last year was $4.473 billion. That figure is set out throughout the Budget Papers. If honourable senators opposite were only to apply their minds to the Budget Papers they could see that quite clearly. Just so that they do know for certain that what I am saying is true, I now seek leave to incorporate in Hansard part of Budget Statement No. 5 headed 'Budget Outcome 1982-83' which sets out the main features of the 1982-83 Budget.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
The main features of the 1982-83 Budget outcome were as follows:
an overrun of $2799m (to $4473m) on the deficit estimated at budget time, partly attributable to lower than expected economic activity, and partly to discretionary decisions;
total outlays of $48 982m, 18.5% higher than 1981-82 and 4.1% greater than the budget estimates;

main contributions to the outlays overrun of $1915m over budget estimates were increased payments for unemployment benefits, natural disaster relief payments for drought, capital injections to TAA, Qantas and the Australian Shipping Commission, increased equity payment to AUSSAT, drought assistance to farmers through interest and fodder subsidies and higher public debt interest payments;
total receipts were below the budget estimate by $884m or 1.9%;

most major receipts categories fell below budget estimates, primarily because of a weaker labour market and a lower level of economic activity generally than was assumed at budget time. For example, gross Pay-As-You-Earn (PAYE) collections were down $261m, sales tax $139m, customs duty on imports $131m and traditional excises, $114m;

there appears to have been a major, albeit unquantifiable, shortfall from the $ 615m expected to be collected as a result of increased penalty rates for late payment of taxes due in earlier years. This was an aspect of the collection shortfalls from personal income tax on assessment ($247m) and company tax ($232m );

there were also shortfalls of $175m from estimated collections under the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Act and of $50m from the Bank Account Debit Tax, reflecting delays in implementing the 1982-83 Budget measures and also a subsequently revised (and narrower) scope to the unpaid company tax legislation; and
only the crude oil and LPG levies and net receipts from government enterprises yielded significantly more than the budget estimates (by $199m and $225m respectively).

A major part of the deficit overrun was attributable to the automatic response of receipts and outlays to the sharp decline in the economy. It is estimated, however, that somewhat more than $200m of the receipts shortfall and a significant proportion of the outlays overrun did not reflect automatic influences, but rather such factors as new policy decisions (including those in respect of drought and flood relief and financial assistance to Commonwealth transport authorities) and delays or subsequent changes in the implementation of Budget measures. In this sense, a substantial proportion of the deficit overrun could be regarded as reflecting the post-budget decisions of government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw attention to the first paragraph which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The main features of the 1982-83 Budget outcome were as follows: an overrun of $2799m (to $4473m) on the deficit estimated at budget time-
Then it gives the explanation. It says:
partly attributable to lower than expected economic activity, and partly to discretionary decisions.

So it is clear, as I mentioned earlier, that as there was lower than expected economic activity, what happened was that the Government changed gear and made discretionary decisions to increase expenditure in order to try to overcome some of the horrific results of the recession that we were facing. What I have just incorporated in Hansard goes on to set out the matter clearly. I hope that some honourable senators, especially Government senators, will apply their minds to it and read the various points that are raised, particularly in the last paragraph, which says:
A major part of the deficit overrun was attributable to the automatic response of receipts and outlays to the sharp decline in the economy.

I know that Senator Walsh will rise shortly and attack the former Government and deliver all sorts of diatribes about its Ministers, but there is no doubt that if the Labor Party had been in Government in 1982 it would have adopted a similar course. I challenge Senator Walsh to say whether it would not have adopted a similar course and whether he does not consider that these were the sorts of things that a government faced with this sort of economic downturn would have done. Of course Labor would have done them. But the point is that the Budget deficit for last year is clearly $4.473 billion, $4.5 billion in round figures, and not the $9.6 billion which fools-that is what they are-keep talking about.

Where does this figure of $9.6 billion come from? It comes from a projection of the 1982-83 expenditure into 1983-84, and it is then calculated, as a projection forward of all of that expenditure, to work out to $9.6 billion. But this new Government has now acknowledged that there are revised growth figures from the unreal levels that were used in the March deficit calculating starting point to forecast that $9.6 billion. It has now admitted that the revised growth figures have added at least $1.4 billion to revenue. So that reduces the $9.6 billion, anticipated, by $1.4 billion at least. That would bring it back to $8.2 billion. Then in addition this Government claims that it cut $1.2 billion from expenditures that it anticipated that my party would have continued during 1983- 84. If the Government was capable of reducing it by $1.2 billion, I suggest my party in government would have been capable of reducing it by $1.2 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Probably by $3.2 billion.

—As Senator Archer has said, probably by $3.2 billion-because time after time Mr Fraser and Mr Howard demonstrated their ability to reduce the Budget deficit very substantially from what was anticipated might be the result of the various demands on the Government during the Budget run-up. However, on the Labor Party's own figures, the estimate of $9.6 billion has been reduced by $2.6 billion. What the Labor Party then did was to go out and spend. On its own figures the Government has spent, under this Budget, $2.5 billion, on its own initiative. If one applies one's mind to that subject, one realises that it has spent $2.5 billion on its own initiative, having effected the savings that I have mentioned, and it has come up with a Budget deficit of $8.4 billion. So if we take off the $2.6 billion, we are at a deficit of about $6 billion. So if the Labor Party wants to attack my party and Mr Howard and Mr Fraser for what they estimated the Budget deficit for 1983-84 would have been under a Liberal- National Party government, it should be attacking us for coming out with a Budget deficit of about $6 billion. Let us be generous with a billion dollars and say $7 billion. But in any event, it would have been $1.4 billion at least, or $2.4 billion, or some such figure, less than what the Labor Party has come out with, because this Budget has budgeted for a deficit of $8.4 billion, on the Government's figures. It is the Government's Budget. It is not our Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: All this talk about $9.6 billion is absolutely rubbish. It is rubbish whether it comes from Senator Walsh in his diatribes or from any other foolish senator who picks up such figures, starts relating them, and then, incredibly enough, wants to relate them back and say that it was last year's Budget deficit and not a projection for this year's Budget deficit. The figures will show that last year's actual Budget deficit, despite the enormous overrun-and I acknowledge that there was an enormous overrun as a result of the Government's changing gear and of the problems that the economy was facing-was only 2.8 per cent of gross domestic product. Of course, the GDP was down enormously as a result of the problems of rural income and the problems of non-rural income arising from the recession. We had the drought and other factors affecting the rural income, and we had the economic problem affecting the non-rural income, and still the Budget deficit was only 2.8 per cent of GDP; whereas this year's Budget deficit, notwithstanding the improvement in the economy, notwithstanding the massive improvement in particular in rural incomes--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 4.7 per cent.
—Is 4.7 per cent of GDP. Let Senator Walsh deny that that is a fact.
—I have just confirmed it.
—I am sorry, Senator. I take it back. I know that Senator Walsh, despite his diatribes, is frequently honest with his figures.
—I said it was 4.7 per cent before you did.

—Sometimes Senator Walsh misleads the Senate fractionally, but usually, if one pins him down, one finds that he is honest with his figures. He has confirmed that the Budget deficit for this year is estimated to be 4.7 per cent of gross domestic product. Last year's actual figure was only 2.8 per cent of GDP, notwithstanding the problems that the Government faced. So, could we please hear the end of all the nonsense of criticism of last year's deficit. Let us try to make sure that 1983-84 is a successful year for this country and that 1984-85 is an even more successful year.

SPEECH.PARA: I have already drawn attention to the enormous importance of the Government's wages policy. I wish it success because it will be of vital importance to the Budget outcome and, of course, to the resulting economy of this nation. I am concerned, as I am sure Senator Walsh is concerned, that one of the problems might very well be that, as a result of the indexation of wages, when the economy does recover wages will leap off from a higher base than perhaps that on which they would have been had they not been indexed. I turn to another matter of grave concern. Today I received a letter from the Lutheran Laymen's League of Australia Inc., which stated:
Many are asking, 'How many of our parliamentarians can still be trusted?' Promises are made one day and broken the next without batting an eyelid.

I would like to apply that quotation to the present Government and the promises which it made. Let us go through some of the broken promises of the Government to date, remembering that it has been in office for only a few months. The Government promised an immediate reduction in income tax for almost six million Australians. Of course, as all of us knew, it could not keep that promise! Senator Walsh knew before the last election that there was no way it could keep that promise. But he was part of an organisation which went around Australia supporting these sorts of promises. He knew that it was not possible to carry them out. He will stand up and say that it was not possible to carry out the promise to make tax reductions because of the Budget deficit figures. But he knew what the Budget deficit figures were going to be. He knew that there was an enormous overrun. he knew that the economy was in deep decline. Yet he was part of a group of people who stood before the people of Australia and said that there would be tax cuts for six million Australians. He is laughing now because he knows that that was an absolute lie and a deception of the people of Australia. Of course it was; and Senator Walsh acknowledges that.

The Government also broke its promise that it would not change the tax on lump sum superannuation payments. Well, glory be! Lump sum superannuation payments gave people an opportunity to invest in this nation. I know that people such as airline pilots get enormous sums on retirement. But what do they do with their money, even if the sum involved is a quarter of a million dollars? They do not take it out and sink it in the sea or something like that. They reinvest it in this nation. The economy is all about the flow of money. These people were not damaging the economy. But this Government grabbed them in a place where it really hurt. It has destroyed superannuation. It has destroyed the opportunity for the people of this country to go forward and make savings. One of the fundamental principles of Australians under Liberal-National Party governments has always been that people save for their future. But the Australian Labor Party taxes the hell out of people's futures the first opportunity it gets on gaining office. Yet, the Government promised that there would not be such a tax.

The Government promised that it would maintain the home loan interest rebate- another broken promise; that it would keep the health insurance rebate until the introduction of Medicare-another broken promise; that it would not means test the over-70s pension-another broken promise; that it would not introduce an assets test-another broken promise; that it would abolish the pharmaceutical declaration form-another broken promise; that it would increase the spouse and sole parent rebates-another broken promise; that it would maintain drought relief to help the rural recovery-another broken promise; that it would adequately compensate Tasmania over the dam-another broken promise; that it would remove sales tax on retread tyres-another broken promise; that it would reduce the price of petrol by 3c a litre-another broken promise; that it would reduce the charges for private patients in public hospitals by $60 a day-another broken promise; that there would be no more job losses in the steel industry- another broken promise; that it would maintain real funding for local government -another broken promise; that it would lift the tax threshold to $5,000 or $5, 893 for pensioners-another broken promise; and that there would be no tax on wine-another broken promise.

Yesterday we debated in this Senate another 15 broken promises or dishonoured assurances to the education community of Australia. The Labor Party really has come into government and in a few short months has absolutely destroyed all faith in politicians right around the nation. How can anyone believe politicians anywhere? As the author of the letter I quoted said:
'How many of our Parliamentarians can still be trusted?' Promises are made one day and broken the next without batting an eyelid.
He continued:

Clearly we have reached a time when there needs to be a complete overhaul of procedures and legislation, particularly as they relate to powerful employing bodies, the industrial scene, the work-force generally, the public service, the media and our own political system.

This Government has displayed a complete failure to treat the people of this nation properly and decently. Its failure to fulfil so many promises is really almost beyond description. I am staggered to think that a government could be elected with such a massive majority and then just turn around and quite wilfully disregard all of the promises it has made and treat the people of Australia as if they are fools. The fact that the Government and its leader have such an incredibly high popularity rating is, I think, beyond description.

I find, as I go around the community, that people tell me what they have lost. What have they lost? They have lost their superannuation benefits. They have lost their income tax rebate on health insurance; they have lost their home deposit assistance scheme; they have lost the housing interest rebate scheme; they have lost the tax concessions on home insulation; members of the Defence Force reserves have lost their tax exemption in respect of pay; people have lost the $1,000 dividend rebate for investing in Australian companies; they have lost concessions in respect of school fees at non-government schools; they have lost because of postal and telecommunication charge increases as well as all of the State increases that have been imposed by State Labor governments around this country; they have lost because of the increased cost of petrol as a result of increased excise and the reduction of the freight equalisation scheme; and they have lost the value in their pensions as a result of the Government juggling the consumer price index. For what? If it had been for the benefit of the unemployed , if in some way this Government had formulated a Budget which might have helped to increase employment in this country, the people of Australia willingly would have lost this sum of money. Whatever the amount is. I have estimated that about $1.4 billion has been ripped off the people of Australia. The people would have willingly forgone that sum if they could have seen some reduction in the unemployment level or some proper approach towards budgeting to provide jobs in this country. Of course, what has happened is that the Government has abandoned the unemployed of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —We still have the Sex Discrimination Bill though.

—As Senator Harradine says, the Government has not abandoned the Sex Discrimination Bill, but it has abandoned the unemployed. There is nothing in this Budget for the unemployed. In fact, Mr Hawke's greatest promise was about employment. Right at the beginning of his policy speech, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: There are tremendous issues involved in this historic election on 5 March-first and foremost, the right of all Australians to a job . . .

That was what he said when he opened the election campaign for the 5 March election. He went throughout Australia saying: 'This election is about jobs, jobs, jobs'. Notwithstanding that, there is nothing in this Budget to reduce the level of unemployment around the nation and that will be verified when the figures come out in 12 months time. The people of Australia will then see that unemployment has not fallen in any way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — Apparently the list of speakers in this debate has been shortened. All speakers, other than myself, on this second reading debate have now completed their speeches. I do not intend to speak for very long because the matters of detail and real substance which any honourable senator may wish to pursue can be taken up at the Committee stage of the debate. I will make a couple of comments about Senator Lewis's speech which I just heard. I thought it was quite good, incidentally, until he went on with all that nonsense about superannuation. I thought it was quite a well presented speech until then. I will take up one of the challenges that he laid down. Senator Lewis challenged me to respond to a proposition. He assembled that if Labor had been in government in 1982-83, it would have brought down the same sort of Budget as the previous Government.
—No, would have increased its expenditure to cope with the economic downturn.

—I am sorry, that was not my understanding of what was said. I will comment on the sort of Budget we would have brought down. We certainly would not have brought down the sort of Budget brought down in 1982-83, which was a Budget without any economic strategy. Its strategy was solely political; it was designed to have the previous Government re-elected in a premature election. It was replete with bribes directed at electorally sensitive groups, mostly in the tax expenditure field, and the cost of which was mostly deferred. One of the very serious problems confronting this Government in forming this year's Budget was that revenue losses of the magnitude of $1 1/2 billion were thrust into this year's accounts as a result of the heap of tax expenditure bribes offered by the previous Prime Minister in the 1982-83 Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government addressed itself to those matters. It also set in operation a number of other significant taxation reforms, the revenue gains of which will be deferred to the financial year 1984-85. When the figures are adjusted for both the bills acruing from tax expenditures approved by the previous Government in 1982-83 and the gains to revenue deferred into 1983 and 1984-85 by changes made to the tax system by this Government, it will make a difference of about $3 billion to this year's figuring. In other words, the previous Government left us with this legacy of debt, the payment of which had been deferred into the next financial year.

I make a very general comment about the Budget. All Budgets, of course, entail judgments, both value judgments and economic judgments. The sorts of value judgments that are included in this Budget are the sorts of economic judgments which any Labor government would have to make. The principal consideration is the people who have suffered most from the present recession, the unemployed. So far as additional funds can be made available from government expenditure, those funds should be targeted towards the unemployed. Hence the very substantial increase in the rate of benefit to the most disadvantaged people even among the unemployed group-that is, the single unemployed and the dependants of the unemployed in general.

I will not attempt to go into the economic judgments in detail. The Government, after considering all factors, made a judgment about the appropriate size of the deficit. Some argued-and in some cases presented quite respectable statistical evidence-in favour of a larger deficit than that the Government finally chose. I think the point that such serious analysysts have overlooked is what Keynes probably would have called animal spirits and what, more recently, was called business confidence. I refer to the fact that the Australian community in general and the business community in particular have been conditioned to believe over many years, throughout the seven dark years of Fraserism, that if the deficit rises necessarily inflation rises, interest rates rise and unemployment goes up. However shaky the statistical evidence in support of those assertions may be-it is at best equivocal-if such perceptions are sufficiently widely believed they are likely to become self-fulfilling. That was a matter which the Government had to consider when making its judgments.

The crucial element in the Government's strategy for the restoration of sustained economic growth and a reduction in unemployment, of which this Budget is a part, is an effective prices and incomes policy. An examination of the sad economic history of the 1970s shows that those half dozen or so nations which have throughout that dark period managed to maintain low rates of unemployment, low rates of inflation and acceptable rates of economic growth are, without exception, those which have had-whether formally enshrined and recognised or not -an effective prices and incomes policy. That is the key, the foundation stone, of this Government's economic policy. I do not propose to delay the passage of the Bill any longer and suggest that the second reading vote be taken.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Senator Walsh) agreed to:
That consideration of the Bill in Committee of the Whole be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The purpose of this statement is formally to foreshadow and outline the major amendments to the Sex Discrimination Bill to be moved on behalf of the Government. There are 53 Government amendments to that Bill. A number of these provide drafting and grammatical improvements or are designed to clarify the effects of particular clauses of the Bill. The remainder are amendments made as a result of comments invited and received since the introduction of the Bill in June 1983. A 'Black Type' printed memorandum showing the changes proposed to be made to the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 by amendments to be moved on behalf of the Government has been prepared and provided to honourable senators, as has now a list of the text of the Government amendments and an accompanying explanatory memorandum, all three documents which I now table.

SPEECH.PARA: I further indicate that for the convenience of honourable senators and the expedition of the debate, it is proposed-with the co-operation of the Senate officers-to prepare a consolidated list of all amendments when the amendments proposed to be moved, if any, by the Opposition, the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine come to hand, as I hope they will very shortly, so that such a list might be able to be prepared well in advance of the Committee debate.

The Government has consulted widely on the Bill, and received many useful and constructive comments on its provisions. In particular the Government has benefited from the very practical comments received from the Counsellor and Commissioners for Equal Opportunity appointed under the sex discrimination legislation of New South Wales, South Australia and Victoria. A number of organisations, including the Business Council of Australia, the Australian Parents Council, the Life Insurance Federation of Australia, the Life Insurance Council, and the Coal Industry Association, have made detailed representations on various aspects of the operation of the legislation, as have a number of individuals. The Government has, where possible, accommodated the major concerns raised by these organisations and individuals. In addition, the Government has held discussions with representatives of the Opposition and of the Australian Democrats and with Senator Harradine, and has accommodated their concerns where possible. I turn now to a brief explanation of the major amendments to be moved by the Government.
Exemptions Relating to Work

A number of Government amendments will be moved concerning exemptions from the provisions of the Bill relating to work. An amendment will be moved to clause 12 (3) to limit the exemption permitting discrimination on the ground of sex in relation to domestic duties in the home so that it applies only to the hiring of staff.

The Government will move that a new clause be inserted into the Bill to create new exemptions permitting discrimination on the ground of sex in relation to the hiring of staff for the residential care of children and on the ground of marital status in relation to the hiring and firing of staff where the duties of the position involve the residential care of children and it is intended that the person's spouse would also be employed-for example, as house parents in children's cottages.

In relation to the employment practices of educational authorities, the Government will propose a new exemption permitting discrimination on the ground of sex, marital status or pregnancy in relation to the hiring or dismissal of staff by a school established for the provision of education in accordance with the doctrines of a religion or creed if the discrimination is done in good faith in accordance with the doctrines of the particular religion or creed.

The substance of the amendment proposed by the Opposition relating to exemptions for educational and child care authorities has been accepted but the Government amendments are worded differently and provide for exemptions from the specific clauses of the Bill dealing with hiring and firing, rather than providing the general exemption sought by the Opposition. The effect of this is that the Government amendments will not enable discrimination in the terms and conditions offered to staff or on which they are employed-in relation to pay, for example. Such discrimination would have been possible under the wide exemption sought by the Opposition, and it is for this reason that the Government has not accepted this aspect of the Opposition's amendment.
Exemptions Relating to Education

An exemption will be created permitting discrimination against students or applicants for admission as students on the grounds of marital status or pregnancy by schools established in accordance with the doctrines of religion or creed if the discrimination is done in good faith in accordance with those doctrines. This exemption is also in accordance with the Opposition amendment referred to earlier. A Government amendment will be moved in response to the report of the Senate Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills to clarify the exemption for single sex schools. The Government amendment will provide a further exemption where education at a level at which the applicant is seeking education is provided only or mainly for students of the opposite sex. This is intended to cover situations where, for example, schools are primarily single sex but operate on a co-educational basis at some level.
Provision of Services

The Government will move an amendment to clarify that the legislation does not cover services which by their nature can be provided only to persons of one sex- for example, certain medical services or procedures. This amendment is in response to concerns raised by Senator Harradine.
Discrimination Involving Sexual Harassment

The provisions relating to discrimination involving sexual harassment will be slightly modified, including by extending the coverage to the situation where the person has rejected an advance, refused a request or objected to conduct and as a result has actually been disadvantaged in relation to employment.

The Government will move a number of amendments to ensure that the provisions of the Bill dealing with sexual harassment are applied throughout Australia on the same basis as the provisions of the Bill dealing with other forms of discrimination. An amendment will be moved to clarify the Government's intention that the legislation will not apply to discrimination involving sexual harassment by employees of a State. In addition, the Government has accepted some amendments proposed by the Australian Democrats.
Exemption for Superannuation Schemes

As presently drafted the Bill provides an exemption for two years for discrimination on the ground of sex or marital status in the terms or conditions appertaining to a superannuation or provident fund or scheme in operation at the commencement of the legislation. The Government has received a number of representations concerning these provisions, and in view of the difficulties raised and the complexity of the subject matter, has decided to move an amendment to exempt all superannuation funds or schemes, existing or future, for an unlimited time, but to provide that this exemption may be repealed by regulation. The amendment provides that such regulations are not to come into operation until 12 months after they are made and, in any event, not earlier than two years from the proclamation of the Bill.

The regulations could, of course, be disallowed by either the Senate or the House of Representatives, in accordance with normal procedure. I should make it clear that the Government will not make any regulations until an inquiry into the problems raised by the life insurance and superannuation industry associations has been held and the industry's major concerns have been examined and met, where appropriate. At the same time, the Government is signalling its intention in principle that the Sex Discrimination Act should-and in due course, will-cover superannuation schemes.
Sport

The Government will move an amendment to limit the exemption in relation to sport by providing that persons of either sex can be excluded from any competitive sporting activity where the strength, stamina or physique of competitors is relevant. The Government is of the view that its amendment would accommodate the amendment to the clause proposed by the Australian Democrats.
Clubs

The Government will move amendments to provide that clubs may not discriminate in the terms and conditions of membership afforded to members or where a member in one class of membership wishes to change to another class of membership. The latter amendment was also proposed by the Australian Democrats.
Inquiries and Civil Proceedings

The Government will also move a number of amendments to the provisions for the holding of inquiries into complaints made under the legislation. Major amendments in this category include removal of the restriction on a complainant' s right to seek review by the Human Rights Commission of certain findings of the Sex Discrimination Commissioner, and provision to allow inquiries by the Human Rights Commission to be held in private.
Other Major Amendments proposed by the Opposition

I turn now to canvass briefly major Opposition amendments which the Government has not accepted. Foremost amongs these is the Opposition amendment proposing to delete from the Bill reference to, and reliance on, the external affairs power. The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women (Senator Ryan) and I have already indicated to the Opposition that this amendment is not acceptable to the Government.

The Opposition proposes to oppose clause 82 of the Bill, which deals with self- incrimination. The Government is of the view that the clause as drafted contains sufficient safeguards against the use of information obtained in evidence in proceedings before a court. The Government will, however, move an amendment to the clause to make it clear that the restriction on admissibility of evidence does not apply in respect of proceedings for an offence under clause 83 of the Bill.
Conclusion

For over four months people have had the opportunity to familiarise themselves with the provisions of the Bill. The Government has carefully considered all comments and proposed amendments which have been put. It has accepted amendments which are in accordance with the spirit of the legislation or which appear appropriate for other reasons. It has not accepted, and will oppose, amendments which seek unreasonably wide exemptions from the legislation or which run counter to its intent. The Government again invites the Opposition to reconsider its attitude to the Bill, and to take the plunge and vote as a coalition in favour of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Government amendments to its Sex Discrimination Bill-amendments which have been previously circulated to us and which are before us now-will not enable parliamentarians with a genuine commitment to both sex discrimination legislation and to pro-life values to vote for the Bill.
—That is completely untrue. I have both, and I will be voting for it.

—I hope that Senator Tate will give me the opportunity to explain what I mean by that without jumping straight in in such an emotional fashion. I hope the honourable senator will give me credit for being able to prove to him that that is not so. If he feels it is not so I invite him and the Government to declare that the Bill in its amended form could not be used to widen the scope for deliberately procured abortions, and I include clause 24 in that; to undermine by unreasonable and farcical tests the rights of parents to insist that schools provide an environment conducive to the moral development of their children; to involve non-government schools in damaging litigation to the advantage of opponents of education, justice and freedom of choice--

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. It seems to me that Senator Harradine is debating the substantive issues involved in the Sex Discrimination Bill, which is inappropriate under Standing Orders, given that the Bill itself is clearly on the Notice Paper.
—What were you doing?

—I was, by leave, making a ministerial statement describing for the convenience of honourable senators, not in order to debate substantively the issues, what the Government proposed to accept and not accept in order that the course of the debate might subsequently be clear. I suggest that Senator Harradine's comments, however heartfelt, are in fact out of order at this stage. He will have ample opportunity in debate on the Bill itself to make the points he obviously wants to make.

—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President, I refer you specifically to page 3 of the statement, which, under the heading 'Provision of Services', outlines the Government's amendment and says:

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is in response to concerns raised by Senator Harradine.
I am, in a short statement, attempting to state quite categorically that that is not so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, there is no point of order. You sought leave to respond to the Attorney-General's statement. You may continue.

—Again, I invite the Government to declare that the Bill in its amended form could not be used to violate the conscientious objection rights of individuals with respect to the administration of certain programs and procedures and the provision of goods, facilities and accommodation. There is no excuse now for the Government to refuse to amend the Bill further to make sure it cannot be used for ulterior purposes.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Amnesty International-Northern Territory Criminal Code- Diethylstilboestrol- Queensland Aborigines

PROCTEXT.PARA: Amnesty International-Northern Territory Criminal Code- Diethylstilboestrol- Queensland Aborigines

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to remind honourable senators that this week, 17 to 23 October, is Amnesty International's annual Prisoner of Conscience Week. The theme for the week in 1983 is human rights activists in prison. The October Amnesty International newsletter supplement details a number of case histories of human rights activists who have been imprisoned for non-violent human rights work. The supplement hopes that the Federal Parliament will take action to express its concern about such imprisonments for what are no more than human rights activities. I understand that many members of this Federal Parliament are very actively involved in Amnesty International. Today I joined many of my colleagues in King's Hall at the ceremony of lighting an amnesty candle. It was lit by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at 1 p.m. A petition was signed by many members and senators who were there as representatives of all the parties in this Parliament. On Sunday, 23 October, in Adelaide I will be launching the Amnesty International fun run and breakfast.
—Ha, ha!

—The Attorney-General may laugh. The fun run is a 7 1/2 kilometre run. It will serve to all those who come, and try to trot along, as a reminder of Amnesty International and of the need for continuing effort to urge the release of prisoners of conscience around the world. It will also serve as a reminder of how fortunate we in Australia are, that we are free to run in the sun or the rain while many languish in gaols. We can remember too that it is not only the prisoners who suffer but also their families, relatives and those people in the community who support them. In particular, I draw to the attention of honourable senators the anguish and pain of families of prisoners of conscience.

SPEECH.PARA: The fun run will also remind us of the privilege of our freedom and of the need for constant vigilance, on behalf of human rights, of people in this world and we in Australia, that such behaviour never happens in this country. It is important that we recall from time to time there have been prisoners of conscience in Australia. Our history is not without blot. I believe it is a matter of great pride that Mr Whitlam, in one of his very first acts as Prime Minister of the Labor Government in 1972, granted amnesty or, if one likes, freedom to all those prisoners of conscience who protested at the Vietnam War, either those who had been gaoled or those who had had to go underground to avoid conscription and involvement in that war.

We also need to recall Aboriginal people in this country to know that there is still much for us to be vigilant about. Aboriginal people are fearfully overrepresented in our gaols. They are fearfully represented amongst our poor and our sick. Their human rights are not sufficiently assured. I am glad to be part of this Government that is actively working to improve the rights and services for Aboriginal people in this country and, in particular, the land rights on which so much else for Aborignal people is built. Further, this Government's commitment to human rights is enshrined in its sex discrimination legislation which was recently introduced into this chamber. Again, I remind the Senate of the relative luxury of being us. We can actually devote our energies and efforts to sex discrimination legislation and rights against discrimination in employment and education, while other people in this world are denied their very basic right of free speech. I do not wish in any way to be understood to suggest that our efforts are lesser. I think it is important that we acknowledge the luxury of being Australians. Our basic freedom of speech is, on the whole, guaranteed in this country. The October supplement of the Amnesty International newsletter contains the happy news of the release of four prisoners of conscience. It is probably beyond me to pronounce their names. I seek leave to incorporate the names in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The names read as follows-
Irena Zofia Romaszewska (Poland)
Lee Chae-Oh (Republic of Korea)
Javier Ruiz Vera (Chile)
John Khaminwa (Kenya)

TALK.START.PARA: —One of those persons is a woman from Poland. As I understand the names, the other three persons are men-one from the Republic of Korea, one from Chile and one from Kenya. However, the supplement also contains accounts of many prisoners who are currently in gaol, who are currently undergoing torture and also the other shocking descriptions of people who have simply gone missing following arrest or pick-up. We have no cause for complacency. The accounts are appalling. It is very hard to realise that such horrible behaviour continues to happen and is increasing. Certainly, I find it very difficult to appreciate my brothers and sisters in this world do behave with such horror to their brothers and sisters. I wish to quote from what was said when the Nobel Peace Prize was awarded in 1977 to Amnesty. In making the award the Nobel Committee stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The world has witnessed an increasing brutalization, and internationalization of violence, terrorism and torture. . . . Through its activity for the defence of human worth against degrading treatment, violence and torture, Amnesty International has contributed to securing the ground for freedom, for justice, and thereby also for peace in the world.
The article in this supplement goes on to say:

We in Amnesty International are less confident. Countless prisoners remain. Torture remains. Executions are reported daily. Now human rights run the risk of being dragged into the tangle of international power politics.
The article further commented:
As long as they are incarcerated-
that is, the prisoners-
for their beliefs we must be ready to use our freedom in defence of theirs.
I think that is a line that is particularly relevant and pertinent to us in Australia. I am glad to have this opportunity to commend Amnesty International to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise very briefly in the adjournment debate the response that might be taken to the promulgation of the new Criminal Code by the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly. The Code itself is a massive undertaking. In the normal course of events, one would expect that the clarification of fundamental principles and procedures of the criminal law would be welcome. It could well be that many of the provisions of the Criminal Code which was passed by that Legislative Assembly fall into the category of desirable clarifications and codifications of that law and procedure. In relation to several matters, there is cause for very real concern. For example, in relation to the onus of proof, where voluntary intoxication is involved it is no longer necessary for the Crown to prove beyond reasonable doubt that a person intended to commit a particular crime. Instead, an accused person must prove to the contrary that he or she did not intend to commit a crime. In many cases this makes it almost impossible for an accused person to succeed at trial.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear that this is just part of a bundle of provisions within the Code which try to deal with the problem of intoxication and crimes involving intoxication in the Northern Territory. It is my submission that that fundamental reversal of the golden thread of English criminal law, which says that the onus of proof rests on the prosecution to prove all elements of the crime, including criminal intent, beyond reasonable doubt, is very worrying. As well as that, in cases where an accused is found guilty of a crime involving intoxication, a court can add four years to the stated penalty for the crime. If , for example, the penalty for crime X is imprisonment for two years, if intoxication is involved the judge can award a penalty of six years. Worse than that, section 383 (3), which I will read for the bemusement of the Senate, states:
If the jury finds he-
that is, the accused-

is not guilty by reason of intoxication and his intoxication was voluntary, the Court may order him to pay by way of fine an amount not exceeding the costs of bringing the charge, including the costs of all reasonable investigations relating thereto and the costs of the committal proceedings.

The section goes on to state that in an appropriate case the court may make an order for compensation and restitution. In other words, having been acquitted and found not guilty by the jury on the grounds, amongst other things, that he was intoxicated and the intoxication was voluntary, nevertheless the accused may be required to pay the costs of the police investigation, the committal proceedings and the trial. That is the most breathtaking and audacious assault on our normal concept of what it means to be found not guilty. I would be amazed if there were a more astonishing case. In general, in other words, the Code fails to come to terms with what is a very real social problem, I understand, in the Northern Territory, and that is the incidence of alcoholism and the devastating impact which that sort of disease has on a community which is depressed and deprived.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you object if I said that 'disease' implies a medical model and suggested that you use some other term?

—I am trying to look for a model other than one which leads to a penal and criminal response. I suggest that the answer to the question of alcoholism lies in the public health area rather than in the individual disease area or in some other form of social response than the use of the criminal law.
—Social policy.

—Social policy rather than a penal policy. There are other worrying elements which affect the Aboriginal population in particular. The right of an accused person to make an unsworn statement at trial is abolished. Honourable senators may have misgivings about unsworn statements in Sydney, Melbourne or Hobart. But it is the case, according to those involved in legal service to Aborigines, that Aborigines experience difficulties in giving evidence. There is somewhat of a readiness to agree to propositions put to them. They are vulnerable to cross-examination. Frequently if they appear before courts and are subject to normal cross-examination the outcome is a foregone conclusion. The right of an unsworn statement is said by those commonly associated with the defence of Aboriginal people in the criminal process to be something which ought to be retained with their particular vulnerability in mind.

SPEECH.PARA: I have outlined a serious reversal of the onus of proof. I have outlined some astonishing ways in which the penal law has been used to deal ostensibly with the consequence or the very fact of intoxication. I have outlined some difficulties in the procedural areas of evidence within the court. The Northern Territory Law Society came to this conclusion. It said:

The apparent and significant departures from fundamental principles of criminal law, the apparent confusion as to concepts underlying that law, certain harsh individual provisions, the retention of outmoded concepts, the refusal to recognise underlying social problems and the elimination of established procedures inherent in the code will result in a confused and unsatisfactory state of the law for the Northern Territory.

It called for further debate and consideration of the Code's provisions. I am not sure whether the Administrator in signing that law or giving assent to it has reserved it for the Governor-General's pleasure, as it were, in order for the Governor-General then to have a right to disallow the law. If that is the case, then it follows that the Governor-General would act on the advice of the Executive Council. Therefore, I am asking the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) to indicate whether, in fact, the Code has been reserved for consideration by the Governor-General. If that is the case, is the Attorney- General able to indicate whether some consideration might be given to advising the Governor-General on the exercise of that power? Is he able to do so in relation to matters of substance or is his power of review of matters passed by the Legislative Assembly and assented to by the Administrator only as to, perhaps, procedures within the Legislative Assembly and the process of law making rather than second-guessing the elected representatives of the people of the Territory in relation to the substance of their laws. I can understand that there might be such a distinction and that it might be relevant to the advice which the Executive Council would commonly offer. But, in any case, I think it would be good to see a further response from the Attorney as to the merits of the Criminal Code and for him to give some indication of whether he can bring about a situation to allow for further consideration, if not going so far as to advise the Governor-General not to give his final imprimatur to the Bill, of some of the extraordinary provisions of this Code.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond briefly to the matters raised by Senators Crowley and Tate and leave to my learned colleague, Senator Grimes, the later contributions in this adjournment debate. I am sure all honourable senators, at least those of us with a sincere and genuine commitment to human rights and fundamental freedoms, would be very appreciative of Senator Crowley's contribution and the very effective and, indeed, moving terms in which she spoke tonight of the work of Amnesty International which is an organisation to which many of us in this Parliament belong and an organisation which, very properly, completely crosses party boundaries as well as many others in the international community. Accordingly, we are indebted to Senator Crowley for her contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the matters relating to the Northern Territory Criminal Code raised by Senator Tate, on the face of it there are grounds for concern by reference to human rights standards in relation to at least some provisions of the new Northern Territory Criminal Code. As I have previously publicly indicated, I am, in conjunction with my colleague, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding), having the Code thoroughly examined and analysed. Following some preliminary consideration of it here in Canberra, a senior officer of my Department went to the Northern Territory for six days. He returned yesterday. In the course of that visit he spent a lot of time discussing the terms of the Code with a variety of interested persons and organisations including, in particular, the Government, officials and key consultants responsible for its preparation. I am awaiting now the report from that officer which I expect to receive tomorrow or Monday. I will obviously make recommendations to the Government as to the further course of action, if any, in the light of my consideration of that report and its recommendations.

Senator Tate asked me about the options available to the Government should it appear that there are genuine grounds for concern in relation to at least part of the Code. At this stage, one of the options that might be considered would be to refer the whole question to the Human Rights Commission for inquiry, report and advice. Other possible action, should it appear with or without such a report from the Human Rights Commission that there are grounds for concern, is for the Commonwealth to intervene in a more direct way, subject, of course, to the Territory being unwilling to reconsider such provisions as may be in question in this way. The Commonwealth has available to it the terms of the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act to which Senator Tate made reference. I understand that section 9 of that Act allows the Governor-General acting, of course, on the advice of the Executive Government of the Commonwealth to disallow a Territory law or any part of a law within six months of the Territory Administrator's assent to it. That provision is not contingent upon any specific reservation for the Governor-General's assent. That is the subject of section 8 of the Act.

There are some procedural complexities about the way in which the disallowance provision works. But on the face of it and from the very brisk examination I have given to it so far it appears to be a procedural option, albeit a fairly extreme one, available to the Commonwealth. It is the case, as I have said before, in this Parliament that the Commonwealth retains full constitutional powers so far as the Northern Territory is concerned and, in the context of this legislation, legislative powers. But there are practical limitations that one would apply to the use of those powers except in fairly extreme circumstances. Certainly, no decision of any kind has been made about a Commonwealth reponse to the terms of the Code despite the fact that there are some suggestions to the contrary circulating in the Northern Territory. The situation is as I have described it. I think, probably, there is little more I can usefully add at this stage although obviously this will be a matter on which I will be only too happy to report further to the Parliament when the situation becomes a little clearer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to canvass tonight the problems associated with a drug named diethylstilboestrol. As I understand, it is a synthetic oestrogen which was first synthesised in 1938 by a husband and wife medical team at Harvard University. It was used initially to prevent miscarriages. It was used extensively in Australia between 1941 and 1971 for that purpose, although in 1952 a study in the United States indicated in fact that far from preventing miscarriages it actually appeared to induce them. Indeed anyone who looks up details of this drug, generally known as DES, will find that it was used for an extremely wide range of complaints and effects. Not only has it been used ostensibly to prevent miscarriages but also it has been used to suppress lactation, to actually induce miscarriages, which seems a rather wide sort of extreme, to relieve the symptoms of menopause, to treat acne and to treat certain types of breast cancer. This latter example again seems particularly extraordinary given that by 1971 the Food and Drug Administration in the United States of America was indicating that DES should not be prescribed any longer since it had a proven connection with certain forms of cancer.
—It would have been only a palliative for breast cancer. It would not have been curative.

—The honourable senator certainly would know more about that than I do. I will take his word for it if he says it is a palliative. Nevertheless, if it was indicated to induce other forms of cancer, one wonders how one can use a palliative for one form which is likely to produce another.
—It may not have been alive by the time the second formed, perhaps.
—That may or may not be comforting to the victim.
—I am just-

—Being helpful; yes, I know. I quite understand. What happened of course was that hundreds, indeed even thousands, of women in Australia-and certainly at least that many in the United States-were prescribed a drug which was not only totally ineffective for the condition it was intended to prevent but also resulted first in quite the reverse occurring and, secondly, in serious and often tragic results not only in the takers of DES but also in both their sons and their daughters-that is, the children they were carrying at the time when they were taking diethylstilboestrol. The link between DES and certain forms of cancer was, as I said, indicated in the United States by 1971. According to a pamphlet which is put out by an organisation called DES Action, a large proportion of DES daughters-that is, daughters born to women prescribed DES during pregnancy-have tissue changes of the vagina and cervix. Most of these , the pamphlet points out, are not dangerous. Nevertheless, they are tissue changes. The pamphlet states in part:

SPEECH.PARA: It is known that DES exposure can cause structural changes to the upper genital tract (uterus, tubes and ovaries), the most common and distinctive change being a small t-shaped uterus.

A small number of DES daughters, all under 32 years of age, have developed a rare form of cancer whose name I will not even bother to pronounce, although I am sure Senator Grimes, the Minister for Social Security, who is at the table, is familiar with it. I understand that the effect on sons of women who were taking DES while they were carrying those children includes a higher than normal risk of developing certain gential tract problems including cysts, undescended testes, structural abnormalities and lowered sperm counts. Indeed, according to this pamphlet, some sons may also be infertile. As far as the women who took DES were concerned, the study suggests a possible increase in breast cancer and cancer of the uterus, cervix or ovaries.

DES Action has been campaigning for some time since a number of women in this country became aware of the connection between the use of the drug and genital tract abnormalities and cancer. It has had some small success in Victoria where the Victorian Health Commission has established a DES screening clinic at the Royal Women's Hospital at Carlton. This, I might add, is booked out for something like four months. At present there is a long wait for an appointment at colposcopy clinics at public hospitals and the women in this group are concerned that this is forcing people who want some sort of screening to have to go to private medical practitioners and other specialists and that this of course, is going to cost them money. They believe that there is a clear cut case both now and in the future for all screening and treatment of women who have been taking DES, and of the children to whom they have given birth after taking DES during their pregnancy, to be provided free of charge.

I understand that some time ago the program Sixty Minutes ran a two-segment story on DES which indicated that the drug had been prescribed very widely throughout Australia, which somewhat contradicts a statement made by Dr Cornwall in South Australia that the drug had never been prescribed there. I am not quite sure how he can be so definite about it, but the women who belong to DES Action indicated that after the Sixty Minutes program they received hundreds of letters and calls from all over Australia, presumably including South Australia, and now see the need for co-ordinating a network of screening and information centres across the country. The letter from DES Action to me-and I presume to other senators and members- concluded in this way:

In summary, we firmly believe that there is need for free screening (this needs to be every 6 months for many of those affected) and further, there is need for an effective register and monitoring of these patients. We are therefore requesting that you support our call for:
1. Free medical screening and treatment in adequately staffed and equipped centres.
2. (a) Funding of a nationwide publicity campaign to alert DES daughters, sons and mothers to the problems they may be facing and the need for specialized tests.

I just point out at this stage that it is important for the daughter of a woman who was on DES while she was carrying that child to understand that she may be subjecting herself to additional risk if she takes any extra oestrogen-for instance, via the contraceptive pill.
The letter continued:
(b) Consultation with and funding assistance of DES Action as the resource organization representing DES affected people.
3. Legal and financial help to obtain compensation from the drug companies which manufactured and marketed DES and related drugs as a treatment for miscarriage.
I want to point out here that the drug companies continued to do this despite the fact that it was contra-indicated in 1971 by the FDA in the United States. The letter continued:
4. The establishment of state and federal DES registers so the long term effects of DES can be monitored.

5. Abolition of the use of hormonal growth stimulants in animal and poultry. (It has been shown overseas that these enter the food chain; and it is thought that they may exacerbate some DES-related conditions and thus may further endanger the health of DES daughters, sons and mothers.)
It concludes:
We ask that you raise this matter with your colleagues . . . in Parliament . . .
We would very much appreciate your support and assistance so that some positive action can be taken at the Federal level.

I therefore conclude my comments by asking the Minister tonight whether he is aware of any moves by the Federal Government to assist DES victims in the ways suggested by the convenor of DES Action or in any other way, since it does appear that these women and their offspring were victims of something over which they had no control, that was marketed at first unwittingly but later apparently with the full knowledge of the problems that were involved and who definitely, it seems to me anyway, deserve some sort of assistance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in the adjournment debate tonight to point out what I believe to be a case of the worst type of scraping the bottom of the political barrel. Yesterday the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Wells) asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) to comment on a Courier- Mail article, which, referring to Mrs Lilja, who is the candidate for the State seat of Barron River, states:

SPEECH.PARA: 'Aboriginals there told me of rumours that they would lose their welfare payments and have their children taken away from them if they voted for the ALP, ' she said.

I point out to the Senate that that is a comment on a rumour. I really believe that there would not be too many people in Australia who would have the audacity to believe that type of statement. In an article headed 'Queensland blacks threatened', the Minister's reply was reported as follows:
Political thuggery, blackmail and intimidation were being used to make Aboriginals on Queensland reserves vote for the National Party, Federal Parliament was told yesterday.
The Aboriginal Affairs Minister, Mr Holding, said officials of the State Aboriginal and Islander Affairs Department were responsible.

He told Mr Wells . . . that subordinates of the department's director, Mr P. Killoran, were alleged to have told Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders they could expect to have their children taken away from them, and their social security benefits withdrawn, if they voted against the National Party.

I believe that to comment on a rumour and come back with that sort of attack is stretching political expediency just too far. I believe that the Minister has misused his ministerial powers and position and abused the integrity and the privileges of his office. I also believe that he has denigrated every decent public servant in Queensland. No one in his right mind would believe that anyone could make those sorts of statements, particularly decent, honest public servants. I believe that if the Minister is honest with the people, he will go out and make those statements in the open. Let us see what would happen to him. It is just a political ploy and, I believe, one of the worst kind. As I said before, it is absolutely at the bottom of the barrel and I feel that Mr Holding should be thoroughly ashamed of himself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be dealing with the serious matter first, and it is a serious matter. The matter raised by Senator Haines related to what in fact was a tragedy, the use of diesthylstilboestrol, usually known as DES. As Senator Haines said, it is a synthetic hormone, a synthetic oestrogen, which was used in the 1950s and perhaps in the 1940s as well. I would be very surprised, although I will check on this for Senator Haines, if it were used much beyond the early 1960s in this country. It was used in the mistaken belief that it would prevent miscarriages. Senator Baume may correct me on that, but I doubt whether it was used much here after the 1960s. It was certainly used, like other hormones of this type, as a palliative or even in the belief that it would cure some forms of breast cancer. Many of the oestrogen hormones were used in this way. I am certain that the problems that Senator Haines was talking about would not have arisen out of the use of DES for this condition. I am sure that it is not used at all now. Certainly diesthylstilboestrol was used for the alleged suppression of miscarriages, although it was not effective in that regard. It has certainly been well established that this usage is linked with the occurance in the daughters of women who took the drug of, first of all, non-malignant changes in the vagina and, secondly but less commonly, the occurrence of a rare form of vaginal carcinoma in their daughters and of some serious, but not life threatening, changes in their sons.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter has been raised in the Senate in the past. Former Senator Melzer, who was a colleague of mine, I remember on several occasions raised this matter, particularly as she was interested in the effects and as she was a supporter of DES Action. DES Action has been very active and, as a result of its activity in 1981, a project was developed in Victoria between the Victorian Government and the Royal Australian College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists. As a result of that project the referral clinic that Senator Haines mentioned, at the Royal Women's Hospital in Melbourne, was set up. It produced an excellent information booklet which was made available to all Victorian medical practitioners. It is my understanding that a similar clinic now operates at King George V Memorial Hospital in Sydney and a similar booklet has been made available. Action in the other States, as I understand it, has certainly been less comprehensive, largely because I think of smaller populations and probably the less frequent use of the drug in those States. There were publications of warnings about this drug in 1972 and again in 1975 by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee. It drew attention to the problem. There has been collaboration between this Committee and the Royal Australian College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists in the identification of cases of vaginal carcinoma. I am not sure of the extent of anything else that has been done, but I will certainly seek from the Department more information than that. The National Health and Medical Research Council has also undertaken to keep the matter under review.

We have two problems here. The problems in respect of DES arose initially as an issue of drug safety. It is now primarily a matter of the appropriate treatment of affected persons although, as Senator Haines said, there may be some question about the use of oestrogens aggravating the condition. Daughters of women who took DES. I will check on the medical details of that for her. The provision of treatment, of course, is a State responsiblity. Senator Haines asked, on behalf of DES Action, whether the Federal Government could take some action to support DES Action as a resource group and whether some Federal help could be made available to publicise the problem more and to ease the situation which apparently exists at the Royal Women's Hospital in Melbourne. I will seek the answers to those questions from the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett). I can certainly understand that whenever a program like the program on 60 Minutes is broadcast there would be an upsurge in interest and certainly a great number of people would believe they have been affected. I am not complaining about that at all. I certainly do not believe that ignorance is bliss in this matter. I will seek from the Minister for Health further details of what Senator Haines required. I believe that it is a very serious matter. It is one of the medical tragedies which occur and it is one of the tragedies which will always occur as long as we use drugs or treatments of any kind. That does not lessen the tragedy at all and it does not mean that we should not take very great care to make sure that we can ameliorate the problems which have arisen.

As for Senator Boswell's remarks about the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Holding, scraping the bottom of the barrel in indulging in nasty political tactics in this Parliament, I really think before Senator Boswell talks like that he should go home, get a few copies of the Queensland Hansard and read some of the things that Mr Bjelke-Petersen and Mr Bjelke-Petersen's colleagues and colleagues of Senator Boswell have said in the Queensland Parliament about people such as the former Senator Neville Bonner, who was a distinguished member of the Senate, Senator Georges, and in fact ordinary citizens in the State of Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —I got a serve occasionally.

—And Senator Colston too. In fact, the comments of Queensland members of parliament were so bad that at one stage Senator Georges and Senator Bonner, as I recall it, tried to read in this place straight excerpts from the Queensland Hansard. They were not permitted to do so because of the disgusting content of the Queensland Hansard. Those words were said by the sorts of people that Senator Boswell is now trying to protect.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some facts. As it happens, in the last two days I have spoken in this building, by coincidence, to Aboriginals from north Queensland. Let us look at what may be a little more than rumour. Let us look at what sorts of things have happened in the past. The simple facts are as follows: Mr Killoran is a candidate for the seat of Cook. Mr Killoran for a long time has been the Director of the Queensland Department of Aboriginal and Islanders Advancement. In that role and in that situation he is in fact notorious. It is my information -this information has been given publicly and outside the Parliament; it has been stated on the AM or PM radio program and other programs-that Mr Killoran, in the last couple of years, occasionally turned up in Cairns, the Torres Strait islands, which are in the electorate of Cook, and the northern part of Queensland until six months ago, since when he seems to turn up every couple of weeks. He then seems to travel around the place in a way that he never travelled around before, making promises and being very kind to people. Obviously he knew that he was to be the National Party candidate in that area. That, I believe, is abuse of his position as Director of the Queensland Department of Aboriginal and Islanders Advancement.

The second point is that Wendy Lilja, who happens to be the Australian Labor Party candidate for the seat of Barron River, sought permission to visit the Aboriginal reserve at Wujal Wujal recently. She was informed by the Department of Aboriginal and Islanders Advancement that she could not visit the reserve because the local Aboriginal council did not want her to visit the reserve. She still went. When she got there she found that what she had been told by the Department of Aboriginal and Islanders Advancement was a deliberate lie and that in fact she was very welcome there, as any political candidate should be.

I think it is really getting a bit cheeky, to say the least, for Senator Boswell to come into this place and complain about the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding), in answering a question from Mr Wells, the honourable member for Petrie, mentioning the sorts of things that he mentioned yesterday. I think Senator Boswell must not be aware of what is going on in Queensland. He must not be aware of the complaints of the Aboriginals and Islanders in that State about the treatment they have received from the Department of Aboriginal and Islanders Advancement. He must not be aware of the notoriety of Mr Killoran and his activities in that Department. To suggest that Mr Holding raised the matters that he raised yesterday in the Parliament in a cowardly or any other sinister way is nonsense. The sorts of things he said have been said publicly outside this Parliament. No one has challenged them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you believe that public servants would take children from their parents?

—That is the last point to which I am coming. As it happens, in the last few days I have spoken here to Aboriginal people from the Townsville and Cairns area and in fact from further north because they happened to be in this town. They told me-I happen to believe them because I believe they are honest and trustworthy people-that Aboriginals in that area have been told things such as this: If they vote for the Australian Labor Party they will lose their social security benefits because the Federal Labor Party will take those benefits away from them and give them to the State Labor Government.
—Who told them that?

—They were told that by officers of the Department of Aboriginal and Islanders Advancement and Mr Killoran. That is a deliberate lie. The second thing they were told is that under the Department of Aboriginal and Islanders Advancement, which, I remind honourable senators not only deals with the sorts of affairs one would expect it to look after but also looks after health, education, housing and practically every essential service that people need in the Aboriginal community on reserves in Queensland-
—It administers them. It does not look after them.

—It administers them. It does not look after them well. Those services are administered by the total Department. People from that Department also told Aboriginal people on settlements that if they voted Labor they would be in danger of losing their children because the Labor Party would want to take those children away and send them to school elsewhere. That also is a deliberate lie. It is not surprising that that should happen. It is typical of National Party tactics. I can remember the Australian Labor Party candidate for Leichhardt, a school teacher, losing an election and being refused his job back by the Queensland National Party Government in a way that no other government of this country, Labor or Liberal, would have done. That was done simply because he stood as a Labor Party candidate.

SPEECH.PARA: I can remember the Premier of Queensland-I think it was at the last election, although it may have been at the election previous to that-telling the people of Mount Isa that if they voted Labor they would not get the funds for their water supply and they would not get the sort of treatment that they would get if they voted for the National Party. Those are the sorts of tactics the National Party uses. It is not surprising to me that there have been reports that those are the sorts of tactics the National Party is using now. Senator Boswell has the gall to get up here and suggest that Mr Holding was doing anything other than answering a question straight and answering it factually. As I say, if Senator Boswell thinks that is reaching the bottom of the barrel, he ought to take time off from reading whatever he reads now and read the Queensland Hansard for a while. He will really learn some lessons about what can be found at the bottom of the political barrel or in the gutter.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 8.17 p.m.
