The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 24 August 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why didn't the Australian Government set up a safety committee before the commencement of the 12 nuclear tests carried out in Australia between 1952 and 1957 (see Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council report of January 1983 on British nuclear tests in Australia).
(2) Was there ever a recommendation that an Australian safety committee be appointed before the tests; if so, why wasn't this recommendation acted on and who rejected the proposal.
(3) Why did the Australian Government set up a safety committee before the fourth explosion.
(4) Was it in any way due to concern about the inadequacy of safety procedures during the previous three explosions.
(5) Who were the members of the Atomic Weapons Tests Safety Committee (AWTSC) and what was their 'experience appropriate to the task', as stated in the above- mentioned Report.
(6) Did the AWTSC veto any of the test firing; if so, which ones and for what reasons.
(7) What information, if any, was provided before each detonation on jetstreams .

(8) If no information was provided on jetstreams, does this mean that fallout from these explosions more than likely was transported at very high speed over a much larger part of Australia than is indicated in official reports.
(9) What reappraisal of fallout dispersal has been made by scientists taking into account modern knowledge of jetstreams.
(10) Did the 80 sample collection stations set up in Australia take into account jetstream dispersal or were they based solely on the idea of lower level prevailing winds at the time of each test.
(11) On how many occasions did the post-firing analyses yield results at variance with the predictions of cloud height and fallout pattern.
(12) How exactly was the pre-firing meteorological information gathered and what was considered to be 'favourable conditions'.

(13) Have any tests for caesium-137 and other radionuclides been carried out on drains in Adelaide and other parts of the country as the report states that it is likely some of the fallout would have undoubtedly entered drainage systems: if so, what were the results; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am unaware of the reasons why a safety committee was not set up by the Australian Government until after the third nuclear test. However, I note that there was a substantial Australian involvement-not only for the first test but for the two that followed in 1953-in the form of meteorological and other services, scientific personnel and consultants.
(2) I am unaware of any recommendations for the formation of an Australian safety committee prior to the commencement of the nuclear tests.

(3) I refer the honourable senator to Chapter 7 of the report by the Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council (AIRAC) 'British nuclear tests in Australia- a review of operational safety measures and of possible after-effects' (AIRAC No . 9) which was tabled in the Senate on 1 June 1983.
(4) See 3 above.
(5) The Atomic Weapons Tests Safety Committee (AWTSC) had the following membership:
Professor Sir L. H. Martin, Professor of Physics, University of Melbourne, Chairman (1955-57).
Professor Sir E. W. Titterton, Professor of Nuclear Physics, Australian National University; Member (1955-57), Chairman (1957-73).
Mr W. A. S. Butement, Chief Scientist, Department of Supply; Member (1955-57).
Mr L. J. Dwyer, Director Commonwealth Bureau of Meteorology; Member (1955-60).
Dr C. E. Eddy, Director, Commonwealth X-Ray and Radium Laboratory; Member (1955 -56).
Dr W. J. Gibbs, Director, Commonwealth Bureau of Meteorology; Member (1960-73).
Mr D. J. Stevens, Director, Commonwealth X-Ray and Radium Laboratory; Member ( 1956-73).
Dr J. H. Martin, Physics Department, Cancer Institute Board, Melbourne; Member (1957-59).
Mr J. R. Moroney, Scientist, Department of Supply; Member (1965-73).
(6) No test in the Mosaic, Buffalo, or Antler series of 1956-57 was carried out without approval for firing from the AWTSC.
(7) Before the planned firing time of each test the AWTSC was provided with all available meteorological data by the Bureau of Meteorology.

(9) Fallout data for the nuclear tests were published in full by the AWTSC. They have been reviewed and published by the National Radiation Advisory Committee and by the Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council.
(10) The sample collection stations, set up in Australia, were sited so as effectively to cover the whole of Australia, with particular regard to centres of population and their food supplies.
(11) See AIRAC report No. 9.
(12) See AIRAC report No. 9.

(13) The statement in the AIRAC report refers to an example of factors which would reduce the estimates of radiation dose; the point being that the AWTSC estimates were deliberately cautious. It should be noted that any such fallout which might have entered the stormwater drainage system of a city would have been removed from the living environment of its population. Caesium-137 and strontium-90 in the environment and food supply of Adelaide (and of the other major centres of population in Australia) were monitored for twenty years or more, commencing in 1957. The radionuclides arose virtually entirely from nuclear weapons tests conducted in the atmosphere by USA and USSR in the northern hemisphere, and by France in the southern hemisphere.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 24 August 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the exact purpose of the Ministerial Staff Advisory Panel.
(2) What were the names of the people who served on the Panel and those who provided support services to it.
(3) How long was each member and support staff employed on the Panel, and how much was each member paid.
(4) What was the total cost of the Panel's activities.
(5) How many applicants were received by the Panel.
(6) How many applicants were recommended for positions with Ministers and office holders.
(7) How many ministerial positions were actually filled as a result of the work of the Panel.
(8) How many Ministers and office holders retain the services of the staff recommended by the Ministerial Staff Advisory Panel.
(9) Who appointed the members of the Panel.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Ministerial Staff Advisory Panel advised the Government on the suitability of candidates for appointment to Ministers' staff other than those engaged solely in secretarial positions (that is, below Assistant Private Secretary level), although some support positions were also considered.
(2) The members of the panel were: Professor P. Wilenski (later replaced by Mrs C. Benn), Mr W. P. Butler, Mr T. Moran.

Up to two officers of the Department in the normal course of their duties provided assistance to the Panel at any one time by performing clerical and stenographic functions. The officers varied from time to time, and it is not practicable to name them. In addition officers of the Department provided support services to the Panel indirectly ranging from the payment of fees to the provision of accommodation.
(3) Professor P. Wilenski was employed for 4 days. A total of $902.42 was paid for his services to the Australian National University, where he was at the time employed.
Mrs C. Benn was employed for 2 1/2 days and was paid $567.50.
Mr W. P. Butler was employed for 42 days and was paid $9,163.88.
Mr Moran was employed for a period of 14 1/2 days. The Victorian Public Service Board where he was employed at the time was paid a total of $3,233.50.
In addition to the direct payments made, members of the Panel received Travel Allowances and expenses at the rates applicable to members of the Second Division of the Public Service.

As indicated above up to two persons assisted the Panel at any one time. One was at the Steno-secretary, Grade 1 ($14,070-14,790) classification while the clerical assistance varied, being at the Clerk, Class 8 ($26,800-27,850) or Clerk, Class 6 levels ($22,080-23,480).
(4) It is not possible to extract the exact costs for the support services provided to the Panel due to the varied and ad hoc nature of the services given.
Identifiable costs are:
$ Fees 13,867.30 Fares 1,879.50 Travelling allowances 1,233.65
(5) Although the activities of the Panel have now been wound up, applications addressed to the Panel are still being received. As at 15 October 1983, 1,830 applications had been received.
(8) 25. As at 15 October 1983, 93 persons who were engaged as a result of the Panel's activities were still engaged on Ministers' staffs.
(9) The Prime Minister.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Vandalism in National Parks of Tasmania

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 August 1983 (Hansard, page 254) Senator Chipp asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, without notice:

QUESTION.PARA: (i) whether the Government would move quickly to establish a management authority in South West Tasmania and,
(ii) whether the Government would gazette the Cradle Mountain-Lake St Clair and South-West national parks under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act.
The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided me with further information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

(i) The Government is moving as quickly as possible towards the establishment of long term management arrangements for the South West Tasmania World Heritage Area and proposals are being developed for the consideration of both the Commonwealth and Tasmanian governments. It will of course be necessary for any arrangements and the level of Commonwealth support to be agreed with the State, although it is not possible, at this stage to indicate the detailed form which the arrangements might take. Legislative requirements and the possible establishment of an authority will be considered in the proposals. I should mention, however, that on 31 August 1983 the Prime Minister offered the Tasmanian Government immediate financial assistance to be used by the Tasmanian National Parks and Wildlife Service for essential management purposes in the World Heritage Area during the period until permanent arrangements can be settled.
(ii) I do not consider that further action under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act is appropriate at this time.
